Alabama (Bryan Grayson and Abi Smith)

 

LNG Aff

Plan-
The United States Federal Government, through the Federal Energy
Regulatory Commission, should establish an energy policy prohibiting,
in the United States, non-governmental consumption of natural gas that
has undergone regasification.

Advantage 1:  LNG Bad

Subpoint A:  China

US dependence on LNG is intensifying.  Terminal construction is
accelerating. Darley 04, British Environmental Researcher and Founder
of Global Public Media  [Julian, High noon for natural gas, p. 64-65]
responding to the global...LNG imports

There is nothing that will stop the construction in the status quo.
Even the EPA concludes that FERC ignores environmental and security
concerns when making decisions about LNG importation
O'Driscoll  Sept 24, 04    [Mary O'Driscoll "LNG: EPA FAULTS FERC ON
ENVIRONMENTAL ASSESSMENT OF WEAVER'S COVE PLANT," Greenwire , Vol. 10
No. 9, pg. ln]edlee
The U.S. EPA this week...project can move forward, according to EPA.

Unfortunately, US LNG dependence will force it to maintain Marines and
Special Forces in the Straits of Malacca.  Blanche 04,  Member of the
International Institute for Strategic Studies in London  [Ed, "Tanker
terror: Gulf's oil routes under threat," Daily Star, April 22,
http://www.dailystar.com.lb/article.asp?edition_id=10&categ_id=3&article_id=2597#]edlee
There are growing concerns...devastation it could produce.

2/3rds of the world's LNG passes through the Straits of Malacca in the
South China Seas.  US Energy Information Administration 98      ["South
China Sea Region," pg.
http://members.tripod.com/paracels74/energy.htm]edlee
More than half of the world's annual merchant...longer voyage by
several hundred miles.

This increase in US naval activity in the South China Seas risks
accidents or miscalculation. Either would result in war with China.
Cossa 98, Executive Director of Pacific Forum CSIS  [Ralph, "Security
Implications of Conflict in the South China Sea: Exploring Potential
Triggers of Conflict." PacNet Newsletter, #16, April 17, pg.
http://www.csis.org/pacfor/pac1698.html]edlee
Refraining from further...stumbling into conflict.

The terminal impact is nuclear holocaust.    Johnson 01, President of
the Japan Policy Research Institute     [Chalmer, "Time to Bring the
Troops Home." Nation, 05/14/2001, Vol. 272 Issue 19,
p20//EBSCOhost]edlee
China is another matter...no deterrent effect.

Subpoint B:  Iran

US commitment to LNG will permanently lock-in dependence on foreign
supplies of gas.  Darley 04, British Environmental Researcher and
Founder of Global Public Media          [Julian, High noon for natural gas,
p. 3-4]

Iran is quickly moving into this market and it has the gas reserves to
be a dominant player
Lloyd's List Sept 20, 04  [Tony Gray, "Iran moves nearer to LNG
debut," Issue #58748; Business & Insurance; Pg. 2]edlee
IRAN has moved...reserves after Russia.

Iran will use its economic clout to manipulate the LNG market to the
detriment of US interest
Paul Roberts 04, The End of Oil

And …. Iraqi invasion foreshadowed the US response.  It will launch
preemptive attacks on Iran to secure access to gas.  Darley 04,
British Environmental Researcher and Founder of Global Public Media
[Julian, High noon for natural gas, p. 133]

War against Iran will escalate to a US-Russian nuclear war
Gaffney 2003 (Mark; Researcher, Writer, Anti-Nuclear Activist) "Will
Iran Be Next?" Alternatives: Turkish Journal of International Affairs
Summer Vol. 2 #2
http://www.alternativesjournal.net/volume2/number2/gaffney.pdf
It is very possible...other suspect sites.

US-Russian nuclear war ensures planetary extinction
Caldicott 02, Founder of Physicians for Social Responsibility
[Helen, The new nuclear danger, p. 7-12]
If launched from Russia...September 11 attack.

Without the AFFIRMATIVE we risk permanently locking-in US LNG
dependence.  A transition to energy efficiency and renewables will
prevent consumers from noticing the reduction in natural gas
availability.
Coequyt and Albrecht 04, Greenpeace Researchers         [John and Katie,
Liquid Natural Gas: A roadblock to a clean energy future, Sept. 7, pg.
lng_report.pdf]edlee
California is currently...another LNG  terminal (see Table 1). Pg. 25-27

Advantage 2 - Asian Pipelines

The Global LNG market is on the BRINK and US support is critical to
its survival.
Yergin and Stoppard 03, Chair and Director of Global LNG @ Cambridge
Energy Research Associates'
[Daniel and Michael, "The Next Prize," Foreign Affairs, Foreign
Affairs, November/December, pg. ln]edlee
A new global energy business...later in the decade.

Additionally, The US is the sweet spot in the LNG market.
Discontinuity of imports will ripple throughout the global gas markets
crushing the viability of LNG as a means for distributing natural gas.
Jaffe and Victor 04, Fellow for Energy Studies @ Rice University and
Director of the Program on Energy and Sustainable Development @
Stanford University. [Amy and David, "Executive Summary: Geopolitics
of Gas Working Paper Series,"  August, Pg. Gas_Exec_Sum.pdf]edlee
A major conclusion...power generators (see case study, Ball/Shepherd).

Asia is dependent on Natural Gas.  The lack of a LNG option will force
them to embrace pipelines.  They can quickly make the shift with the
right impetus.
Miyazaki 03 [Jamie Miyazaki, "Natural gas's new global role," Asia
Times, Nov. 11,  pg.
http://www.atimes.com/atimes/Global_Economy/EK11Dj01.html]edlee
Natural gas is beginning...to their customers.

Asian Pipelines are critical to prevent 3 Independent Scenarios for Nuclear War

A.  East China Sea

Pipeline diffuses Sino-Japanese competition for Natural Gas
Ogutchu 03, Principal Administrator @ Organization of Economic
Cooperation and Development
[Mehmet, A graduate of London School of Economics and College
d'Europe, Bruges, "Asian and Chinese Security Issues in the Decade to
2011" Oil, Gas, & Energy Law Intelligence, Fifth Asian Security
Conference 26-29 January 2003, pg.
http://www.gasandoil.com/ogel/samples/freearticles/article_15.htm]edlee
China's energy interests...energy strategies.

Their current Gas competition risk turning the East China Sea into
tinderbox.  China and Japan must find areas of cooperation to prevent
conflict
Takahashi 04    [Kosuke, "Gas and oil rivalry in the East China Sea,"
Asia Times, July 27, pg.
http://www.atimes.com/atimes/Japan/FG27Dh03.html]edlee
Current explorations...gas field.

A conflict over the East China Seas will quickly escalate into a Nuclear war.
Howle 01, Lieutenant Colonel and Executive officer for operations to
the Undersecretary of the Army
[Roy C. Jr., "An Evitable War: Engaged Containment and the US-China
Balance," Parameters , Autumn 2001, pp. 92-104//
http://carlisle-www.army.mil/usawc/Parameters/01autumn/Howle.htm]edlee
Within the last...bombing forces.

B.  Korea

Gas pipeline prevents North Korean belligerence, economically
reintegrate it, and usher in a era of multilateral cooperation
Paik 00, Research Fellow @ Royal Institute of International Affairs
[Keun-Wook, "Revitalising North Korea's Energy :Based on pipeline gas
option," Korean Peninsula: Enhancing Stability and International
Dialogue 1-2 June 2000, Roma, pg. 0033.pdf]edlee
Another option...without confrontation.  Pg. 171-172

North Korea remains a flashpoint for global war. Engagement is the
only way to prevent regime collapse.
Asia Today in Feb. 04   ["The Koreas: Moody's costs the options," pg. ln]edlee
IN THE ABSENCE...suspended its aid.

Regime collapse will trigger a nuclear civil war that risks nuclear
attacks on the US, Japan, and South Korea.
Bennett and Hachigian 04, Senior Analyst and Director of Center for
Asia Pacific Policy at RAND Corporation
[Bruce and Nina, "Don't try regime change in North Korea",
International Herald Tribune, January 31, LN] bg
Ideally, regime change...would be greater.

C.  India-Pakistan

LNG prospects permanently halt movement towards Indi-Paki gas
pipeline.  The pipeline would serve as a confidence building measure
resolving disputes in other areas
Tongia & Arunachalam 99, Professors of Engineering and Public Policy @
Carnegie Mellon University
[Rahul and V.S., Natural Gas Imports by South Asia: Pipelines or
Pipedreams? Economic & Political Weekly (1999) XXXIV(18) pg.
Tongia_pipeline.pdf]edlee

The window of opportunity...win-win prospect.  Pg. 32-35

Indo-Paki CBMs are crucial to avoid conflict escalation and
miscalculation as each country deals with terrorism and the Kashmir
dispute
Bagchee and Randolph 01, Journalist Specializing in International
Affiars & Doctoral candidate in Political Science at Cornell
[Deepanshu and Matthew, "Safety first: building confidence during the
nuclear transition," The Hindu, Sept 3 3,
pg. http://people.cornell.edu/pages/mcr4/The%20Hindu%20%20Safety%20first%20building%20confidence%20during%20the%20nuclear%20transition.htm]edlee
Amid all the post-Agra...nuclear status-quo.

The impact is Nuclear winter and extinction
Fai 01, Executive director @ Kashmiri American Council.         [Ghulam Nabi,
"The most dangerous place," The Washington Times, July 08, Pg. B4
The foreign policy...Material/Cut-off Convention.

Finally, Asia is a region ripe for both cooperation and conflict.
Natural Gas pipelines will usher in an area of multilateral
cooperation and halt the slide toward multiple conflicts
Nakano 03 - Visiting Scholar of Asian Studies @ George Washington University.
[Tamotsu, Chief Researcher in the Northeast Asia Project division at
KRI International, Ltd., a Japanese consulting firm. He was the
coordinator of the "Grand Design for Northeast Asia" project,
sponsored by the National Institute for Research Advancement, a
leading Japanese think tank., International Journal on World Peace,
September 1, No. 3, Vol. 20; Pg. 37//ln]edlee
Northeast Asia...multilateral economic cooperation.

NERC AFF

Contention One: Power Failure

Despite the 2003 blackout, compliance with all North American
Electricity Reliability council standards remains entirely voluntary
Atlanta-Journal Constitution 8 / 14 / 04

Voluntary standards are doomed to fail--noncompliance by one entity
puts the entire grid at risk
Philadelphia Inquirer 4 / 10 / 04

Entire electric faces growing reliability problems that make a
catastrophic blackout inevitable
Clemence 04, Business Writer for Times Union    [Sara, "We're still in
the dark," Times Union, Aug 8, LN] bg

Even small blackouts can cascade and cause region-wide power outages
U.S.-Canada Power System Outage Task Force 04
["Final Report on the August 14, 2003 Blackout in the United States
and Canada," Apr,
https://reports.energy.gov/BlackoutFinal-Web.pdf]

Blackout will cause mass casualties and leave the US vulnerable to
nuclear attack
Congressional Press Releases 10 / 7 / 99

Iran is looking to preemptively strike the USâ€"the conflict will
immediately go nuclear
UPI 8 / 19 / 04

Iran has nuclear and ICBM technologies
Anthony Cordesman 01, "The Missile Threat from North Korea, Iran, and
Iraq and the Rationale for National Missile Defense," Center for
Strategic and International Studies, Jan 24

And, a blackout will tax nuclear power safety systems and risks a
catastrophic meltdown
Public Citizen '03
(The Big Blackout and Amnesia in Congress: Lawmakers Turn a Blind Eye
to the Danger of Nuclear Power and the Failure of Deregulation, at
www.citizen.org/documents/bigblackout.pdf.)abi

Nuclear meltdown will instantly kill 100,000 with many more deaths to
come over time
Caldicott 94, Founder of Physicians for Social Responsibility
[Helen, Nuclear madness, p. 63-64]

And, the massive release of radiation ultimately risks human extinction
Caldicott 94, Founder of Physicians for Social Responsibility
[Helen, Nuclear madness, p. 21-22]

Canada is already acting to enforce mandatory reliability

Plan:
The United States Federal Government, through congressional
legislation, should make compliance with North American Electricity
Reliability Council rules mandatory and enforceable.

Contention Three: Solvency

Mandatory NERC standards are essential to prevent future blackouts and
ensure the long-term reliability of the electricity grid
Gent 04, President and CEO of NERC
[Michehl R., "Prepared testimony of Michehl R. Gent before the Senate
Committee on Energy and Natural Resources," Federal News Service, Feb
24, LN] bg

Mandatory reliability rules are essential to prevent industry backsliding
Chattanooga Times Free Press 8 / 10 / 04

Federal legislation is the only legal means by which to create
mandatory reliability standards
NERC 04
["Legislation Action is Needed to Maintain Electric System
Reliability," http://www.nerc.com/about/legislation.html] bg

Coordination of standards at the federal level is essential to ensure
international compatibility which is necessary for grid reliability
NERC 03 ["NERC's Electric Reliability Legislative Proposal," Dec,
http://www.nerc.com/about/faq.html] bg

Federal oversight ensures adequate communication between aspects of
the electric grid which is vital for reliability
Makovich 03, CERA Senior Director for Americas Gas and Power Research
[Lawrence J., "Contributing events and causes of the blackout,"
Federal News Service, Sep 4, LN] bg

Arizona State JG

 

Here is our 1AC outline. Sorry I do not have the negative arguments
yet. I will try to get them to you tomorrow or Saturday. Also, do you
expect full citations for negative arguments or simply a list?

ASU GJ 1AC

Inherency

Power Industry on brink of bankruptcy and power shortages will occur by 2008
Nuclear News 2004 (Special Report: 2003 ANS/ENS Intl. Winter Meeting, Jan)

Plan: The United States federal government should establish an energy
policy requiring a substantial reduction in the total non-governmental
consumption of fossil fuels in the United States by establishing a
binding cap of year 2000 levels by 2020, and providing production tax
credits for new nuclear power plant construction through normal means.
We'll clarify.

Advantage 1: Water

50% of the global population will die from lack of water by 2025. Asia and
Africa will suffer the most. Desalinization is key to prevent the shortage.
IAEA 2002 (Market Potential for Non-Electric Applications of Nuclear Energy,
Technical Reports Series No. 410)

Water Shortage makes biodiversity loss and water wars inevitable in South Asia
Grossman 2004 (Zoltan, Asst. Prof @ U Wisconsin Eau Claire, "Water Wars and
International Conflict")

Biodiversity loss causes extinction
The Guardian 10/10/2000 p. lexis

Water wars will occur between more than 50 countries on 5 continents
in the coming years. Past patterns of instability won't occur in the
future, and small-level conflicts will spread to global wars.
Postel and Wolf 2k1 (Sandra L. Postel directs the Global Water Policy
Project in Amherst, Massachusetts. She is also a senior fellow with
Worldwatch Institute and a visiting senior lecturer in environmental
studies at Mount Holyoke College. Aaron T. Wolf is an associate
professor of geography at Oregon State University's Department of
Geosciences, and director of the Transboundary Freshwater Dispute
Database project. Foreign Policy, 9/18)

Water war conflict in South Asia will cause extinction
Washington Times 7/8/2003

Nuclear power key to water desalinization in South Asia, Middle East and Africa
IAEA 2002 (same as above)

Advantage 2: Nuclear Medicine

Nuclear medicine and other programs requiring radioisotopes are dying because
the DOE is ending supply
Science News 10/23/99

Reactors are key to radioisotopes
Morris 2k (Robert. The Environmental case for nuclear power: economic,
medical, and political considerations)

Nuclear power isotopes are key to cure diseases like AIDS, cancer and Alzheimers
Columbus Dispatch 9/10/94

AIDS threatens extinction
Veljkovich 99 (AIDS Day special, p. newsrolls.com)

Advantage 3: Proliferation

The NPT and IAEA are dying. Action is needed to reinvigorate the regime
El Baradei 2003 (Mohammed, Dir. of IAEA, The Acronym Institute, 11/3)

Only continual development of nuclear power can uphold article IV of the NPT,
which is key to the global non proliferation regime
Sanders 2004 (Jackie, Ambassador for Non-Proliferation, 4/29,
www.state.gov/t/np/rls/rm/32292.htm)

Nuclear power will prevent global proliferation by fostering cooperative
relations and international norms against proliferation and towards peaceful
nuclear power
Nuclear News 2004 (same as above)

Norms solve – NPT proves
Paine 99 (Christopher, CATO analyst, Cato Policy Analysis no. 330, Jan. 15, p.
online)

Waltz was wrong – proliferation can be unpredictable and makes intentional or
accidental nuclear war an inevitability
National Journal 9/16/2002

Solvency

Government subsidies for plant construction will spur nuclear energy
Deutch 2003 (Prof. of Chem @ MIT, "The Future of Nuclear Power",
web.mit.edu/nuclearpower)

Policy measures restricting greenhouse gas emissions will spur nuclear energy,
the only technology capable of cutting fossil fuels
IAEA 2002 (same as above)

Strong domestic leadership and support for nuclear power is key to US global
nuclear leadership
NEI 2000 (Nuclear Energy Institute, Nuclear Energy: The Renaissance Revealed)

Strong US action will bolster leadership critical to expand the use of nuke
power, including all its benefits
NEI 2000 (above)

Nuclear power is the safest form of energy, saving thousands of lives per
year. It emits no harmful emissions and 100 times less radioactivity than
fossil fuels
McGregor 2001 (Douglas, dir. of SMART at U Mich, "Rethinking Nuclear Power")

Expansion of Nuclear power will be with light water reactors with enhanced
safety systems
Blix 97 (Hans, "Nuclear Energy in 21st Century, Nuclear News, Sept)

LWR aren't proliferation or theft risk because they don't enrich uranium enough
Haeberlin 2004 (Scott, nuclear safety expert, A Case for Nuclear Generated
Electricity)

New LWRs will prevent accidents
Deutch 2003 (above)

Safeguards prevent any accident.
Schrock '98 (Jonathan. "Nuclear Power: a clean safe alternative"
www.goshen.edu/bio/Bio1410/BSSPapers98/schrock/schrock.html#electricity)

Both high and low level waste are disposed of safely. There's no
immediate need for a final storage facility.
Leon, et al. 2k1 ("Sustainable Solutions for radioactive waste," The
OECD Observer no 226/7 Summer)

Augustana GS

 

CAFÉ AFF READ AT DISTRICTS

OBSERVATION 1:  WARMING IS HAPPENING NOW

Warming is occurring and is anthropogenic- the only question should be what should we do about it

Fox 2/18/05  (“February 18, 2005 4:45PM Studies confirm global warming underway By Maggie Fox, Health and Science Correspondent http://www.swissinfo.html?siteSect=143&sid=5548239

 

“A parcel of studies looking at the… we going to do about it.”

Multiple indicators prove we are in danger from warming now.

Gelbspan 2/17/05(People’s Ratification Of The Kyoto Global Warming Treaty by Ross Gelbspan February 17, 2005 Grist Magazine http://www.zmag.org)

 

“As if on cue… We are in it now.”

Records, soil cores, and tree ring data confirm the global warming models predictions of warming:

Columbus Dispatch, March 16, 2004; Lexis

Last year's deadly summer…the greenhouse effect.

We are reaching the point of no return- cuts are needed now 

Gelbspan 2/17/05(People’s Ratification Of The Kyoto Global Warming Treaty by Ross Gelbspan February 17, 2005 Grist Magazine http://www.zmag.org)

 

“In late January… for 420,000 years.”

Continued warming will accelerate and ensure extinction

Edwards and Cromwell 2/9/2005

(“Silence is Green the Green Movement And the Corporate Mass Media”)

 

“Humanity has chosen… would be suicidal.”

We are at the breaking point – must take action to stop warming now or risk extinction

Engelhardt 2/7/2005

“In a new study published… crucial point is reached.”

NEG. authors are bought and sold by the fossil fuel industry:  Singer, Michaels, Lindzen, and Balling are uniquely biased: 

BERGER, 2000 (JOHN, Beating the heat: why and how we must combat global warming, Published by Berkeley Hills Books; Berkeley, California, PG.     62)

Climate skeptics also play… unable to sort out the truth.

SCENARIO 1:  CORAL EXTINCTION

CO2 build up in the atmosphere will make the ocean too acidic killing coral reefs

Clover 2/4/05 (“Acid Seads Will Kill Off Coral Within 70 Years” The Telegraph UK 2-4-5” http://www.rense.com/general62/cpr.htm)

 

“Coral reefs could be dead within two generations… need to do more research.”

Ocean acidification will wipe out the whole marine food chain

McCarthy 2/4/05 (“Greenhouse has threaten marine life” http://www.climateark.org/articles/reader.asp?linkid=386450)

 

“Gigantic changes to the oceans… future of coral reefs.”

Long term studies show that rising sea temperatures will kill 95% of coral on existing reefs

Channel NewsAsia, 2/21/04 LEXIS

 

“Authors Hans and Ove… or even face extinction, the report said.”

Major reductions in GHG emissions necessary to save coral reefs.

Channel NewsAsia, 2/21/04 LEXIS

“the government announced plans in December… at times beyond 2050.”

Reefs are an essential life support system necessary for human survival.

Philippine Daily Inquirer 12/10/2002 LEXIS

“Coral reefs are the marine equivilant… in our planet, she said.”

Acidification risks ending all life on earth.

Lean 2/6/2005 (The Independent LEXIS)

“What could happen?… die within 35 years.”

 


Scenario 2: Rainforests

Warming will destroy rainforests

Lean 2/6/2005 (The Independent LEXIS)

“What could happen? Famously wet tropical forests… smoke over vast areas.”

Rainforests are the earth’s lungs: destroying them undermines human ability to survive

Chiang, staff, Science World, 4/26/2004 LEXIS

“What if humans destroy… cope with the change.”

OBSERVATION 2:

Scenario 1: AIR POLLUTION

Motor vehicles cause more air pollution than any other single human activity:

Leslie Harrison Reed, Jr., Navy Office of General Counsel, 1997 (24 B.C. Envtl. Aff. L. Rev. 695, Boston College Environmental Affairs Law Review; Lexis)

Motor vehicles… areas to vehicular sources.

THIS THREATENS BILLIONS OF PEOPLE: 

Roberts, Earth Policy Insitute, September 17, 2002

(http://www.earth-policy.org/Updates/Update17.htm)

In the United States… billions of people.

Thus the Plan:

AIRPLANES AFF RUN AT DISTRICTS

Observation 1:  Growth in domestic airline travel is causing massive pollution

Airline exhaust emissions cause a massive global warming effect—spewing emissions into the upper atmosphere causes two to three times the warming effect of Co2 alone

Clayton, 2/9/2005, http://www.alternet.org/envirohealth/21225/

“Although jets create…carbon dioxide alone”

 

Projected increases in airline traffic will massively increase the environmental damage caused by airplanes

Clayton, 2/9/2005, http://www.alternet.org/envirohealth/21225/

“By 2050, carbon-dioxide…climate-change models”

 

Advantage 1:  Global Warming

Extremely qualified data says that emissions in the upper atmosphere have an enormous warming effect:

Dempsey, Journal of Air Law and Commerce, Fall 2000 (J. Air L. & Com. 639; Lexis)

“The most comprehensive study…as carbon dioxide alone”

 

Scientific consensus agrees:  jet engines cause global warming:

The Times, 8/4/2004; Lexis

“Yet there is now little dispute…would at ground level”

 

One airline flight can spew out as much Co2 as 80 SUV’s emit in a full year of driving

Rijnen, International Herald Tribune, 2/28/2003; Lexis

“On a round trip…full year of hard driving”

 

By 2020, aircraft will consume the entire amount of greenhouse gases agreed to be reduced by Kyoto:

Dempsey, Journal of Air Law and Commerce, Fall 2000 (J. Air L. & Com. 639; Lexis)

“Still other sources calculate…eliminate in Kyoto”

 

Warming is occurring and is anthropegenic—the only question should be what we do about it:

Fox, 2/18/2005; http://www.swissinfo.org/sen/swissinfo.html?siteSect=143&sid=5548239

“A parcel of studies looking…do about it”

Advantage 2:  Ozone Depletion

Greenhouse gas emissions from airplanes increase the size, depth, and persistence of ozone depletion

Drumbl, Tulane Law Review, 76 Tul. L. Rev. 843, Lexis

“New culprits…depth and persistence”

 

Because aircraft pollute in the upper atmosphere, they contribute more profoundly to ozone depletion than ground based sources

Dempsey, Journal of Air Law and Commerce, Fall 2000 (J. Air L. & Com. 639; Lexis)

“Yet of all the modes of transport…via catalytic reaction”

 

Stratsopheric ozone depletion threatens human survival

Turco, 2003; http:www.ioe.ucla.edu/academic/M1Breadings/Ozone%20Handout-03doc.pdf

“Ozone is singled out…survive on this planet”

 

Plan at Districts:

The United States federal government should establish an energy policy requiring a substantial reduction in the total non-governmental consumption of fossil fuels in the United States by creating an emissions trading system for the domestic airline industry with a cap on fossil fuel consumption equivalent to a domestic emissions reduction from airplanes by 40% by 2010.

 

Observation 2:  Solvency

Studies prove:  an emissions cap and trade system for the aviation industry is a cost-effective measure to solve Co2 emissions by airplanes:

International Civil Aviation Organization, 10/30/2001

http://www.aee.faa.gov/emissions/global/ICAO_to_SBSTA15-Oct2001.htm

“One of the principal findings…civil aviation in the long term”

 

Climate change policies must be tailored to aviation’s specific characteristics—their generic counterplan solvency won’t apply:

International Air Transport Association, 2/8/2004

http://www.icao.int/icao/en/assembl/a35/wp/wp085_en.pdf

“climate change policies…cost-effective solutions”

 


Requiring emissions reductions from aircraft engines will lead to technological innovations

Royden, 2003; http://www.4cleanair.org/AircraftTestimony.pdf

“The history of Clean Air Act implementation…accelerate technological innovation”

 

Tradable permits for airlines creates the best carrot & stick

British Airways, last modified, 2/18/2005

“Based on historical…enhance emissions reductions”

 

A requirement of a 40% reduction in jet engine emissions by 2010 is feasible:

Dempsey, Journal of Air Law and Commerce, Fall 2000 (J. Air L. & Com. 639; Lexis)

“Some nations are urging…by the year 2010.”

 

Further, the empirical success of automobile emission controls prove that regulatory standards can be a catalyst for the airline industry:

Dempsey, Journal of Air Law and Commerce, Fall 2000 (J. Air L. & Com. 639; Lexis)

“Further, some air transportation…significantly curtail pollution”

 

And the plan creates a framework for an international airline emissions trading scheme:

International Air Transport Association, 2/8/2004; http:www.icao.int/icao/en/assembl/a35/wp/wp085_en.pdf

“Under the second approach…monitoring and compliance”

 

Action on reducing emissions keeps other nations on board to meet their Kyoto targets:

Lindsay, Brookings Review, 9/22/2001

“Creating a two-track system…reducing its emissions”

 

Slowing the rate of warming allows for society & the environment to adapt:

Reuters, 3/10/99 (http://www.crystalinks.com/greenhouse3.html)

If temperatures change slowly...potential cause for concern

Columbia Affirmative

 

Contention 1

 

  1. The US is fighting a CIA-backed proxy war to extract, export, and consume Columbia’s oil supplies; U.S. militarization of Columbia is not about the drug war, it’s an oil war; (Troy Skeels, eat the state, v5, #23, 7-25-01, http://eaththestate.org/05-23/PlanColumbiaAndean.htm)

 

  1. Plan Columbia represents modernity’s fitting of the subaltern in to the problem-solution framework; this is doomed to fail and inevitable leads to imperialism; we need an ontological break from this: (Arturo Escobar, Third World Quarterly, v25, p.2-07-230, 2004, “Beyond the Third World: Imperial, Globality…..”)

 

  1. Plan Columbia is a process of circumscribing being, placing it on a standing reserve. The US government attempts to lay the wqorld sphere before our panoptic gaze as part of a broader claim to truth and power over the other; in this situation, the world inevitably becomes what we view it as, which makes all of the government’s claims not only self-fulfilling, but inherently suspect: (Spanos, 2000; America’s Shadow: An Anatomy of Empire)

 

  1. The American humanist project leads to physical and ontological destruction; we continue to develop and deploy new weapons to genocide against others (Spanos, same source as above, p.154-155).

 

  1. Plan Columbia is designed to exterminate small farmers and indigenous people (Hector Mondragon, 2000; Z Magazine, http://www.zmag.org/crisescurevts/colombia/gas1.htm)

 

 

PLAN: The United States federal government should ban the nongovernmental import and consumption of fossil fuels from the region known as Colombia.

 

Contention 2- we think that the plan let’s Colombia be- only such an ontological rupture can hope to oppose the pax metaphysica. The plan is an action, but also a rethinking itself

(Spanos, same book, p.192-193).

 

 

 

Fossil Fuels AFF

 

Contention 1- Too Late

 

A. Human-centric commodification mentality, exemplified by our addiction to fossil fuels, has ushered in a new age of the anthropocene that ensures humyn extinction; where humans are, other beings are not; we are now left with an ethical choice—do nothing and let the earth be extinguished, or act in the name of the beauty and intrinsic value of nature

(Mark Lynas 04- http://www.newstatesman.com/Ideas/200402230015)

 

B. Human extinction is inevitable- it is the natural course of evolution. There is no reason to prolong life; the threat of pending extinction presents us with a moment to think like a mountain, and to remember that when humyn life is gone, rocks will dance. Only ecocentric thought will allow us to change; embracing despair is the only way to continue living as humyns:

(John Seed, http://www.rainforestinfo.org.au/deep-eco/Anthropo.htm; “thinking like a mountain”)

 

C. Anthropocentrism totally distorts our concept of being; it represents at once the death of god, but also the positing of people as gods. This dualism has left us in a void of being where there is literally no meaning to our existence. Our localized concept of being/self is more shattering and destructive than nuclear annihilation (McKibben, 1990; “The End of Nature”, the New Yorker, p.78-79).

 

PLAN: The USFG should ban all nongovernmental consumption of fossil fuels in the united states.

 

Contention 2- Making amends

 

  1. Life is an anthropocentric concept. Seeing this construct by embracing the inevitability of human extinction brings a spiritual affirmation to our existence that nothing- not even death- can take away. Our task is to care for nature as we care for part of ourself (Seed ’88, same as above).

 

  1. Banning fossil fuel consumption launches a process of unlearning and will pave the way for ecocentric thought to take hold. (Saloor 04; Harry, founder of the management school of restorative business, http://www.restorative-business.org/selected_articles.htm)

 

  1. Life, in its barest form, is an insufficient value in the face of extinction; we need ecocentrism as a process of self-experiencewhere we recognize the other, marginalized side of our being. Only this form of ecocentrism gives life a value, both in living, and in death: (Klaus Bosselmann, When Worlds Collide, no page #).

 

Berkeley LR

Binghamton, Jake Gartman & Matt Malia

BINGHAMTON GM:

Observation One: Inherency

Bush will bring voluntary emission intensity reductions in the status
quo as an alternative to Kyoto – unfortunately this actually
guarantees increased emissions, it does however non-unique much of
neg's offense.

Knox 2K4 (John H. [Associate Professor of Law, Pennsylvania State
University, Dickinson School of Law] 12 Penn St. Envtl. L. Rev. 135,
The International Legal Framework for Addressing Climate Change,
Winter 2004)

"In March 2001, when President Bush announced" ... "carbon emissions
or mandatory limits on them."

Plan Text:

The United States federal government should establish an upstream,
auctioned cap and trade system that reduces total non-governmental
consumption of fossil fuels in the United States to 15% below 1990
levels by 2015.

Observation Two: Global Warming

The scientific debate is over – international scientific consensus,
ice core and tree ring data plus ice sheet melting rates all confirm
warming is real and anthropogenic.

Denee A. DiLuigi, 2K2, Special Assistant United States Attorney at the
U.S. Attorney's Office, Northern District of California, J.D. Golden
Gate University School of Law, KYOTO'S SO-CALLED "FATAL FLAWS": A
POTENTIAL SPRINGBOARD FOR DOMESTIC GREENHOUSE GAS REGULATION, 32
Golden Gate U.L. Rev. 693, Spring

"The overwhelming majority of the scientific community believes" ...
"the models indicated less than a tenth of a percent chance that
melting over the last 46 years was the result of normal variations."

The newest scientific research has determined that even slight carbon
increases trigger feedbacks which accelerate warming – we control
uniqueness because the three biggest are rapid and positive.

Fred Pearce, July 24, 2K4, Environmental Consultant for New Scientist,
"Harbingers of doom?" New Scientist, Features; Pg. 44

"Nor was Murphy alone with his tail. He showed a projection by David
Stainforth" ... "major positive feedback to global warming."

Continued warming will cause rapid disease mutation.

[Brunegraber, et al, 1999]
Laura, Mark Bittner, David Zimet, "A Study of the Effects of Global
Warming on the Spread of Vector-Borne Diseases"

"Most directly, warmer temperatures and" ... "dangerous problem indeed."

That leads to extinction.

[Daswani, 1996]
Kavita, interviewing Dr Avi Ben-Abraham, "one of 100 greatest minds in
history" according to MENSA and youngest person to ever become a
doctor of medicine and surgery (17 y/o), South China Morning Post,
January 4th, "Leading the way to a cure for AIDS," L/N

"Dr Ben-Abraham said: "Nature isn't benign. The " ... "of the human
race," he said."

Continued Warming causes coral reef destruction which triggers food
shortage, mass riots and kills three billion people.

Danfa Hopenstand, 2K2, Wisconsin Environmental Law Journal, Global
Warming and its Impact on Near-Shore Communities: Protection Regimes
for Fish and Coastal People Affected by Coral Reef Damage, Spring

"Global warming threatens the viability of coral reefs in two
significant ways." … "prevent further global warming and the loss of
marine biodiversity."

Loss of ocean biodiversity causes global extinction.

Robin Kundis Craig, 2K3, [Assoc Prof of Law @ Indiana U School of Law]
Taking Steps Toward Marine Wilderness Protection? Fishing and Coral
Reef Marine Reserves in Florida and Hawaii, 34 McGeorge L. Rev. 155,
Winter

"The world's oceans contain many resources and provide many services"
… "passed on relatively intact to future generations."

Observation Three: Peak Oil

According to British Petroleum reports global oil production rates
will peak in 2007 – this process is already occurring in many major
oil producing nations and will only get worse as discovery rates are
declining far faster than unconventional oil sources can be brought
online

Powerless New Zealand, Tuesday, October 5, 2K4 (PowerLess NZ is a
growing group of scientists, energy analysts and concerned citizens
whose principle objectives are to alert both Government and the
general public to New Zealand's looming energy crisis) Energy
Bulletin, The 2007 Peak Oil date explained,
http://www.energybulletin.net/2375.html?PHPENERGYBULL=348ddc27e6f1e065c3e7697df7e71e98

"As peak oil theory begins to break in Governments and the mainstream"
... "anytime we are potentially a week away from shortages."

Peak oil is inevitable in the short term – unless US consumption
decreases we'll have war and the biggest economic downturn ever.

Paul Roberts, March 8, 2K4, author of The End of Oil: On the Edge of a
Perilous New World, Los Angeles Times, Running Out of Oil... and Time,
p. L/N

"SEATTLE — The news last month that the vast Saudi oil fields are in
decline" ... "political conflict: the energy war."

The resulting economic collapse leads to escalatory nuclear conflicts
that will destroy civilization and the biosphere – this means
extinction.

T. E. Bearden, LTC, U.S. Army (Retired), June 24, 2000, CEO, CTEC
Inc., Director, Association of Distinguished American Scientists
(ADAS), Fellow Emeritus, Alpha Foundation's Institute for Advanced
Study (AIAS), The Unnecessary Energy Crisis: How to Solve It Quickly,
http://www.zpenergy.com/modules.php?name=Downloads&d_op=getit&lid=2

"History bears out that desperate nations take desperate actions" ...
" also a world destruction crisis."

Observation Four: Solvency

An upstream trading program would affect all levels of the economy
while encouraging innovation within both upstream and downstream
sectors – costing less than any other approach.

Nordhaus & Danish, Pew Center for Climate Change, 2K3 (Robert R. &
Kyle W. Designing a Mandatory Greenhouse Gas Reduction Program for the
U.S. May, http://www.pewclimate.org/docUploads/USGas%2Epdf)

"Upstream Cap-and-Trade. While a realistic downstream emissions" ...
"large-source downstream program."

Our trading system is best for innovation and it encourages firms to
achieve even greater reductions under the cap, this also ensures
successful monitoring.

Jennifer Yelin-Kefer, 2K1, J.D. Yale Law School, Warming up to an
International Greenhouse Gas Market: Lessons from the U.S. Acid Rain
Experience, 20 Stan. Envtl. L.J. 221, January

"Market mechanisms may have several other general benefits" ...
"rather than the means."

Already established monitoring systems and verifiable self-reporting
ensures accurate tracking of emissions.

Hoong N. Young, 1998, J.D./MBA Case Western Reserve University, AN
ANALYSIS OF A GLOBAL CO2 EMISSIONS TRADING PROGRAM, Florida State
University 14 J. Land Use & Envtl. Law 125, Fall

"Monitoring emissions by participants will be another challenge" ...
"sales reports of producers of fossil fuels. n229"

Our evidence is comparative – auctions are the only way to keep costs
low, maintain enforcement, prevent monopolies and ensure fair trading
while creating the incentive to reduce emissions below the regulatory
baseline.

Jennifer Yelin-Kefer, 2K1, J.D. Yale Law School, Warming up to an
International Greenhouse Gas Market: Lessons from the U.S. Acid Rain
Experience, 20 Stan. Envtl. L.J. 221, January

"Market-based mechanisms, unlike command-and" ... "them a competitive
advantage over non-participants. n291"

A strong US model for action on climate change would create the moral
legitimacy to push China and India to follow suit.

Paul Roberts, 2K4, [Energy and Economy expert for Harper's Magazine]
The End of Oil, p. 325-326

"Politically, a new U.S. energy policy would send a powerful message"
… "postindustrial economy on a hundred-year-old energy source?"'

Slowing the rate solves warming by increasing the threshold for our impacts.

Kendrick Taylor, 1999, [Research prof with the Water Resources Center
of the Desert Research Institute & Chief Scientist for the National
Science Foundation's WAISCORES program] "Rapid Climate Change,"
American Scientist, July-August, p.
http://waiscores.dri.edu/Amsci/taylorthree.html

"Although we do not know the critical level" … "higher level before
reaching the critical threshold."

Current energy economy is a tragedy of the commons – it prevents
market transition now.

Paul Roberts, 2K4, [Energy and Economy expert for Harper's Magazine]
The End of Oil, p. 264-265

"Because asst inertia operates most powerfully in those sectors" …
"Gordon told me, "but without over-committing to them."

We've read a trade add-on:

US competitive gains in relation to Europe after Kyoto comes into
force will cause the EU to sanction the US and create a political
climate of protectionism.

PETER J. FONTAINE, 2K4, Environmental Attorney, "The Gathering Storm,"
PUBLIC UTILITIES FORTNIGHTLY, August, p. L/N

"There is little question that CO[2] reduction measures will increase"
... "and the sanctions prompted the United States to act quickly to
remove the subsidies. n9"

Trade disputes would escalate quickly, collapsing the WTO and with it
global free trade.

Philippe Legrain, 2K3, special adviser to WTO Director General Mike
Moore, "The Coming Collapse of Free Trade," The New Republic, November
3, p. L/N

"Such a tit-for-tat battle could easily escalate." ... "as voices in
Congress periodically propose."

Continued global trade and mechanisms of the WTO are key to the
cooperation that prevents global nuclear war.

Copley News Service, December 1, 1999, p. L/N

"For decades, many children in America and other" ... "world peace
shouldn't be protesting world trade. They should be celebrating it."

BINGHAMTON GM:

Observation One: Inherency

Bush will bring voluntary emission intensity reductions in the status
quo as an alternative to Kyoto – unfortunately this actually
guarantees increased emissions, it does however non-unique much of
neg's offense.

Knox 2K4 (John H. [Associate Professor of Law, Pennsylvania State
University, Dickinson School of Law] 12 Penn St. Envtl. L. Rev. 135,
The International Legal Framework for Addressing Climate Change,
Winter 2004)

"In March 2001, when President Bush announced" ... "carbon emissions
or mandatory limits on them.""

Plan Text:

The United States federal government should establish an upstream,
auctioned cap and trade system that reduces total non-governmental
consumption of fossil fuels in the United States to 15% below 1990
levels by 2015.

Observation Two: Global Warming

The scientific debate is over – international scientific consensus,
ice core and tree ring data plus ice sheet melting rates all confirm
warming is real and anthropogenic.

Denee A. DiLuigi, 2K2, Special Assistant United States Attorney at the
U.S. Attorney's Office, Northern District of California, J.D. Golden
Gate University School of Law, KYOTO'S SO-CALLED "FATAL FLAWS": A
POTENTIAL SPRINGBOARD FOR DOMESTIC GREENHOUSE GAS REGULATION, 32
Golden Gate U.L. Rev. 693, Spring

"The overwhelming majority of the scientific community believes" ...
"the models indicated less than a tenth of a percent chance that
melting over the last 46 years was the result of normal variations."

The newest scientific research has determined that even slight carbon
increases trigger feedbacks which accelerate warming – we control
uniqueness because the three biggest are rapid and positive.

Fred Pearce, July 24, 2K4, Environmental Consultant for New Scientist,
"Harbingers of doom?" New Scientist, Features; Pg. 44

"Nor was Murphy alone with his tail. He showed a projection by David
Stainforth" ... "major positive feedback to global warming."

Continued warming will cause rapid disease mutation.

[Brunegraber, et al, 1999]
Laura, Mark Bittner, David Zimet, "A Study of the Effects of Global
Warming on the Spread of Vector-Borne Diseases"

"Most directly, warmer temperatures and" ... "dangerous problem indeed."

That leads to extinction.

[Daswani, 1996]
Kavita, interviewing Dr Avi Ben-Abraham, "one of 100 greatest minds in
history" according to MENSA and youngest person to ever become a
doctor of medicine and surgery (17 y/o), South China Morning Post,
January 4th, "Leading the way to a cure for AIDS," L/N

"Dr Ben-Abraham said: "Nature isn't benign. The " ... "of the human
race," he said."

Continued Warming causes coral reef destruction which triggers food
shortage, mass riots and kills three billion people.

Danfa Hopenstand, 2K2, Wisconsin Environmental Law Journal, Global
Warming and its Impact on Near-Shore Communities: Protection Regimes
for Fish and Coastal People Affected by Coral Reef Damage, Spring

"Global warming threatens the viability of coral reefs in two
significant ways." … "prevent further global warming and the loss of
marine biodiversity."

Loss of ocean biodiversity causes global extinction.

Robin Kundis Craig, 2K3, [Assoc Prof of Law @ Indiana U School of Law]
Taking Steps Toward Marine Wilderness Protection? Fishing and Coral
Reef Marine Reserves in Florida and Hawaii, 34 McGeorge L. Rev. 155,
Winter

"The world's oceans contain many resources and provide many services"
… "passed on relatively intact to future generations."

Observation Three: Peak Oil

According to British Petroleum reports global oil production rates
will peak in 2007 – this process is already occurring in many major
oil producing nations and will only get worse as discovery rates are
declining far faster than unconventional oil sources can be brought
online

Powerless New Zealand, Tuesday, October 5, 2K4 (PowerLess NZ is a
growing group of scientists, energy analysts and concerned citizens
whose principle objectives are to alert both Government and the
general public to New Zealand's looming energy crisis) Energy
Bulletin, The 2007 Peak Oil date explained,
http://www.energybulletin.net/2375.html?PHPENERGYBULL=348ddc27e6f1e065c3e7697df7e71e98

"As peak oil theory begins to break in Governments and the mainstream"
... "anytime we are potentially a week away from shortages."

Peak oil is inevitable in the short term – unless US consumption
decreases we'll have war and the biggest economic downturn ever.

Paul Roberts, March 8, 2K4, author of The End of Oil: On the Edge of a
Perilous New World, Los Angeles Times, Running Out of Oil... and Time,
p. L/N

"SEATTLE — The news last month that the vast Saudi oil fields are in
decline" ... "political conflict: the energy war."

The resulting economic collapse leads to escalatory nuclear conflicts
that will destroy civilization and the biosphere – this means
extinction.

T. E. Bearden, LTC, U.S. Army (Retired), June 24, 2000, CEO, CTEC
Inc., Director, Association of Distinguished American Scientists

Boston College -- ALL

 

Affirmative Disclosure for Boston College BC and Boston College SS

 

Plan

 

The United States Federal Government should establish by congressional legislation a cap and tradable auctioned permit program requiring, via reductions in fossil fuel consumption, non-governmental entities to reduce their greenhouse gas emissions to 2000 levels by 2010 as specified in the Climate Stewardship Act.

 

Observation One:  Inherency

 

Russian ratification of Kyoto makes entry into force imminent ­ this is a dramatic diplomatic defeat and creates the perception of inevitable US regulation

Chattanooga Times Free Press 10/4/2004 (“The U.S., Isolated Again”) p. lexis

The United States is out in the cold

CONTENTION ONE- INHERENCY
Bush is pursuing voluntary emissions caps in the status quo—guarantees increasing energy
consumption and CO2 emissions
Knox, 2004
(Winter, 12 Penn St. Envtl. L. Rev. 135, lexis)
“In March 2001, when President Bush… mandatory limits on them."

THUS THE PLAN:
THE UNITED STATES FEDERAL GOVERNMENT SHOULD ESTABLISH AN UPSTREAM, AUCTIONED, CAP AND TRADE SYSTEM
WITH A CAP THAT REDUCES DOMESTIC NON-GOVERNMENTAL CARBON EMISSIONS FROM FOSSIL FUELS TO BELOW 1990
LEVELS BY 2012.

CONTENTION TWO- WARMING

SUBPOINT A- ECOSYSTEM COLLAPSE
Warming is occurring quickly and is human induced—the most qualified scientific evidence proves
Gelbspan, long time science reporter and winner of the Pulitzer Prize, 2004
(Ross, Boiling Point, p. 23-32)
“That argument was first answered in”

Fossil fuel consumption is the major contributor to this massive biodiversity loss- impact is
extinction
McDaniel and Borton, bio scientists, 2002 (10/1, Bioscience, No. 10, Vol. 52, p. 929)
“When we use fossil fuels”

Slowing the rate of warming is critical—gives ecosystems time to adapt
Thomas professor of Biodiversity and Conservation at the School of Biology at U Leeds 2004
(Carl et. al. Nature, January 8, “Extinction Risk from Climate Change”)
“Despite these uncertainties”

SUBPOINT B AGRICULTURE
Warming will cause frequent extreme weather events generating massive climate instability
Godrej 2001 – Former editor of New Internationalist
The No-Nonsense Guide to Global Climate Change, p. (23-24)
“All change”

Climate oscillations will destroy agriculture and the world economy—kills billions
Milbrath, Director of the Research Program in Environment and Society at the State University of
New York-Buffalo, 1994 (THE FUTURIST, May, p. 28.)
“Another scenario suggests”

(“The Coming End of Cheap Oil” The Social Contract, Summer
http://www.thesocialcontract.com/cgi-bin/showarticle.pl?articleID=1094&terms=)

Without immediate efforts to reduce consumption the oil peak will destroy the global economy
Roberts, Harper's Magazine, Finalist for the National Magazine Award, 2004
(Paul, The End of Oil: A Perilous New World, p. 12-14)
“Yet despite the staying power”

This causes multiple nuclear wars
Lewis 98 (Chris, Coming Age of Scarcity, Amercian Studies at UC Boulder)
“Most critics would argue”

As supplies run out the U.S. will initiate a massive military campaign to secure oil supplies,
collapsing hegemony
Richard Heinberg, New College of California, program of Culture, Ecology, and Sustainable
Community, 2003 (The Party’s Over, p. 197-8)

Causes extinction

(http://www.energybulletin.net/2291.html)

CONTENTION SIX- SOLVENCY

of the US economy and costs less than any other approach
Nordhaus and Danish, 2003
(“Designing a Mandatory Greenhouse Gas Reduction Program for the U.S.”, March,
http://www.pewclimate.org/docUploads/USGas%2Epdf)
“Upstream Cap-and-Trade…. downstream program”

Reducing emissions levels to 1990 levels by 2012 would pave the way for aggressive reductions in
CO2
Krupp, , 2003 (1/8, FDCH)
“Targets and Timetables…. for addressing climate change”

Emissions trading gives businesses the incentive to invest in new technologies that curb
emissions- a domestic scheme would help jumpstart the movement to a stop climate change globally
Browne, 2004
(John, Foreign Affairs, July/August, lexis)
“The role of business… yield impressive results”

Emissions trading enhances environmental goals
Ellerman, Joskow, and Harrison, 2003
(“Emissions Trading in the U.S.”, May, www.pewclimate.org)
“The use of emissions trading… remaining environmental problems”

US leadership is critical—causes other countries to change their CO2 emissions
Roberts, Harper's Magazine, Finalist for the National Magazine Award, 2004
(Paul, The End of Oil: A Perilous New World, p. 14-5)
“By necessity, much of”

Cal-Berkeley RS

 

AFFIRMATIVE #1 : PRODUCTIONIST METAPHYSICS

 

Contention One: Descarte’s Bag of Tricks

 

Kaiser Sosé claimed that the greatest trick the devil ever pulled was making the world believe he did not exist.  Our modern era has increasingly been characterized by captivity to a civilizational system that compels us to go on destroying the world in order to live. There are many among us who would be glad to release the world from its captivity. But they are prevented from doing this because they can not see the bars of the cage.

 

The discipline of modern metaphysics was inaugurated by Rene Descarte’s meditations by a fireplace. He thought to himself: how do I know that my senses correspond to an external reality? How do I know that my senses are not being manipulated by an evil genius?

 

Descartes thought he had found a solution: even if I doubt everything else, I am sure that my thought is there. I think, therefore I am. This description of consciousness depends on the depiction of a subject as a psychosomatic apparatus bringing objects into certainty through the workings of its mental apparatus. It is this objectifying method that reduces the world into calculable quantities that comprise a large machine.

 

hanspeter Padrutt, member of daseinanalytisches institut, heidegger and the earth, ed. ladelle mcwhorter, 1992, pg 19-21

 

 

This understanding of subjectivity is neither natural nor inevitable. But we are subtly conditioned to buy the Cartesian line. Think back to Sesame Street: we see Elmo and Big Bird – we see thought bubbles above their heads – and we see scenes playing out in the thought bubbles. This is a depiction of mental content as representations about the external world in the mind of a subject. What is the reason we have been conditioned to understand ourselves in this way?

 

Humanity has found itself mired in an understanding of being that is synonymous with production, a move that has resulted in the yoking of the very forces of nature in the service of technological expansion. Let us be clear: technology is not a set of devices – rather, it is a particular set of ontological conditions that makes possible the worldview of industrial production.

 

michael e. Zimmerman, professor of philosophy at tulane university, heidegger’s confrontation with modernity, 1990, pg. xii-xiv

 

 

How does technology relate to our self-understanding? Technological humanity is compelled to turn nature into a stockpile of raw materials whose only value lies in their usefulness for our purposes. Central to this project is the appropriation of natural entities for the purpose of energy consumption. The continual consumption of fossil fuels represents the triumph over nature as a potent object. The world is revealed as standing reserve and humans as nothing more than the orderer of the standing reserve.

Tad Beckman, Professor Emeritus of Philosophy at Harvey Mudd College, “Martin Heidegger and Environmental Ethics,” 2000, [Online: http://www2.hmc.edu/~tbeckman/personal/Heidart.html]

 

At the very pinnacle of this technological culture, however, a fundamental reversal of the traditional subject/object dichotomy sets in. Machine technology now rebels against us. We become slaves to a technological mode of being that uproots us from the earth in an infinite quest of magnification of power. Social heirarchies and disciplines are produced in order to master humanity and make us amenable to the demand of technology’s call to master the earth.

 

michael e. Zimmerman, professor of philosophy at tulane university, heidegger’s confrontation with modernity, 1990, pg. 199-202

 

The violence of the Holocaust and hydrogen bombs were made possible because of humanity’s conception of everything as resources to be produced or destroyed at will. It is the logic of industrial technology’s mode of being that made possible the most horrific violence of the twentieth century.

 

michael e. Zimmerman, professor of philosophy at tulane university, heidegger’s confrontation with modernity, 1990, pg. 43

 

 

Ultimately, our one-dimensional disclosure of entities denies them any being at all. Nature is reduced to energy and we lose the capacity to be-in-the-world. We can only exist instrumentally in the service of technology’s final victory over nature. This eclipse of being has fated us to exist in a state of ontological damnation, the eradication of any possibility of a clearing through which life can manifest itself.

 

Michael Zimmerman, professor of philosophy at Tulane University, Contesting the Earth’s Future: Radical Ecology and Postmodernity, 1997, p. 119-20

 

 

Resolved: The United States federal government should establish an energy policy requiring a substantial reduction in the total non-governmental consumption of fossil fuels.

 

 

Contention Two: The Open Expanse of the World

 

Language is the house of being. It discloses things about the way our being has been constituted. The resolution allows us to see the bars of the civilizational system that is keeping us captive to technology’s imperative to continually consume fossil fuels. The call to “let these entities be” represents a step back from the constant purposiveness demanded by modern technology. The statement reveals that technology is merely a purposeless historical world that is driven by the infinite self-expansion of production. This disclosure of groundlessness makes possible the openness necessary for the arrival of a new era.

 

michael e. Zimmerman, professor of philosophy at tulane university, heidegger’s confrontation with modernity, 1990, pg. 234-6

 

 

What effect does this opposition to absoloutist resource extraction have on our own self-understanding? The resolution is couched in the form of a grammatical imperative to an agent, the federal government. This statement calls on that agent to let-being-be, to stop being as it is, a call that threatens the typical configurations of subjectivity in the modern age.

 

ladelle Mcwhorter, assistant prof of phil at northeast missouri state university, heidegger and the earth, ed. ladelle mcwhorter, 1992, pg 4-7

 

 

The effect of this paradox is to inaugurate a shift away from the objectifying subject to the open expanse of everyday being in connection with what encounters it, what it cares about. Our project is not a search for a true or authentic identity – rather, it is a call to shift from the forced derivative disclosure of a calculating subject to the open interconnected mystery of the world itself.

 

hanspeter Padrutt, member of daseinanalytisches institut, heidegger and the earth, ed. ladelle mcwhorter, 1992, pg 19-21

 

 

Let us be specific about the changes that are being called for in our relationship with the world - our encounter with care enables us to dwell on the earth without engaging in the violence of forced disclosure of materials as standing reserve. The plan does not represent detachment or drawing back, rather it enacts our belonging to earth in a manner of heedful attentiveness.

 

gail Stenstad, professor at east tennessee state university, heidegger and the earth, ed. ladelle mcwhorter, 1992, pg. 71-2

 

 

To shrink back from the earth, to alienate ourselves from the capacity to care – this path is conducive to a violent way of being on the Earth. This refusal of belonging tends toward contraction into nothing. If we are to flee from our connectedness, we will necessarily bring death to everything earthly and alive.

 

gail stenstad, professor at east tennessee state university, heidegger and the earth, ed. ladelle mcwhorter, 1992, pg 72-3

 

 

What effect does this talk of subjectivity have on our ability to act ethically? The shift to an understanding of the openness of being means that being is a radically interdependent condition, made possible only because of my responsibility to the Other. Thus, one has a responsibility for the Other that is incalculable and without limits. One’s being must be affirmed in terms of a right to be in relation to the Other.

 

David Campbell, International Politics, Newcastle, and Michael Dillon, International Relations, Lancaster, The Political Subject of Violence, 1993, p. 169-171

 

 

AFFIRMATIVE #2: TRAUMA AND MEMORY

 

Section One: Blood and Oil

 

In 2003, America launched a preemptive invasion of Iraq. The public was sold a string of stories about the invasion: a connection between Iraq and 9/11, stockpiles of weapons of mass destruction, and the promotion of democracy. But the decision to invade Iraq was made because of Saudi Arabia.

 

George Friedman, founder and chairman of Stratfor, one of the world’s most respected private global intelligence firms, America’s Secret War: Inside the Hidden Worldwide Struggle Between America and its Enemies, November 2004, p. 233-6

 

 

An invasion of Iraq would enable America to bring enormous amounts of Iraqi oil on to the global market. This would be a terrific economic threat to Saudi Arabia – one that would give the US leverage over Saudi policy decisions.

 

George Friedman, founder and chairman of Stratfor, one of the world’s most respected private global intelligence firms, America’s Secret War: Inside the Hidden Worldwide Struggle Between America and its Enemies, November 2004, p. 247-9

 

 

The string of inconsistent reasons that served as the justification of the war on Iraq was the imposition of ideology at the level of images.

 

slavoj zizek, senior researcher at the institute for social studies in ljubljana, iraq: the borrowed kettle, 2004, pp.

 

 

 

 

 

 

Section Two: Narrations of the State

 

The violence of sovereign power that was responsible for the invasion is produced through rewriting trauma into a linear narrative of national heroism. This is the legitimation of sovereignty through the “politics” that characterizes the processes of institutions.

 

jenny edkins, senior lecturer in international politics at the university of wales aberystwyth, trauma and the memory of politics, 2003, pp.

 

 

This reified notion of politics produces the modern autonomous subject through the construction of social relations that express power. The linear narrative of the conflict brings our social reality into being.

 

jenny edkins, senior lecturer in international politics at the university of wales aberystwyth, trauma and the memory of politics, 2003, pp.

 

 

The Iraq narrative reduces life to bare life by constructing Iraq as a sacrificial zone of exclusion. This enables the structure of bare life to be applied to every living being.

 

jenny edkins, senior lecturer in international politics at the university of wales aberystwyth, trauma and the memory of politics, 2003, pp.

 

 

Sovereign power is now characterized by its ability to indefinitely maintain a state of exception where decisions about life and death are arbitrary and everything is possible. This is the point of no return for biopolitical governance.

 

jenny edkins, senior lecturer in international politics at the university of wales aberystwyth, trauma and the memory of politics, 2003, pp.

 

 

Section Three: Superpower Syndrome

 

Our memory of the Iraq conflict is organized by the traditional mode of politics to legitimize a particular liberal consensus: those who disagree play the role of villains in a new cosmic struggle.

 

jenny edkins, senior lecturer in international politics at the university of wales aberystwyth, trauma and the memory of politics, 2003, pp.

 

 

The appropriation of trauma in Iraq has been used to unleash untold levels of violence in an effort to sacrificially cleanse the world. This response can only result in a malignant synergy where the apocalyptic energies of American war planners and jihadist groups are mutually reinforced.

 

Robert Jay Lifton, visiting professor of psychiatry at Harvard Medical School, Superpower Syndrome: America’s Apocalyptic Confrontation with the World, 2003, p. 1-4

 

 

This reenergization of apocalyptic impulses promises to end in the destruction of the world.

 

Robert Jay Lifton, visiting professor of psychiatry at Harvard Medical School, Superpower Syndrome: America’s Apocalyptic Confrontation with the World, 2003, p. 17-8

 

 

THUS, THE UNITED STATES FEDERAL GOVERNMENT SHOULD ESTABLISH AN ENERGY POLICY REQUIRING A SUBSTANTIAL REDUCTION IN THE TOTAL NON-GOVERNMENTAL CONSUMPTION OF FOSSIL FUELS IN THE UNITED STATES THROUGH A BAN ON NON-GOVERNMENTAL CONSUMPTION OF IMPORTED OIL.

 

 

Section Four: The Struggle of Memory Against Forgetting

 

The plan is an oppositional statement to the state narrative of the invasion. The call to ban the consumption of imported oil serves as the focal point for a re-telling of the invasion. It is an antagonistic dialogue with the state narration centered around making explicit the American strategy of Grab the Oil.

 

Freeman, writer in economics and education, “Will the End of Oil Mean the End of America?” Common Dreams, March 1, 2004, http://www.commondreams.org/views04/0301-12.htm

 

 

The plan exposes the gap between the state narration of the invasion and the actual justification of oil. The distinction itself becomes a part of the public discourse.

 

slavoj zizek, senior researcher at the institute for social studies in ljubljana, iraq: the borrowed kettle, 2004, pp.

 

 

The plan encircles the trauma of the Iraq war, marking it in its very impossibility. This keeps open a space for genuine political challenge by destabilizing the production of linearity around which traditional politics coheres.

 

jenny edkins, senior lecturer in international politics at the university of wales aberystwyth, trauma and the memory of politics, 2003, pp.

 

 

The plan initiates this struggle for memory to counteract the debilitating effect of a neatly scripted heroic narrative for the United States in the War on Terror. We must recall the violence of the present conflict in all of its ambiguity and difficulty, as something that we are ourselves are implicated in. Remembering what happened, in all its traumatic reality, is the only way to escape the cycle of violence that our present reliance on neat and heroic stories traps us in.

 

jenny edkins, senior lecturer in international politics at the university of wales aberystwyth, trauma and the memory of politics, 2003, pp. 172-4

 

 

Hope is always bound up with the reach of the imagination We have the capacity to probe painful truths in connection with all apocalyptic violence and to make contact with the human suffering involved. We need to bear witness, compassionately, to the destructive events of our era if we are to embark on a more humane course.

 

Robert Jay Lifton, visiting professor of psychiatry at Harvard Medical School, Superpower Syndrome: America’s Apocalyptic Confrontation with the World, 2003, p. 192-4

Case Western Dorsey & Dennisen

 

 

 

Case outline:

 

 

First NASA has abandoned Space Solar Power, a technology that could

easily provide gigawatts of electricity

 

 

John Gartner, Wired News, NASA Spaces on Energy Solution,  Jun. 22, 2004

 

 

Secondly We are ready to build a Space Solar Power system now, the

biggest hurdle, transportation costs, will be overcome as soon as plan

is implemented

 

 

Space Solar Power Workshop, 2004 [Part II The Keys to Space Solar Power,

The Space Solar Power Workshop is jointly run by Auburn Space Power

Institute and Georgia Tech University, cards are from an introduction on

the website www.sspi.gatech.edu]

 

 

 

 

Adv. 1 - Space Exploration

 

 

 

First Note that the technology accompanying Space Solar Power key to

Space Exploration in general

 

 

John Gartner, Wired News, NASA Spaces on Energy Solution,  Jun. 22, 2004

 

 

Second Space Solar Power will quickly become lucrative for private

business, and encourage the private sector to explore space, SSP will

promote and expand space exploration for private industry and government

Leonard David, Senior Space Writer for Space.com, October 17, 2001

 

 

 

Third, The Private Sector is key to the future exploration of space, and

Bush is failing to capitalize on this possibility

Berger, January 10, 2004 [Space News Staff Writer Bush Space Vision

Needs Pricate, Public Sector Cooperation, Advocates say]

 

 

 

Fourth Space Solar Power is absolutely key to space exploration

including missions to mars

Mankins, John C. 1997 A Fresh Look at Space Solar Power: New

Architectures, Concepts and Technologies, IAF Advanced Projects Office,

NASA

 

 

 

 

Fifth, Exploring other planets is key to human species survival

 

 

Carl Sagan 1994 (American astronomer, planetologist, biologist) "A Pale

Blue Dot"

 

 

 

Adv. 2 Global Poverty

 

 

First, Centralized power distribution networks reinscribe the rich poor

gap, they sidetrack populations who have the most need dooming billions

to constant poverty

 

 

ITDG June, 2004 [Intermediate Development Technologies Group; Powering

Poverty Reduction, Position paper for Renewables 2004]

 

 

 

 

Second, even Status Quo interest in renewables cannot solve for the rich

poor gap or the racist policies - they short circuits help to the poor

 

 

ITDG June, 2004 [Intermediate Development Technologies Group; Powering

Poverty Reduction, Position paper for Renewables 2004]

 

 

Third 1.6 Million people die every year from poorly ventilated energy

consumption, safe, decentralized electricity production is key to

solving

 

 

ITDG June, 2004 [Intermediate Development Technologies Group; Powering

Poverty Reduction, Position paper for Renewables 2004]

 

 

 

Fourth Renewable Energy is key to saving the lives of millions of

children, the world's greatest killer of children thrives on the smoke

of home cooking fires

 

 

ITDG June, 2004 [Intermediate Development Technologies Group; Powering

Poverty Reduction, Position paper for Renewables 2004]

 

However, Space Solar Power can be the lynchpin in providing power to

places that do not have access to power plants - with nothing but a

non-polluting receiver, village life-support systems can provide

drinkable water, lights and communication

Leonard David, Senior Space Writer for Space.com, October 17, 2001

 

 

Additionally Space Solar Power is key to helping people who can't afford

energy distribution infrastructure

 

 

John Gartner, Wired News, NASA Spaces on Energy Solution,  Jun. 22, 2004

 

 

Adv. 3 Environment

 

 

First, CO2 emissions will cause rapid warming in the Status Quo, and no

action is being taken to solve the problem

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Warming triggers oceanic shifts responsible for oscillations

 

 

Oscillations will kill billions

Millbrath

 

 

 

Plan text:  The united states federal government should establish an

energy policy requiring a substantial reduction in total

non-governmental consumption of fossil fuels by requiring status quo

fossil fuel power plants to be replaced by space solar power throughout

the united states. 

 

 

 

 

 

Observation 4 is Solvency

 

 

 

Space Solar Power is virtually limitless, there is enough power to drive

a power grid hundreds of millions of times the size of the US grid, and

no new science is required

 

 

Smith, Arthur, Aug 11, 2003, [The Case For Space Based Solar Power

Development, Space Daily, pres. Long Island Space Society]

 

 

 

Second, In less than 2 years satellites could be transmitting energy

wirelessly from space, however NASA funding is critical to Space Solar

Power, which it is the best option for renewable energy

John Gartner, Wired News, NASA Spaces on Energy Solution,  Jun. 22, 2004

 

 

Third Space Solar Power is an essential part of the US energy policy,

for costs similar to that of current fusion research, it is possible to

have several Gigawatts of power as well as a profit

 

 

Smith, Arthur, Aug 11, 2003, [The Case For Space Based Solar Power

 

 

Fourth SSP complements and improves terrestrial Solar Power, plan makes

decentralized solar power more efficient, affordable and effective

 

 

Landis, 2004 [Geoffrey Landis, Reinventing the Solar Power Satellite,

Nasa Glenn Research Center February]

 

Next the positives outweigh the negatives of Space Solar Power, it is

unending and produces zero emissions

Steve Price, NASA News, Solar power collected in space and beamed to

Earth could be an environmentally friendly solution to our planet's

growing energy problems.  March 23, 2001

 

 

 

Finally, This is not Sim City, There is no risk of Microwave Beamed

power hurting ANYONE

 

 

Dye 2001 [Lee Dye, Science Correspondent, ABCNews.com, May 16]

Status quo solutions fail- no plan to address future energy needs

these structures dooms us all
Heinberg 2003, “the party’s over” p 200-1

A. the peak
70’s oil crisis was only a precognition- a permanent version will soon arrive
Goodstien “out of gas” 2004 p 17

Peak is coming- half the oil is already gone
Goodstein 26-28

The peak can’t be delayed- even another field the size of Saudi Arabia is only a
two year delay
Goodstein 35-6

The peak hits in 2008
Wesolowsky 1/14/2005 www.truthnews.net/world/2005010079.htm

Transition must come before the peak to lead to orderly transition
Goodstein 30-1

Change now is key to have lubricants in the future
Howe 67-8

B. tar sands

US tarsand and shale oil will be developed
DOE 2004

Processing tarsands destroys the environment (laundry list)

Canada has the worlds largest tar sand reserves by many times, they will be
developed
Douthwaite again

Both china and the US want the tar sands oil, china will not focus on Asian
sources of oil but on those in canada
Brush 1/26/2005 moneycentral.msn.com/content/p105037.asp

Bush rhetoric otherizes and sets stage for conflict with china
Walkom 1/22/2005 Toronto Star

US and China will compete for Canadaian oil, the US can de-escalate this however

conflict may go nuclear

Plan- 5% annual reduction of non-goct fossil fule use with a ban on the use of
oil from tar sand using the 2005 fossil fuel use total as a maximum.

Plan leads to soft landing
Howe 63-69

Using tar sands in oil projections means bad projections
Howe

Views of china as enemy construct the US-China relationship as one of hostility,
US acts to open communication and interaction can transcend these patterns
Troush 1999 CNAPS working paper

The utopian fantasies of the status quo will always collapse, it is better for
the self to take action to collapse them then wait for the inevitable
Stavrakakis 1999 “lacan and the political” 116-7

Must leave fantasy to have accurate impact analysis

Our language here about the transition is uniquely productive
Howe 94-97

Current policy on OCS windmills based in flawed ethic of the sacred

n121-n134

Pelton, baltimore sun, 1/2/2005 lexis

privilage
Wickersham again

an alternative ethical framework is better- the aff adopts the ethic of a garden
beyond that of the dichotomy of human-nature
Pollan "the idea of a garden" 1995, Timmy didn't write down a page number, but
the card starts...ends "everybody enjoys a good local fight...but on the idea of
a garden"

roots of crisis, leads to anti-humanism/bad ecocentrism

didn't make with the page, "the wilderness vision...ecological in a free society"

plan- USFG read resolution- by having congress amend the outer concontinental
shelf land act to require that 10% of all electricity currently generated and
all future electricity generated in the united states be provided by
environmentally sited offshore wind farms on the outer continental shelf.

larger ethics of hope
