Culture Jamming

Affirmative begins with video presentation of G.W. Bush in his speech @ O’Hare
9/27/2001, video presentation starts 10:51 into speech and ends after 1:23 of
playing time, final phrase “enjoy life, the way we want it to be enjoyed”

Do you want to be a good american?  Can you imagine doing anything less?  This
speech is illustrative of a larger rhetorical frame that the government operates
within, aligning with corporate fossil fuel interests to create a network of
language and images that create our world and our culture, the spectacle of
consumption.  The corporations use the government and their texts to transform
public discourse to that of fossil fuel consumption while masking discursive
practices, condifying the need to consume in the discursive space.
Sharon Livesey 2002 Journal of Business Communication 39:1 “Exxon Mobil
presented its March/April…contributing to the cause of the natural environment
by producing energy-efficient fuels.”

This closure of discourse ignores the needs of the environment through oil
corporations privileging destructive forms of economy, knowledge, and
rationality that justify unlimited growth and manipulation
Livesey 2002 “In summary…produces rational choice and the greatest social good”

Additonally, government and corporate power utilize media effectively creating
misinformaton to transform public understanding to support consumption
Kalle Lasn “Culture Jam” p 24-5 “If we now absorb…infotoxin of them all: cynicism”

Aside from resulting in consumptive mindsets and actiosn this rhetorical
condition has a more insidious effect through foreclosure of criticism, shutting
down any chance for debate and democratic contestation of consumption through
its administration of what can and cannot be spoken about
Judith Butler “Precarious Life” p xx-xxi “to decide what…about the effects of war”

Advocacy statement

USFG should reverse its discourse about consumption

Changes in rhetoric needed because only a change in rhetoric will actually
change mindset of consumption

Then play video of Bush at 7:15 into speech saying: “I like my cheese burger medium”

Our culture jamming of corporate domination of public discourse is an individual
act that can break the flow of our culture and smash open perspectives of
consumption to reveal the world that must be transformed creating the potential
of a new way of being in the world as consumers, an upheval in our current
destructive society
Lasn 1999 p. 105-6  “when I was shooting…brings everything into focus”

And analysing corporate-governmental rhetoric acknowledges the mediated reality
that accouts for the personal ways in which people experience the world creating
the most effective type of criticism of current society
Raymie McKerrow Communication Monographs 56 1989 “public address as
traditionally…of sterile forms of criticism”

Finally, redefining the truth of established power towards one of advocacy of
non consumption challenges currently accepted truths and creates new social
relations of consumption while allowing continued criticism and debate based on
the former rhetorical structures
McKerrow 1989 “nevertheless a consideration…the critique continues”

Dartmouth -- ALL

Dartmouth Affs

BeMa has only run OCVs
BrMa usually runs Mass Transit, but has run OCVs
CS has run all 4, usually OCVs

---- OCVs AFF

A.  OIL PRODUCTION WILL PEAK

US OIL DEMAND IS SKYROCKETING
NYT 10-5-04 "Americans have completely"
OIL PRODUCTION WILL PEAK BY 2010
New York Press 6/2/4 www.nypress.com/17/22/news&columns/AaronNaparstek.cfm?page=1&last=4 "that the level of demand predicted by the"
DISCOVERIES DECREASING AND RESERVES OVERSTATED
Financial Times 9/22/4 "They point out that no big oilfield"
EVEN NEW BIG FIELDS WON'T MAKE A DIFFERENCE
David Goodstein'04 Out of Gas 35-6
UNCONVENTIONALS ARE NET ENERGY LOSERS
Goodstein, 31-2
NEW EXTRACTING TECH USES MORE ENERGY TO PRODUCE OIL, DECREASING NET ENERGY
Richard Heinberg 03 The Party's Over p109-110
PEAK PRODUCTION CREATES A RACE FOR REMAINING RESERVES
Paul Roberts, 04 The End of Oil p 45-6
WAITING UNTIL THE PEAK WILL BE DISASTEROUS - UNCERTAINTY FAVORS ACTION
Roberts 64-5

B.  GLOBAL WAR

WITHOUT IMMEDIATE REDUCTIONS IN OIL CONSUMPTION, THE TRANSITION WILL ENTAIL CHAOS AND CONFLICT
Roberts p.331
A CHAOTIC TRANSITION RESULTS IN GLOBAL ECONOMIC COLLAPSE AND WAR
Roberts 12-13
THERE WILL BE NUCLEAR RESOURCE WARS FOR DEPLETING OIL
Andrew McKillop 03 solutions.synearth.net/2003/12/02
OIL REVENUE EXACERBATES CORRUPTION, REPRESSION AND CONFLICT
Amory Lovins, Winning the Oil Endgame, 2004, p.18-19

C.  AG

AS OIL RUNS OUT, INCREASED FUEL COSTS DEVASTATE AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION, RESULTING IN THE DEATHS OF 2 OUT OF 3 PEOPLE
Heinberg, 177

D.  ECONOMY

LOWER PRICES WERE TEMPORARY - PRICES ARE SHOOTING PAST OCTOBER'S HIGH
Daily Telegraph, 1/10/5 "Another rise in oil prices... further pressure on crude"
OIL IS HEADING FOR 100 DOLLARS A BARREL - THERE'S NO SLACK IN THE MARKET
Forbes 10/19/04 www.forbes.com/business/energy/2004/10/19/cx_da_1019topnews.html
HIGH OIL PRICES DEVASTATE CONSUMER SPENDING AND THE US ECONOMY
Washington Post 1/8/5 "strong consumer spending can no longer be relied upon"
THIS COLLAPSES THE GLOBAL ECONOMY
Fred Bergsten 9-9-04 www.iie.com/publications/papers/bergsten0904.htm
ECONOMIC DECLINE CAUSES WORLDWIDE WAR
Business World 9/10/98 "What would it be like if global recession"
OIL SHORTAGE ENDS THE GLOBAL ECONOMY FOREVER
Heinberg 203
THE PLAN:  THE UNITED STATES FEDERAL GOVERNMENT SHOULD ESTABLISH A SYSTEM OF OIL CONSERVATION VOUCHERS FOR GROUND TRANSPORTATION VEHICLES, PHASED IN TO ACHIEVE AT 25% REDUCTION IN NON-GOVERNMENTAL CONSUMPTION WITHIN 16 YEARS.  THIS REDUCTION WILL BEGIN IMMEDIATELY AND MUST BE AT LEAST 1% PER ANNUM.  THE UNITED STATES FEDERAL GOVERNMENT SHOULD REQUIRE VOUCHERS FOR PURCHASES ON AN OIL CONTENT PER GALLON BASIS AND PERMIT THE TRADE OF THESE VOUCHERS.  AN ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEDURE WILL BE ESTABLISHED TO DIVERT ADDITIONAL VOUCHERS IN CASES OF DEMONSTRATED SPECIAL NEEDS; THIS DIVERSION WILL COME FROM THE SET TOTAL NUMBER OF VOUCHERS.  THE UNITED STATES FEDERAL GOVERNMENT SHOULD MAKE IT THE DUTY OF THE STATES TO DEVISE IMPLEMENTATION AND ENFORCEMENT SYSTEMS, WHICH WILL GO INTO EFFECT WITH FEDERAL APPROVAL AND OVERSIGHT.  IN THE ABSENCE OF A STATE PLAN, THE FEDERAL GOVERNMENT WILL ASSUME ADMINISTRATIVE RESPONSIBILITIES IN THAT STATE.  FEDERAL OVERSIGHT, ENFORCEMENT AND FUNDING WILL BE PROVIDED.  WE WILL CLARIFY.

E.  SOLVENCY

OCVs LIMIT OIL CONSUMPTION WITHOUT HURTING THE ECONOMY
Martin Feldstein '01 National Interest, Special Issue p 60 EBSCO
OCVs DECREASE OIL CONSUMPTION, REDUCING ECONOMIC AND MILITARY DIFFICULTIES
Martin Feldstein '03 www.nber.org/feldstein/oildependenceaea2003.pdf
CONSUMPTION IS KEY TO SMOOTH THE TRANSITION AWAY FROM OIL
Roberts p14
NEW CAR TECHNOLOGY IS COMING - OCVs KEY TO GETTING PEOPLE TO USE IT
Feldstein 01 (above)
US KEY TO WORLDWIDE ENERGY MARKETS
Roberts p288
BEST STUDIES FIND NO ADVERSE ECONOMIC EFECTS FROM ENVIRONMENTAL REGULATIONS
Meyer 95 web.mit.edu/polisci.mpepp/Roberts/eier.pdf "When we turn away form anecdotes and special interest"
RACE TO THE BOTTOM BY STATES MEANS FEDERAL ACTION IS NECESSARY
Saleska 98 Cornell Journal of Law and Public Policy "Try as they might, legal theorists cannot will away"
STATES WON'T ENFORCE WITHOUT FEDERAL BACKUP
Kuehn 6/96 Tulane Environmental Law Clinic "One state environmental commissioner observed"

--- Mass Transit AFF

CONTENTION ONE: THE STATUS QUO

Current transportation policy massively funds highways for private car use over mass transit. This causes segregation and immense economic disparities between cities and suburbs.

bullard johnson and torres '04 p. 179-81 "transportation decision-making - whether at" Highway Robbery

CONTENTION TWO: VULNERABILITY

Government policy to secure cheap gas for private autos reflects an attempt to deny vulnerability. The right to private car use currently depends on the threat of violence and manipulation of other people's vulnerability to ensure unfettered access to cheap gas.

Rev. Bryan MASSINGALE, Institute for Peace and Justice, 2/8/03

http://www.ipj-ppj.org/massingale%20-%20connection%20between%20materialism%20&%20militarism.htm

"Thus our core American value, the freedom"

Suburban segregation and distancing from privileged private car use organizes the American community around fear of vulnerability. The need for pure spaces is intimately connected a desire to eliminate anxiety in favor of total control.

Jerry FRUG, Samuel R. Rosenthal Professor of Law @ Harvard, 1996
(Stanford Law Review, "Surveying Law and Borders," May)

"Richard Sennett's important book, The Uses of Disorder... although this common identity is"

Fear of vulnerability requires gender securitization to ensure white women remain safe from the chaotic inner city. This disciplines and essentializes "women" according to the cult of domesticity, and forces "men" to become protective guardians.

Jerry FRUG, Samuel R. Rosenthal Professor of Law @ Harvard, 1996
(Stanford Law Review, "Surveying Law and Borders," May)

Trying to eliminate anxiety through denial of vulnerability makes life worse than death.

Carse 80 Death and Existence

"A personal relationship does not exist until we respond to others" p. 4-6

Trying to hide our own vulnerability through a private-car bound way of life ensures perpetual and increasingly destructive war.

Val PLUMWOOD, Environmental Philosopher & Australian Research Council Fellow @ Australian National University, 12/2/03 "Fossil Fuel Fundamentalism and Interspecies Ethics" http://www.savetheridge.org.au/govtplans/BPST-Program-Dec2003.doc .

"fossil fuel fundamentalism and the primacy of the automobile"

Extinction
Gregory Stephens 02 "The American people's belief in cheap oil as a birthright is what drives the Bush administration's"

CONTENTION THREE: BLOOD SACRIFICE

Privileging private car use causes racial distancing and enables the narrative of the inner city as chaotic and threatening to the health of the population. The consequent demonizing of the less productive justifies discriminatory resource allocation and a segregation of moral responsibility that lets dangerous races die so the rest of the population can survive.

Kevin D. KUSWA, PhD Communication Studies, Director of debate and Instructor of Rhetoric @ Richmond, '02

(Journal of Law in Society, "Suburbification, Segregation, and the Consolidation of the Highway Machine" Winter)

"Significant to enabling this coalition was the postwar subsidization...and the urban environment"

This demonization of the inner city is key to the securitization of space in American politics. Current transportation policy is a necessary part of the biopolitical racing and placing of people to ensure the health of the body politic.

Kevin D. KUSWA, PhD Communication Studies, Director of debate and Instructor of Rhetoric @ Richmond, '02
(Journal of Law in Society, "Suburbification, Segregation, and the Consolidation of the Highway Machine" Winter)

"The connections between highways and suburbia...suburbia, and the urban environment"

This form of state racism makes war and genocide a permanent condition of society by justifying the destruction of dangerous others for the health of the population.

Eduardo MENDIETA, Assistant Professor, University of San Francisco Philosophy, 4/25/02
(http://www.sunysb.edu/philosophy/new/research/mendieta_3.pdf )

"I have thus far discussed...foes are biological in nature."

HENCE THE PLAN:
THE UNITED STATES FEDERAL GOVERNMENT SHOULD ESTABLISH AN ENERGY POLICY REQUIRING A SUBSTANTIAL REDUCTION IN NON-GOVERNMENTAL CONSUMPTION OF OIL USED IN GROUND TRANSPORTATION VEHICLES IN THE UNITED STATES WITHIN 15 YEARS. THIS REDUCTION WILL BEGIN IMMEDIATELY AT A RATE OF AT LEAST 1% PER ANNUM. THE UNITED STATES FEDERAL GOVERNMENT MUST REACH THIS TARGET THROUGH ADJUSTMENTS IN THE FEDERAL TAX ON GASOLINE AND PARALLEL INCREASES IN DIRECT FUNDING OF PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION IN THE UNITED STATES.

CONTENTION FOUR: SOLVENCY

Mass transit provides an alternative to the car culture. Mass transit transforms our securitized and racialized spaces into heterogenous communities.

Gerald E. FRUG, Professor of Law @ Harvard, Apr 1998
(NYU Law Review, "City Services")

"Highway maintenance also raises broader issues... that reaction is"

These heterogenous communities break with the biopolitical moral order of the suburb.

Jerry FRUG, Samuel R. Rosenthal Professor of Law @ Harvard, 1996
(Stanford Law Review, "Surveying Law and Borders," May)

"Gans, however, considers heterogeneity undesirable only"

Support for mass transit must be combined with reductions in automobile fossil fuel consumption.

Bare 03 Virginia Environmental Law Journal

"Any response to the sprawl dilemma must be initiated through federal action"

Federal action is key to check sprawl and overcome segregated interests.

Environmental Lawyer 01

"Urban sprawl has resulted from a variety of historical, economic, and political"

The plan would lead to lower transit fares and undermine residential patterns based on spatial purity.

Kushner 92

"Public transportation is highly efficient. It reduces congestion, public property"

Plan
The US Congress should establish and energy policy requiring the executive branch to reduce total nongovernmental oil consumption by 25 percent within 15 years. The executive branch should engage in binding regulatory negotiations to determine implementation. Parties will have no more than one year to negotiate.

Emory CG

 

The United States Federal Government should establish an energy policy requiring a substantial reduction of non-governmental fossil fuel consumption by establishing a tradable permits regime requiring a decrease in consumption of fossil fuels so that emissions decrease 7% from 1990 levels in the United States by 2012 and establish an auction system for permit distribution.

COMPETITIVNESS

An international transition to renewable energy has already begun and a large scale market for sustainable technology will be in place within 10-20 years.

 

El-Ashry, CEO of the Global Environmental Facility, 2001 [“Renewable Energy: GEF Partners with Business for a Better World,” www.gefweb.org]

 

 

Renewable energies are the market of the future; they’ll dwarf all other opportunities.

 

Joseph Romm, principle deputy assistant secretary at the department of energy, 3/14/96[FDCH]

 

The U.S. is losing its ability to compete in the new energy market; Germany and Japan are poised to dominate.

 

Los Angeles Times, 5/23/04 [Power Outage; The U.S. is falling far behind its rivals in developing alternative energy sources]

Failure to lead in the international renewable energy markets will undermine overall U.S. economic competitiveness.

 

Daniel M. Kammen, professor of public policy with the Goldman School of Public Policy, et. al., 12/01 [“Renewable Energy a Viable Choice,” Environment]

 

 

US firms will be subject to tariff barriers if the U.S. doesn’t reduce emissions, causing uncertainty that threatens competitiveness.

 

Kiplinger Business Forecasts 7/27/01 [What Kyoto's Revival Means for U.S. Business]

 

U.S. competitiveness is key to hegemony; a loss of our edge will cause isolationism.

The impact is nuclear war.

 

Khalilzad, RAND Corporation, 1995 [Zalmay, “Losing the Moment?” The Washington Quarterly, Spring, l/n]

 

U.S. implementation with permits will encourage innovation and reduce costs.

 

Jennifer Yelin-Kefer, Stanford Environmental Law Journal, January 2001 [20 Stan. Envtl. L.J. 221]

The renewable tech created by tradable permits will restore competitiveness and make it easy to meet reduction requirements.

 

Daniel M. Kammen, professor of public policy with the Goldman School of Public Policy, et. al., 12/01 [“Renewable Energy a Viable Choice,” Environment]

 

A combination of monitoring and verifiable self-reporting will ensure accurate tracking of greenhouse gases.

 

Hoong N. Young, Journal of Land Use & Environmental Law, Fall 1998 [14 J. Land Use & Envtl. Law 125, “An Analysis of a Global CO2 Emissions Trading Program”]

 

Empirical support goes aff.

 

Elaine Kamarck, heads the program on 21st-century governance at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government, 12/31/97 [Pittsburgh Post-Gazette, American Know-How can cool the world]

 

 

WARMING

Permit trading will create foundation for future climate change agreements and restore our leadership in climate change.

 

Daniel Bodansky, National Interest, Fall 2001 [Bonn Voyage: Kyoto’s Uncertain Revival]

 

U.S. leadership in climate change is critical both because its own emissions are massive and because it has the ability to reduce emissions worldwide.

 

Sir John Houghton, co-chair of the scientific assessment working group of the intergovernmental panel on climate change, 7/28/03 [The Guardian]

 

The plan provides the basis for the U.S. to craft an international climate change regime.


David G. Victor, senior fellow for science and technology at the Council on Foreign Relations, 3/23/01 [New York Times]

 

Self-enforcement ensures future agreements will work.

 

David M. Driesen, Associate Professor at Syracuse University College of Law, Fall 1998 [26 B.C. Envtl. Aff. L. Rev. 1, “Free Lunch or Cheap Fix?: The Emissions Trading Idea and the Climate Change Convention”]

The Heat is on-The 3 Biggest feedbacks are all positive and guarantee rapid warming greater than ever anticipated- newest research proves

New Scientist 7-24-04

 

This part of the debate is over- GCM’s underestimate its effects which include international water wars, ethnic conflicts, and agricultural collapse

Dr. Kennedy,  who we guarantee will be the most qualified source on the issue, 6-24-04  started his distinguished career as a neurobiologist. He then served as Commissioner of the FDA and then for 12 years as President of Stanford University. Today, he conducts his research through the Institute for International Studies, focusing on transboundary environmental problems, and is a member of the National Academy of Sciences and editor in chief of Science, the journal of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.  http://www.pewclimate.org/docUploads/Kennedy%2Epdf

Despite extensive and continuous government assistance -- including more than

been ordered and built in the U.S. since 1973. After building more than a
hundred plants between 1954-1973, orders have been cancelled over the last
thirty years, and capacity in the industry has stagnated since 1989.  The
decline of nuclear power is a result of several factors: the Three Mile Island
disaster heightened public safety fears and citizen opposition

Florida CW

 

Plan Text

 

The Department of Energy should establish an energy policy granting adequate funding to Changing World Technologies to research and develop the process of thermal depolymerization under the Clean Coal Power Initiative.  The Department of Agriculture should require the conversion of all agricultural waste to fuel through the thermal depolymerization process by 2034, and the Department of Energy should require that the fuel be used in place of foreign oil.  Funding and enforcement guaranteed.  We reserve the right to clarify intent.

AFF broke at districts
Districts Aff:

We begin with an excerpt from Bush's State of the Union Address
(retrieved from Richard Slawsky, New Orleans City Business feb 14,
2005, "Bush-backed energy bill gains support in Louisiana" from
lexis-nexis).  The needed senate support for the energy bill now
exists: it should pass after Easter. Jim Blum (Washington post
February 13, "Another Energy Push planned; proponents encouraged by
enchanced GOP Majorities on Hill" p.l/n) argues that Barton's
committee is entering a markup stage for which to gain more bipartisan
support for the bill.  Pat Gehrke ["Critique arguments as policy
analysis: Policy debate beyond the rationalist perspective"
Contemporary Argumentation and Debate vol. 19 p.19-39) argues that
policy interpretation relies on communication and that this
communication largely shapes the people in the debate and the policy
itself. Traditional fiat debating ignores other important parts of
policy making because it emphasizes impacts – this a priori
"outweighs" all other parts of the debate. This is a different stage
of policy making: we interpret the resolutional word "should" as
futurity (dictionary.reference.com/search?=should), so the Energy
policy act of 2005 should pass, and we need to mark it up.  Another
impact of policy making is the institutional forces at work behind
debate.  Walter Mignolo explains that as academics and scholars
involved with corporate universities, we have a responsibility to
engage the humanities: technical skills and efficiency, while
important, don't guarantee ethical conduct in political engagements
("Globalization and the Geopolitics of Knowledge: The Role of the
Humanities in the Corporate University," Nepantla: Views From the
South, April 1, 2003 (vol. 4, no. 1) 98).  Ethical policymaking
requires that we also attend to the discursive impacts of the round –
raka shome explains that imperialism takes place discursively in the
age of late capitalism and globalization ("Postcolonial Interventions
in the Rhetorical Canon: An 'Other' View," Contemporary Rhetorical
Theory, eds. Lucaites, Condit, Caudill (NY: Guilford, 1999) 591-608,
esp. 599-600.) and Charles Wilkins argues that the linguistic content
of policy, including preambles,  implicates legislators and the
citizens (The Eagle Bird: Mapping a New West, (NY: Pantheon, 1992)
15.).  In response to these concerns, we strike out the phrase "for
the American people" in the preamble to the Energy Policy Act of 2005
because: it excludes other beings on the planet directly implicated by
US fossil fuel consumption; isolates the US, erecting a barrier
between "us" and "them,"; and is redundant and unnecessary
(http://energycommerce.house.gov/108/0205_Energy/Cover%20and%20Table%20of%20Contents.PDF).

 

This is all of the affs we ran except our districts aff: i will send that
tomorrow  I will also send Neg info at that time
Thanks
Michael Richardson
FHSU Debate

Aff broke at Northwestern

This aff follows a similar thread of the Black Mesa aff that we ran most of
the rest of the 2nd semester (the aff in the UNT casebook).  It takes a
slightly different trajectory.  It began with an explanation of a few
threads of Phil’s genealogical background including his family’s immigration
to Wilson Kansas and escaping oppression in Europe, to then become
generations of Kansas farmers.  From there, the IAC turns to an explanation
of the Black mesa dispute from Ward Churchill’s chapter on it in Struggle
for the Land: p. 143 and then move into an explanation of the N-aquifer
drying up from a piece of evidence from Repps Hudson (“Peabody’s Use of the
Desert Water Takes Spotlight at Annual Meeting,” in the St. Louis
Post-Dispatch, May 4, 2002) as well as the Black Mesa Trust President,
Leonard Selestewa internally quoted in Brenda Norrell’s article called
“Black Mesa Residents Urge Search for Energy Alternatives,” Indian Country
Today (aug 11, 2004) about continued use of the aquifer as irresponsible.
Sean Patrick Reily (“Gathering Clouds: Arizona’s Navajo and Hopi Tribes Have
Won a Water-Rights Battle Agaisnt the Coal Company that has Sustained their
Fragile Economies, But on the Threshold of Impending Victory, a Sobering
Question: Now What?” LA Times Magazine  June 6, 2004) gives the statistics
about what exactly is being taken from the aquifer. – We read a hopi wuuchim
prophecy song sung by valgean joshevena, senior found on
http://www.blackmesatrust.org/hopi_elders.htm.  We read more explanation
about the destruction to the hopi people/the area by use of the aquifer
found in S.J. Wilson “OSM Holds scoping meeting in Flagstaff” found at
http://blackmesais.org/OSM_flagstaff.htm.
The next move of the affirmative begins with a card from Whitt, Roberts,
Norman, and Grieves in “Belonging to the Land: Indigenous Knowledge Systems
and the Natural World” 26 Oklahoma City University Law Review 701 (summer
2001) about having/showing respect for land and stories, and having a
belonging to the land as well as quoting Lawrence Sullivan in Native
American Religions and Cultures of North America (2000) p. 3 and n3 talking
about the anthropology of the sacred.  Sullivan is talking about one of the
problems of communication between Indians and non-Indians is a totally
different perception of reality, and that’s how we have to begin to build
connections is starting there.  thus we affirm the topic respectfully in
alternative indigenous realities attempting to understand that one topical
reality must not be a-priori accepted over another- it must however begin
with respect, and must be located in a particular context (this context is
the Black Mesa coal/water dispute).  And then we read a quote from Lillian
hill from http://www.inmotionmagazine.com/global/wj_lh_int.html talking
about the value of water in hopi tradition, including that their science
suggests that there are beings in the water.  We conclude with a quote from
the Arizona governor explaining that 2005 is a critical year in the debate
over the Mohave Generating station/coal mining quoted in Jim Maniaci @
http://gallupindependent.com/122104gov.html.

Aff broke at UNT

-       Peabody energy- peer reviewed scientific studies
-       Masayesva, Black mesa trust, our science is interconnected
-       Sekaquaptewa – mining does not violate Hopi religion
-       Johnson, Peabody consultant, Aquifers get off reactor
-       Black mesa water contract- western science compartmentalized
-       Corbin Harvey, Watersong (audio)
-       Masayesva, water is affected by words, prayers and songs
-       Interior department – good neighbor
-       McDonald, chair Navajo tribal concil – grandparents burrow
-       Privilege rap: south central Kansas, Fort Hays,white, land, genocide
-       Santiago (poem) Praise
-       Mina Lasa, Hopi Kikanonowi, Orasis Pueblo, Leave it to us to decide
-       Zait, Prez, Navajo – can never agree

Must shatter interpretive framework, must de-homogenize personal privilege,
must read contradictory perspectives and representations against one another

- LA Times Magazine, 6/27 2004, l/n, Cry, Sacred Ground, 1988

www.blackmesatrust.org/vervow%2001.htm
www.osmre.gov/news/093003B.txt
Navajo-hopi land dispute, HRGS 7/24/74
Black Mesa Poems, 1989
Navajo-Hopi Dispute Settlement Agreement-In-Principle HGOS 2/10/93

Aff broke at Wake

We begin with an epigraph from Michel Foucault’s “Of Other Spaces” arguing
we are in the epoch of space, and anxiety of our time is one of space and
spatiality.  We acknowledge our privilege in line with Linda Alcoff who
argues that we need to recognize the ways we are advantage by societal
imbalances and then recognize what we can do to affect those imbalances
positively- we affirm the resolution as heterotopias, we affirm its
heterotopias- this examines the words and things of debate and fossil fuel
consuption- we also include the old-order amish as a topical heterotopia,
one that is incongruous to American fossil fuel consumption- we defend the
role of the ballot differently, such that it being configured as a
discursive heterotopia capable of including various incongruent arguments
and advocacies intention and cite Benjamin Gennochio from Post Modern Cities
and Spaces (ed. Watson and Gibson) 1995, who argues that discursive
heterotopias alter and unravel understandings of the giveness of words and
things—this helps give us the tools to fight discursive imperialism in an
age when imperialism is not just physical but also discursive as Raka Shome
in 1999 (Not contemporary rhetorical theory “post colonial interventions in
the Rhetorical Canon: An ‘other’ View”

Aff Broke at Gonzaga

Heterotopia AFF
Michel Foucault 1967 "Of Other Spaces"
http://foucault.info/documents/heteroTopia/foucault.heteroTopia.en.html
- We are in the epoch of space, of the side-by-side, of the
dispersed
-this lecture concerned itself with heterotopias
-we affirm the resolution as a heterotopia, affirm its
heterotopias, its other place, its countersites
Foucault "of other spaces" on the concept of heterotopia
- its in relation to all the other sites, but suspect,
neutralize, or invent the sets of relations  -- really
existing places
-we acknowledge our privilege as white males as part of a
privileged team and university
-we affirm the old order amish in Yoder Kansas as a
hetertopia since they exist in the cracks seams and fissures
of non-governmental fossil fuel use with respect to
energy/electricity and fuel use
-we must proceed with caution because heterotopias are
dangerous places, including the amish, but the question is
how do you approach these other spaces
-the amish negotiate outside influence with electricity use,
refusing many "modern" technologies
-the buggy physically is a heterotopia such that it can be
enclosed or open (depending on the way the sides are set up)
as a way of negotiating influence
-locating the cracks, seams and fissures in the political
groundwork is pragmatic politics in the age of space
-heterotopias transform this debate space in largely
unthought ways: including language, thinking evidence,
flows, and ballots
-global capital and industrial farming are imposing a lethal
homogenization on the planet, devastating local knowledge
and diversity, we must deviate - in debate where time is
the rule, space is a serious deviation: vote aff to deviate

Fullerton (Alshiek & Seidman)

 

FULLERTON AS

The affirmative starts off with a short discussion as to how an Iraqi individual might experience the United State’s presence in Iraq. It suggests it is a pretty terrible, miserable experience.

 

“Thomas Hubbard”, “Terrorism”, poetsagainstthewar.org

 

In the aftermath September 11th 2001, profound sense vulnerability throughout America and the world is born. Aggression towards difference followed the attack as the government decided to retaliate with an attack on Afghanistan, while threatening any and all countries that are part of the ‘axis of evil’. Since, the United States has pursued its ‘War on Terror’, which included violence towards Iraq because of Weapons of Mass Destruction as well as Iraqi ties to September 11th.

 

The Iraq Attack has been framed with the most benign intentions conceivable; however time has also told that it is a resources war. For Americans this resource war has meant their drills that seek to extract oil simultaneously extracts Iraqi’s blood. The seeds for democracy are planted, but the United States has let the soil run dry. This vile and vulgar ‘War on Terror’ has been waged to destroy all who do not believe what Americans do or want what Americans want.

EVEREST IN 2004 [Larry Everest, reported Iraq for over 20 years, Oil, Power, and Empire, Monroe (Canada): Common Courage Press, pg 248-249]

The Iraq Attack is part of a larger system of violence and domination that seeks to erase difference to order the world. In the process, history is something that has been hegemonized, which has risked further violence. This is systematic of a collective mindset of cosmic control, which depends on the empire’s projected illusion of invulnerability. When this illusion is confronted with reality, escalation becomes inevitable

LIFTON IN 2003 [Robert Jay Lifton, “American Apocalypse”, The Nation, December 22, 2003, http://www.thenation.com/doc.mhtml?i=20031222&s=lifton]

In lieu of the injustice associated with United States’ Attack on Iraq, we feel that the statement that ‘the United States federal government should establish an energy policy requiring a substantial reduction of total non-governmental fossil fuel consumption’ is a productive one.

Our advocacy represents an oppositional statement to the narrative of invasion. The call to limit nongovernmental fossil fuel consumption functions as the focal point for a genealogical retelling of the invasion of Iraq. It is an antagonistic perspective with the stories of weapons of mass destruction centered around it, which makes explicit the American ‘Grab the Oil’ Strategy. Such is precisely our reading of the resolution as we attempt to make it our own manual for living.

 

CLIFFORD IN 2001 [Michael Clifford, Political Genealogy After Foucault, 2001, pg 70-71]

 

It is our affirmation that is a return to knowledge that does not recreate hegemonic ways of knowing that destroy difference through inscription; instead our affirmation offers greater hope for destabilizing the dominant narrative of subjugation.

 

FOUCAULT IN 1976 [Michel Foucault, “Society Must Be Defended”, Lectures at the College de France, 1975-1976, New York: Picador, Ed. Arnold Davidson, trans. David Macey, pg 6-9]

 

Given that the will to consume oil has been used in order to further America’s imperial tactics, we wish to use the resolution to contextualize it in our lives, specifically, to effect how we consume the resources of the earth as well as people. We use the resolution to reclaim our agency to align ourselves with a political approach that does not rely on unbridled consumption. Indifference is no longer an excuse for domination of difference.

 

CRITCHLEY IN 1999 [Simon Critchley, Ethics Politics Subjectivity, pg 109-111]

 

An element of stepping off this dangerous treadmill, absolutely requires that we speak out against the violent tendencies that has destroyed the lives of Iraqi people; as we stand in solidarity with Fi Amanallah plea.

Finally, silence is no longer an option when confronted with the violence against Iraqis insofar as it makes the lives of the suffering Iraqis ungrievable. Our affirmation becomes a force that asserts the value of Iraqi people through representation. This restores meaning to politics in order to bring about an age of interdependence and justice.

 

BUTLER IN 2004 [Judith Butler, professor of Rhetoric and Comparative Literature at the University of California, Berkeley, Precarious Life: The Power of Mourning and Violence, pg 146-151]

Fullerton (Magallon & Montes)

 

This is the statement we have defended in the last four tournaments:

 

We will not defend fiat.  We will not pretend to be the federal government.  But at the end of the debate we will ask you to express an opinion about whether the USFG should reduce consumption, particularly by ceasing the extraction of oil from Chiapas for consumption in the US.  The topic asks a question:  Should the United States Federal Government reduce fossil fuel consumption?  This question is a subset of the theme of this speech:  Western culture, for which the USFG asserts the role of official caretaker, IS the center, and it consumes all at the margins.  It consumed the gold of the Aztecs and the bodies of Mayans, the land of Mexico and the coast of California, and when it became valuable, western culture consumed the oil of Mexico and Guatemala.  Fossil fuel consumption cannot be understood in isolation, but against a 500-year history of western culture consuming Latino culture.  We affirm the resolution; this consumption must stop.  It must stop in on our televisions, in hiring practices, in immigration law, in our universities, in our books, in our thoughts, our hearts, our minds, and yes, in fossil fuel consumption.

 

1) The dominant will always push the weak to the margins….this has proven throughout history…. We provide the example of 500 years of colonization…

 

The story of the Encounter from the perspective of the Arawak

Zinn 95 (Howard, A People’s History of the United States, Pg. 1-7)

 

Cortes and the genocide of the Aztecs

Zinn 95 (Howard, A People’s History of the United States, Pg. 11-12)

 

2) Such domination exists today….this is reflected by inequalities that exists today…

 

Latinas have the highest dropout rates in the U.S.

Vives 2001 (Olga, National Organization for Women, Fall, http://www.now.org/nnt/fall-2001/latinas.html?printable)

 

Latino under-representation in education makes Latinos disinterested in schools

Talavera 2005 (Pedro, Department of Foreign Language, The Chart Online, January 21, http://thechartonline.collegepublisher.com/news/2005/01/21/PublicForum/Latino.UnderRepresentation.Lends.To.Misunderstanding.About.Education-837031.shtml)

 

Latinos are the most harmed in the workplace

The Rights Stuff 2004 (May-June, National origin religion and the Minnesota Human Rights Act, http://www.humanrights.state.mn.us/rsonline4/or_overview.html)

 

This same discrimination is in the health care systemMaynard 2005 (What Goes Wrong: The Human Factor Treating People Differently, http://www.maynardije.org/news/features/040913_lehrman-part2/page4/)

3) (We have a discussion of US imperialism being a new form of colonization; in which western consumption is prioritized and culture is sacrificed for its consumptive needs)

 

We talk about the Zapatistas as being an example of uprising against the system; and we should have a historical analysis to understand ways in which we can use history for the future.

 

We make a specific correlation and explanation as to how US energy policies has encouraged companies to exploit oil in the Chiapas region.

 

What is a source of pride for Brenda and I, what is central to Latino culture, is that we derive our self-respect from our connection to indigenous culture.  In that indigenous culture we find a source of hope, and just as the Zapitistas do what they can do protect culture in Chiapas, we will try to protect that culture in this debate.

Georgia (Todd Mitchell and Kevin Rabinowitz

Georgia (Brent Culpepper and Hays Watson)

 

Ob. 1:  Bush's recent New Source Review allows exempted coal
plants to avoid pollution upgrades
Environmental Media Services 2003 ["Bush Admin Relaxes New
Source Review"  Sept. 12, 2003.
www.ems.org/new_source_review/reaction.html]
"the new exclusion will allow plant operators"

As a result, Exempted Coal Plants are not required to meet the
CAA pollution standards
Barton 2001.  [US H of Rep.  Hearing on Energy and Air Quality
Subcommittee of the Energy and Commerce Committee.  FNS.
March 14, 2001]
"fired power plants on the thesis that eventually they'd"

This means that nearly 4/5ths of all coal plants continue to
avoid meeting emissions requirements resulting in the
consumption of massive amounts of fossil fuels
Hsu 2001.  [George Washington University Law School.  Summer,
14 Tul. Envtl. L.J. 427]
"Nearly four-fifths of the coal-fired power plants in the
United States"

Exempted Coal Plants Consume Twice as much fossil fuels to
produce electricity
Pace Energy Project 98.  ["New York's Dirty Secret:  The Power
Plan Pollution Loophole,"
www.eany.org/reports/dirtypower/dirtyny3.pdf]
"All Power plants are not created equal"

The USFG should establish an energy policy requiring the
prohibition of non-governmental consumption of Fossil Fuels in
power plants currently exempted from the Clean Air Act and
Related Amendments

Observation Two:  EJ

Abandonment of the New Source Review Program allow thousands
of Dirty Coal Plants to remain open in American's minority
communities

Lawyers' Committee for Civil Rights under Law 2003.
["Environmental Justice: New Clear Air Act Regulations & The
Anticipated
Impact on Minority Communities" June 2003.
http://www.lawyerscommittee.org/features/40thpapers/ej.pdf]
On December 31, 2002, the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency
(“EPA”) finalized one rule and proposed another, the effects
of which will be to dramatically weaken the nation’s clean air
laws by changing the Clean Air Act’s New Source Review

And Race is the single most likely determining factor of
exposure to Dirty Coal Plants

Lawyers' Committee for Civil Rights under Law 2003.
["Environmental Justice: New Clear Air Act Regulations & The
Anticipated
Impact on Minority Communities" June 2003.
http://www.lawyerscommittee.org/features/40thpapers/ej.pdf]
Race plays a significant role when measuring the likelihood
that a community will be located near municipal landfills,
incinerators, and toxic waste dumps.

Subpoint A:  The Movement

These Coal Plants exist in minority communities because of the
structural racism inherent in siting and represent potentially
the greatest environmental injustice we face - the continued
existence of these plants subjects minority communities to
disproportional air pollution and health hazards

Lawyers' Committee for Civil Rights under Law 2003.
["Environmental Justice: New Clear Air Act Regulations & The
Anticipated
Impact on Minority Communities" June 2003.
http://www.lawyerscommittee.org/features/40thpapers/ej.pdf]
This paper focuses on six such communities around the United
States, including in Ohio, Texas, “Chicagoland”, Pennsylvania,
New Jersey, and Georgia.

Regardless of the Reason for exempted coal plants placement -
The outcome is racist and indicative of larger social norms

Foster 1998.  [Associate Professor of Law @ Rutgers.  86
Calif. L. Rev. 775]
"The chicken or egg quandry posed by commentators does not"

And Ethics demands an on face resistance to racism
Barndt

Environmental Justice Movements are demanding a challenge to
the symbolic racism embedded in siting of plants - Legislation
that takes a stand against Exemptions is critical to address
the central concern of minority communities

Kaswan 1997.  [Alice.  Asst. Professor of Law @ Catholic
University.  47 Am. U.L. Rev. 221  December]

"Environmental laws play three different roles in the pursuit
of environmental justice"

National Legislation alone solves for the Environmental
Justice Movement

Bullard 1993.  [Robert D.  professor of Sociology at the
University of California, Riverside.  Confronting
Environmental Racism]

"The lessons from civil rights struggles around housing,
employment, education, and public accommodations over the past
four decades"

The Plan is a long awaited Victory of Environmental Justice
Advocates call for Greater Community Participation in the
siting and eradication of dirty coal-fired plants.  This
pragmatic victory helps us to recognize the efficacy of a
multiplicity of perspectives to establish flexible
environmental standards

Shutkin and Lord 1994.  [Law Professors @ Boston College.  96
w. va. L. rev. 117]
"The environmental justice movement's push for greater
community participation"

The Environmental Justice Movements Potential for
Transformative Change Comes from its Embrace of Difference for
Unity

Schlosberg 1999.  [Environmental Politics.  Spring #1]
"In the various organisations and networks"

Continued Environmental Injustices present Multiple Scenarios
for Extinction - The Environmental Justice Movement is the
only hope for Survival

Bryant 1995.  [Bunyan.  UM Environmental Justice Initiative.
Environmental Justice:  Issues, Policies and Solutions].

Sub Point B:  The Ethic

The Institutional Racism intrinsic to exempted coal plants is
the single greatest barrier to a community of multiculturalism

Moore and Head 2002.  Toxic Struggle:  The Theory and Practice
of Environmental Jusice.  Pp. 126

Hiroshima.  Pp. 155-156

apocalypse rather we must engage in an ethical coalition

capable of reconstituting an ethic where Auschwitz is rendered
impossible

Holy Community Solves

AFF – Gonzaga – Hahn & Hutchison

 

Gonzaga HH--not sure what the most recent version of their aff was, although they were crafting it around Derek Bell's story "The Space Traders" about race in America.

 

It's still the Space Traders by Derrick Bell.

 

We start with Day 1, which is that the traders have arrived and

explained their proposal.

 

Then there's a statement about how the space trade is analogous to the

consequences of our consumption.

 

Then we read the next day, which is the president talking in his

cabinet meeting about how to respond; all the members leave with the

understanding that the trade is going to happen.

 

We read another statement about the ineffectiveness of traditional

appeals for inclusion.

 

Then days 7-the end of the story, which consist of the Jewish

anti-trade rally and its failure, the  ratification of the amendment,

the crackdown on blacks by the supreme court and executive laws, and

finally the blacks being shipped away.

 

Then we make our statement about affirming the topic in order to

interrogate our consumptive practices (not the exact text, but

something close to that).  We discuss what it means to "go lightly"

towards the topic.

 

Finally, we read the protagonist's (Golightly) speech at the anti-trade

coalition.

 

 

Gonzaga HH Aff

Rnd #1 – Nichols

Vs. Georgia RW

Judge: MacCartney

 

1AC

 

Aliens from the unknown have come to Earth with an offther that will solve all consumption of fossil fuels. In exchange for all African Americans in the United States, the Space Traders will provide an unlimited, perfectly efficient energy source that will solve all dependency and environmental problems of America. The Traders have given us until January 16th to complete the trade, a small sacrifice must be made for this immense  privilege—trading all African Americans, who put a drain on social services and croud prisons

Derek Bell

 

Plan: The United States federal government should establish an energy policy requiring the substantial reduction in the total non-governmental consumption of fossil fuels in the United States by completing the Agreement to Transfer All African Americans in exchange for the perfect renewable energy provided by the Space Traders.

 

We must assume that the African Americans will be taken to a land of milk and honey – claims that trade represents the American Final Solution must be rejected – we must assume the Best – African Americans will be taken to a place better than any white controlled part of the US.

 

Confronting Real = confronting the impossible choice of ethics

Zupancic, Ethics of the Real, 234-238

 

2AC

 

AT: T USFG

1. We meet the definition – we are the government in Washington DC – constitutional amendment is part of the federal government

 

AT: FW

1. Plans are not an inherent part of the resolution; they are an artificial construct – it is their burden to prove why we should be forced to defend something more than the resolution

 

2. We meet – we’ll defend the USFG doing the topic as an ethical middle finger to consumption – they can read all their DAs

 

3. CI – the resolution – our intellectual proposition affirms it. Plans allow the aff to spike out of resolutionally based neg DAs through overspec. Our interp key to topic focus.

 

4. We are not utopian – we don’t wish away the world problems.

 

5. Aff gets to pick the focus fo the debate – as long as we meet the resolution, we get to pick the focus and impact frame

 

6. Plan texts aren’t stable – ASPEC and ISPEC prove that the plan is meaningless

 

7. Their interp of extra T doesn’t allow affs to claim advantages

Our 1AC is usually identical to that which Harvard AM reads We have a warming
and an oil advantage. However, we've also read a permit selling advantage. I've
included the tags and cites within this email.
Tell me if we're missing anything

Adv. 1
Russian economy growth will eliminate their surplus permits, there will be a
dearth of permit sellers in the global emissions trading market
Sejo, Senior fellow at resources for the future 12/15/03 (Google "The end of
Kyoto?" or : why it doesn't'really matter what the Russians do about Kyoto)
Until recently, the above estimates might have seemed moot. After the fall of
the soviet union, Russia experienced dramatic declines in economic acitivity
and coincidental large decreases in greenhouse gas emissions.


As the Russian surplus disappears the US will become the primary seller on the
international permit market
McKibben, http://www.brookings.org/dybdocroot/views/papers/mckibbin/143.pdf
Moreover, the U.S. proposal would probably not even achieve the goal of
stabilizing emissions.



Multi0variable economic models show that the US will be a significant permit
seller McKibben, Professor
Same as above
We use an econometrically estimated multi region, multi sector general
equilibrium model of the world economy to examine the effects of using a system
of internationally tradable emissions permits

participating countries have very different marginal costs of abating carbon
emissions.

Iowa RS

 

Observation One: "Give Me Liberty or Give me Death"

 

The Bush Administration continues its policy of corporate welfare through the "new source review" -- a policy that specifically allows older coal plants to escape environmental regulation.  This is a form of discrimination, where people are forced to live in misery in the name of the "rights" of fat cat coal plant owners.

Armstrong June 2003 www.lawyerscomm.org/features/40thpapers/ej.pdf

"On december 31, 2002, the U.S. ... constantly polluted air."

 

These groups demand that these fossil fuels plants be removed form their communities due to the adverse effects that it has on their health and their communities.

 

Congresssional Black Caucus 2004 www.cbcfinc.org/pdf/Climate_Change.pdf

"A second detailed study indicates..."

 

These political demands for equality are silenced in our democracy in the name of liberal rights -- liberalism defines rights and liberty as a need to protect the individual and their right to property.  This separation of equality from liberty has become the fundamental basis for liberalism, capitalism, and all inequalities that have existed in our society.  If we hear calls for equality and put them into the framework of rights we can take liberal notions of rights to their very limit and question the entire order of politics that presides over society now.

 

Balibar 94 Masses, Classes, and Ideas "Let us then leave aside...a mediation becomes necessary."

 

We need to take an intellectual commitment to reconstitute what it is to be political -- to not do so would allow the negative forms of politics that make life meaningless and violence possible to continue to exist.

 

Balibar 2002 Politics and the Other Scene "What I call the other scene...optimism of the will", as Gramsci wrote"

 

Neoliberalism tells people that new forms of politics aren't needed.  THrough this, it sustains violence of collective suicide on a global level.  After all, neoliberalism doesn't need to justify its violence if it already justified the infallibility of property rights.  Only chanign the politics of relating to the other will bring about an end to genocidal violence.

 

Santos 2003 [eserver.org/bs/63/santos.html] "According to Franz Hinkelammert..innocent civilians."

 

We are thus resolved and call on you to affirm:

 

The United States Congress should require an immediate phase-out of the burning of fossil fuels by non-governmental fossil fuel plants currently exempted for modernization from the New Source Review.

 

Observation Two: The Ballot

 

Use the ballot to affirm your commitment to equaliberty.  Voting for our plan functions as a call for equaliberty -- a starting point from which other demands against oppression and inequality can emanate from.  We can combine the two concepts of equality and liberty to create a new universal beyond the political stalemate that pervades modern politics.  This juxtaposition is the most radical move since it questions the very coordinates of politics, threatening the current violent social order.

 

Johnson Dec 1 2003 Historical Materialism 11(4) With the proposition of equaliberty...resistance to imperialist globalization"

 

And why stop there?  If the process of creating new universals with specific demands for equaliberty is politically subversive, it can be a metaphor for all kinds of demands, making a totally new realm of politics possible.

 

Zizek Summer 98 Critical Inquiry 24 "Let us begin with the question...particular problem of their plight"

 

The proper political act is the act that laughs in the face of criticism and failure -- succumbing to what is "socially possible" or "acceptable" is antithetical to proper politics and is a conservative justification for the status quo.

 

Zizek 2000 Contingency, hegemony, Universality pp. 121-5

 

Voting for the Affirmative is the most ethcial option.  Ethics demands that we are unconditional in our attack of capitalism.  Endorse an ethics where we accept our responsbility in the construction of our political reality, and assert political acts that do no rely on any existing symbolic authority.

 

Daly 2004 Conversations with Zizek pp. 19

James Madison GM

Observation One – The Monkey Trap

(Robert Freeman 2004. “will the end of oil mean the end of America?”

www.commondreams.org)

 

Observation Two – Apocalypse Now

 

The oil peak is here. Negative arguments are wild exaggerations funded by

the fossil fuel industry.

(Matt Savinar 2004 “The oil age is over”

www.lifeaftertheoilcrash.net/index.html)

 

We have all the qualifications; your arguments come from naïve economists

(Richard Heinberg 2003 “The party’s over oil, war and the fate of industrial

society)

 

90% of the human population will die from war, disease and starvation when

the oil crash comes

(Savinar)

 

In response to the peak, transnational oil companies are looking for new

areas to drill. The exploration drive will destroy ecologically essential

habitat and lead to tyranny.

(Scott Holwick 2000. “transnational corporate behavior and its disparate…”

Winter, 11, Colorado journal of international law and policy)

 

This is apocalypse now. The economic system based on fossil fuels has

created a tyrannical U.S. state. The impact is genocide and biocide.

(William Ophuls 1997. “requiem for modern politics” pg 168-

170)

 

In response to the oil peak, the U.S. has initiated a policy

of      oil grab. This policy ensures widespread military

intervention

(Nafeez Ahmed 2003. “The coming crisis”

http://usa.mediamonitors.net/content/view/full/238)

 

The Bush oil grab strategy will cause wars with north korea, Iran, china,

libya and Syria

(Ahmed)

 

These oil grab wars will result in extinction

(Savinar)

 

Plan: USFG should establish an energy policy of energy reconfiguration

requiring a 50% reduction in non- governmental fossil fuel consumption over

current levels by 2015. The conservation standard should be set to rise 5%

every year until 2015. Funding and enforcement guaranteed.

 

Observation Three – A new Hope

 

The alternative to oil grab is energy reconfiguration. We can decrease

energy consumption in all sectors by 50% through conservation and

efficiency.

(Freeman)

 

An efficiency standard that rises 5% a year ensures a smooth transition. It

allows markets time to adjust and ensures reductions outpace economic

growth.

(Ross Gelbspan 2004. “toward a global energy transition.”

Dollars and Sense March 1, #252, lex)

 

We can easily reduce over 50% of fossil fuel consumption through

conservation and efficiency gains.

(Amory Lovins 2004. “leaner, greener world”. Aug 23rd, lex.

Business week online interview)

 

Finally, energy reconfiguration saves the economy and the environment, while

reducing the terrorism and militarism.

The

military savings alone could pay for the entire transition.

(Freeman)

 

Observation Four – Framework

Fiat is a utopian moment—The ability to imagine another world without the

restraints of place…But we will defend the implications of our vision once

implemented. However, disadvantages based on the process of the plan attempt

to place our utopia within the confines of the current political time and

space. Such arguments are merely inherency for our utopian vision.

(Freeman)

 


Kansas CS

Derek Denniston is author of High Priorities: Conserving Mountain Ecosystems and Cultures, Worldwatch Paper 123 and co-author of State of the World 1995, Dr Martin Price is Director of the Centre for Mountain Studies at Perth College, within Scotland's UHI Millennium Institute, 'creating the University of the Highlands and Islands'. He is also on the Board of Directors of the Mountain Forum. http://www.peopleandplanet.net/doc.php?id=966&section=11  21 Sep 2004

Plan text:  The USFG should establish an energy policy requiring a substantial reduction in total non-governmental fossil fuel consumption by banning fossil fuel consumption in pesticides and fertilizers. Enforcement guaranteed.  We'll clarify intent. 

 

Inherency

 

Pesticides and Fertilizers account for 36 % of ag fossil fuel use (Pfiefer 2004, "Eating Fossil Fuels")  "In the United States, 400 gallons of oil…"

 

Pesticides and fertilizers rely heavily on oil for production (WordIQ.com 2004, "Definition of Organic Farming")   "Another hidden cost is the depletion…"

 

The US pesticide accounts for 20 % of the world market (EPA, 03, "1998-199 Pesticide Market Estimates:  Usage")  "US pesticide amount used in 1998…"

 

The US exported 3.2 billion pounds of pesticides (International Journal of Occupational and Environmental Health, 2002,"US pesticide exports remain high")  "Nearly 3.2 billion pounds of pesticide…"

 

 

Pesticides Advantage

 

A. Human health

 

Pesticides kill 20,000 per year (Peminetel and Lehman, 93, The Pesticide Question: Environment, Economics, and Ethics.   p. 48)

 

Pesticides alter human development risking extinction (Colborn, 96, Our Stolen Future:  Are we threatening our fertility, intelligence and survival?)

 

Pesticides will lead to extinction (Beeman, 01, A Green and Permanent Land, p. 2)

 

 

B. Biodiversity

 

Chemicals decrease diversity risking food shortags and extinction (Conscious choice, 2002)            

 

Pesticides erode human health and ecosystems (Cousens, 2000)  

 

Biodiversity is key to preventing total extinction (Diner, 1994)  

 

 

 

 

Fertilizer Advantage

 

A. Soil

 

Agricultural chemicals are the greatest threat to soil (Beeman, 01)                     

 

Chemical fertilizers destroy soil microbes (Beeman, 01)   

 

Micoroorganisms are key to agroecosystems (Kennedy, 98)    

 

Chemicals cause erosion (Kimbrell, 2002)  

 

Erosion causes poverty and war (Beeman, 2001)

 

Soil erosion will lead to extinction (Beeman, 01, A Green and Permanent Land, p. 13-14)

 

 

B. Explosives

 

Attacks will be conventional (Parachini, 2001)

 

The accessability of chemical fertilizers guarantees an attack (News and Record, 2004)                       

 

Guarantees nuclear war (Sunday Herald, 2003)   

 

 

Ecology Advantage

 

Soil degradation is human domination over nature  (Beeman 2001)   

 

Pesticides cause mastery over nature (Pimental and Lehman, 1993)

 

Ecology is key to freedom, health, the economy and survival (Beeman, 2001)

 

Sustainable ag is key to solving rural decline, economic collapse, ecological disharmony, disease, pollution, biodiversity loss, health problems, and war (Beeman, 2001)

 

Law is key to check industrial agriculture, which is the greatest threat to harmony with nature (Beeman, 2001)

 

Government action is critical to preventing disaster (Beeman, 2001)

 

Government is key to solve pesticide use- farmers won't do it on their own (NAS, 2000)

 

 

 

Solvency

 

The world models US pesticide legislation (Multinational Monitor, 1991)

 

The world models US pesticide policy (NAS, 2000)

 

Regulations increase the economy (Bleise 99)

 

Pesticides cause higher food prices (Pimental and Lehman, 93, The Pesticide Question:  Environment, Economics, and Ethics, p. 60)

 

Natural farming solves pests and herbivores (Barret and Skelton, 02, Landscape Ecology in Agroecosystems Management, p. 332)

 

Pesticides remain in the soil kiling rotating crops, thus pesticides stop the ability to rotate crops and reduces yields (Pimental and Lehman, 93, The Pesticide Question:  Environment, Economics, and Ethics, p. 61-62)

 

Lack of rotating crops cancels out pesticide effectiveness (Pimental and Lehman, 93, The Pesticide Question:  Environment, Economics, and Ethics, p. 47)

 

Pesticide use leads to pesticide resistance decreasing crop production (Pimental and Lehman, 93, The Pesticide Question:  Environment, Economics, and Ethics, p. 56-57)

 

Reducing pesticide use increases production more than pesticide use- Indonesia proves (Pimental and Lehman, 93, The Pesticide Question:   Environment, Economics, and Ethics, p. 56)

 

Pesticide use reduces agricultural production-cotton proves (Pimental and Lehman, 93, The Pesticide Question:  Environment, Economics, and Ethics, p. 59)

 

Even if OF has lower yields, its because they lack the huge subsidies CF has.  Everyone turning organic would increase yields (WordIQ.com, 2004, "Definition of Organic Farming") "Some organic farming advocates believe that…"

 

Organic techniques solves humus deficiency, pests, crop diseases, and health problems (Beeman, 01, A Green and Permanent Land, p. 49)

 

All of your evidence that says pesticides and fertilizers are good are biased because they are funded by huge agribusinesses (WordIQ.com, 2004, "Definition of Organic Farming")  "Throughout this history, the focus of scientific…"

 

The costs of pesticides are drastically underestimated (Pimental and Lehman, 93, The Pesticide Question:  Environment, Economics, and Ethics, p. 72)

 

Avery is a liar (Cooper, I forget the year, but he really did lie)

Long Beach (Kandeel & Peterson)

Louisville (Ebony Floyd and Jennifer Harris)

Mary Washington PW

Plan Texts

The United States Congress should establish a domestic Renewable Fuel
Standard, requiring that 15% of fuel in the United States be comprised
of cellulosic biomass ethanol by 2020.  This standard should contain
credit-trading provisions.  We'll clarify.
Or
The United States Congress should establish a domestic renewable fuel
standard, capping non-governmental oil consumption at 85% of current
levels and requiring that at least 15% of nongovernmental oil consumed
in the United States comes from cellulosic biomass ethanol by 2020.
This standard should contain credit-trading provisions.  We'll
clarify.

Early in the year we read a generic corn ethanol RFS that required 5
billion gallons- but that is fairly unlikely.

World Oil Production will peak in 2010
Engdahl, The Centre for Research on Globalization, 8/04

1, 2004   www.globalresearch.ca <http://globalresearch.ca> 6 August
2004 >

on Crude Oil Depletion - C.J.Campbell - Revised February 2002
http://www.mbendi.co.za/indy/oilg/p0070.htm>

disorderly transition

Trade Wars Adv

Advantage One is Trade
As Kyoto implementation becomes more likely- Europe will place massive
trade sanctions on the U.S. to correct competitive imbalances
Peter Fontaine, Cozen O'Connor Law Firm Energy Chair, 2004
[Public Utilities Fortnightly, August, v. 142, i8, "The Gathering
Storm: Russia Resurrects the Kyoto Protocol and the Prospect of Their
Mandatory CO2 Emissions Cuts for U.S. Utilities, or the Start of a

Observation One: Inherency

Contention Two: Out of Oil

 

First, the world is currently on an oil production plateau – we have the unique opportunity to engineer a stable slide down the energy curve

Richard Heinberg, Staff at the New College of California, “Power Down: Options and Actions for a Post-Carbon World”, 2004, p. 36-37

 

This historical period… measured and deliberate.

 

And, negative authors are overly optimistic, reserve growth and new discoveries won’t prolong depletion

Richard Heinberg, Staff at the New College of California, “the Party’s Over: Oil, War, and the Fate of Industrial Societies”, 2003, p. 116

 

Next let us… of smaller fields.

 

And, multiple empirical examples disprove industry estimates and confirm peak production theory

John Attarain, Free Lance Write rand PhD in Economics from U of M, “The Coming End of Cheap Oil”, The Social Contract Press, Summer 2002, http://www.thesocialcontract.com/cgi-bin/showarticle.pl?articleID=1094&terms=

 

Other geologists have… and Britain (1999).(10)

 

And, put away the Simon evidence, new technology won’t create more net energy – and our authors already account for it

Richard Heinberg, Staff at the New College of California, “The Paryt’s Over: Oil, War and the Fate of Industrial Societies”, 2003, p. 109-110

 

Lomborg’s second argument… ever-decreasing EROEI.

 

Additionally, unconventional oils are net energy losers – they won’t solve depletion

John Attarain, Free Lance Write rand PhD in Economics from U of M, “The Coming End of Cheap Oil”, The Social Contract Press, Summer 2002, http://www.thesocialcontract.com/cgi-bin/showarticle.pl?articleID=1094&terms=

 

But the cornucopian… not help much.

 

Moreover, the market won’t supply renewable energy until it is too late

Matthew Savinar, J.D., “The Oil Age is Over: What to expect as the World Runs Out of Cheap Oil, 2005-2050”, 2004, p. 51

 

Classical economics works… very rough seas.

 


 

We isolate Three Impact Scenarios

 

Sub-point A is for Economy

 

First, oil is absolutely critical to the economy – energy efficiency is irrelevant

The Guardian, Pumped-up oil prices will hurt us all, November 1, 2004, L/N

 

Demand for oil… not stack up.

 

Additionally, the recession post-peak would be catastrophic – worse than 1929

Paul Roberts, Energy Author and Analyst, “The End of Oil: On the edge of a Perilous New World”, 2004, p. 13

 

The last three times… oil supplies remained.

 

This culminates and extinction

Lt. Col. Thomas E. Bearden, Phd in Nuclear Engineering, April 25, 2000, http://www.cheniere.org/correspondence/042500%20-%20modified.htm

 

Just prior to… of it, resulting.

 

Sub-point B is for global chaos

 

Initially, as oil reserves are depleted competition will heat up between the U.S., Russia and China over the last remaining sources – this quickly escalates from regional proxy conflicts in to global superpower war

Michael Klare, Professor of Program Peace and World Security Studies at Hampshire College, “Blood and Oil: The Dangers and Consequences of America’s Growing Dependency on Imported Petroleum”, 2004, p. 177-178

 

In this precarious… between local powers.

 

And, even if we lose deliberate nuclear war, heightened tensions due to oil depletion could lead to accidental launch

Matthew Savinar, J.D. and Oil Depletion author, “The Oil Age is Over: What to Expect as the World Runs Out of Cheap Oil, 2005-2050”, 2004, p. 98

 

Remember that in… accidental nuclear annihilation.

 

Finally, fossil fuel is the foundation of modern society – peaking without an alternative guarantees the deaths of at least 2 billion people

Richard Heinberg, Staff at the New College of California, “The Party’s Over: Oil, War and the Fate of Industrial Societies”, 2003, p. 32

 

The third danger… anticipated petroleum depletion).

 


 

Sub-point C is for oil spills

 

First, Low mileage standards lead to millions of gallons of oil spills per year in the U.S. and more worldwide – increasing CAFÉ standards is key to preventing this devastation

Noam Mohr and Joseph Shapiro, Researchers at the U.S. PIRG Education Fund, “Pumping up the Price: The Hidden Costs of Outdated Fuel Efficiency Standards”, October 2000, http://uspirg.org/reports/pumpinguptheprice2000.pdf

 

Transporting the excess…  is likely far higher.

 

Furthermore, Oil pollution crushes the marine oxygen pump

Paul Stephen Dempsey, Professor of Transportation law and Director of the Transportation Law Program @ University of Denver College of Law, 1984, 6 NW. J. INT’L L. & BUS. 459

 

The ramifications of… of the ocean.

 

Finally, the continued functioning of the biological pump is critical to the continuation of life on earth

Donald A. Bryant, Dep’t. of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology @ Penn. State University, “The Beauty in Small Things Revealed”, Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, August 19, 2003, http://www.pnas.org/cgi/content/full/100/17/9647

 

 


 

Thus, the plan

 

The United States Federal Government, through the Office of the Secretary of Transportation, should increase Corporate Average Fuel Economy standards for the car and light truck fleets to require a reduction in total nongovernmental oil consumption in the United States by two million barrels per day below current levels by the year 2012 and four million barrels per day below current levels by the year 2020. The increases should be phased in at regular intervals to achieve the specified reductions. We’ll clarify.

First, plan level reductions are economically and technologically feasible – and C.A.F.E. is the best way to solve

Natural Resources Defense Council, “Dangerous Addiction: Ending America’s Oil

Dependence”, January 2002, http://www.nrdc.org/air/transportation/oilsecurity/security.pdf

 

Raise Fuel Economy… in this decade.

 

And, U.S. action to bridge the peak would create global energy transformation

It is important… dominated geopolitical order.

 

Also, Plan is key to buying time for renewable energy by pushing off the oil peak

What is important… a long-time.”

 

And, Your turns are flat wrong – C.A.F.E. empirically led to huge oil savings without increasing costs or decreasing safety

Amory Lovins, Experimental Physicist and CEO of the Rocky Mountain institute, et Al, Winning the Oil Endgame: Innovation for Profits, Jobs and Security, 2004, http://www.oilendgame.org/pdfs/WtOEg_72dpi.pdf

 

Before we similarly… efficient Japanese imports (p. 140).

Welch ‘02

                (David, Business Week, 4-20)

“Detroit was blindsided. Expecting an assault of environmental legislation… what the environmental lobby is counting on.”

 

INTERNATIONALLY, CHINA RECENTLY CREATED NEW STRICT FUEL CONSUMPTION LIMITS – THESE REGULATIONS WILL LOCK OUT U.S. AUTOMAKERS FROM THE CHINESE MARKET BECAUSE OF FUEL ECONOMY STANDARDS

 

AFX 11-9-04

“stringent new fuel economy standards in china will force…. For automobile manufacturers with sales in China.”

 

AS A RESULT, THE AUTO INDUSTRY IS TOAST – CHINA IS THE CRUCIAL MARKET OF THE FUTURE FOR SECTOR-WIDE GROWTH

 

Street Sweep 6-9-04

“China’s huge population and hot economy make it the key emerging market for the world’s automakers… from around the world.”

 

HIGH CAFÉ STANDARDS KEY TO FACILITATE CHINESE MARKET ACCESS AND BOOST AUTO INDUSTRY COMPETITIVENESS

 

Lash ‘03

(Jonathon, President of the World Resources Institute, Fmr Dir Environmental Law and Policy Program @ Vermont Law School, Building the Wrong Cars in Detroit, WRI Features, Vol. 1 No 9 November, http://newsroom.wri.org/wrifeatures_text.cfm?ContentID=2176)

“LOW CAFE FUEL-EFFICIENCY STANDARDS FOR AUTOMOBILES IN THE UNITED STATES MAY END UP HURTING DETROIT…. IF U.S. AUTOMAKERS ARE SERIOUS ABOUT GETTING INTO THESE MARKETS, THERE IS LITTLE TIME TO DELAY. THEY'D BETTER STOP FIGHTING CAFE STANDARDS, AND START MAKING MORE EFFICIENT CARS.”

 

INDEPENDENTLY – AUTO INDUSTRY HACKS AND SKEPTICS ARE WRONG – CAFÉ INCREASES WON’T CAUSE SHORT TERM JOB LOSS OR DAMAGE AUTO REVENUES – MOST CONCLUSIVE EVIDENCE POINTS IMPROVED ECONOMIC GROWTH ACROSS THE BOARD

 

Rinaldi ‘02

(Kara, Et Al., Deputy Policy Director, Alliance to Save Energy, Increasin     rica’s Fuel Economy, February, http://www.sierraclub.org/globalwarming/cleancars/cafe/briefing_book.pdf)

Raising fuel economy would create new jobs in the automotive… as was true for the last two times around—will disappear forever."4

 

DOWNTURN IN THE AUTO SECTOR SPILLS OVER – COLLAPSE WHOLE ECONOMY

 

Hall ‘04

                (Don, President Virginia Automotive Dealers Association, Richmond Times Dispatch, 3-10)

“AS IMPORTANT as the impact of such a drastic tax increase… increasing vehicle prices”

 

NUCLEAR WAR

 

Mead ‘04

(Walter Russell, Snr Fellow @ Council Foreign Relations, Foreign Policy, 4-1)

 

CONTENTION THREE – ENVIRONMENTAL LEADERSHIP

 

INCREASED FUEL EFFICIENCY STANDARDS ARE KEY TO RESTORE U.S. ENVIRONMENTAL LEADERSHIP WHICH IS KEY TO OVERALL HEGEMONY AND SOFT POWER

 

Walker ’02

                (Norbert, NYT, 8-28, Lexis)

“at present there is much talk about the unparalleled strength…. And protecting the planet.”

 

STRONG U.S. ENVIRONMENTAL LEADERSHIP IS KEY TO PREVENT GLOBAL ENVIRONMENTAL DESTRUCTION WHICH RISKS PLANETARY EXTINCTION

 

Harris ‘01

(Paul G., Lecturer @ Lignan U, Hong Kong And Associate Fellow at the Oxford Center for Environment, Ethics, and Society at Mansfield College, Oxford University, The Environment, International Relations, and U.S. Foreign Policy, p. 241-2)

 

THUS THE PLAN –

 

The United States Federal Government, through the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, should increase Corporate Average Fuel Economy standards to require a substantial reduction in the total non-governmental consumption of fossil fuels in the United States. We’ll Clarify.

 

After this, we read various pre-empts or a framework argument, depending on who we are debating.

 

We’ve also read this longer version of environmental leadership (Round 5 of Northwestern).

 

contention __ : Environmental leadership –

 

numerous setbacks have devastated the u.s. credibility internationally but policy choices now could restore leadership

 

Nye ‘04

(Joseph, Prof and Fmr Dean Of Kennedy School of Gov’t @ Harvard, Can America Regain Its Soft Power After Abu Ghraib?, Yale Global, 7-29, http://yaleglobal.yale.edu/display.article?id=4302)

Even before the Abu Ghraib photos were published, anti-Americanism had been rising around the world. … working more closely to involve allies and international institutions.

 

higher café standard restore u.s. environmental leadership internationally which is key to overall soft and hard power

 

Walker ‘02

                (Norbert, chief economist at Deutsche Bank Group, New York Times, 8-28)

At present there is much talk about the unparalleled strength of the United States on the world stage. metaphorically speaking, to get out of its oversized, gas-guzzling S.U.V. -- and join the rest of the world in doing more to combat global warming and protecting the planet.

 

café increases overcome international anger over rejection of kyoto

 

Denver Post ‘04

                (10-6, Lexis)

By signing the Kyoto treaty, Russian President Vladimir Putin put the … that's earned the United States so much international criticism.

 

 

strong u.s. leadership is necessary to prevent a global nuclear exchange

 

Khalilzad ‘95

Harris ‘01

(Paul G., Lecturer @ Lignan U, Hong Kong And Associate Fellow at the Oxford Center for Environment, Ethics, and Society at Mansfield College, Oxford University, The Environment, International Relations, and U.S. Foreign Policy, p. 241-2)

Environment, Equity, and U.S. Foreign Policy: Normative Implications …. because that is likely what Americans would expect of others were the United States in similar circumstances.68

 

specifically – café is key to demand international air pollution protection

 

San Francisco Bay Guardian ‘00

(Knight Ridder, Common Dreams, 5-27, http://www.commondreams.org/views/052900-104.htm)

Environmental groups have been pushing Congress to raise the CAFE standard to 45 mpg … lessen the toll air pollution takes on our health (according to several national studies, air pollution is responsible for 64,000 deaths each year).

 

transportation-related air pollution kills 3 million a year

 

Roberts ‘02

                (Bernie, Earth Policy Institute, 9-17, http://www.earth-policy.org/Updates/Update17.htm)

The World Health Organization reports that 3 million people now die each year from the effects of air pollution. … some cities-is primarily composed of ozone and particulates.

 

this terminally results in extinction

 

Drisen ‘03

                (David, Prof Law – Syracuse, Buffalo Environmental Law Journal, Fall, 2002/Spring ‘03

Michigan State HV

Stefan:  Here's aff stuff for MSU HV:

Trade:

Doha is on the brink – US Leadership on ag key to multilateral trade
Oxfam 2004 (July, “One minute to midnight”, Briefing Paper 65, http://www.oxfam.org.uk/what_we_do/issues/trade/downloads/bp65_wto.pdf)

Now key – US action checks WTO collapse
Oxfam 2004 (July 31, “Trade talks move inches”, Press Release, http://www.oxfam.org.uk/press/releases/wto_310704.htm)

Industrial ag is the root cause of subsidies
Grossman 1994 (Margaret Rosso, Ag Law Prof @ U. Ill, “Agriculture and the Environment”, 42 Am. J. Comp. L. 291 (Supp.), p. Hein)

Industrial ag --> export crops and dumping through subsidies
Madden and Chaplowe 1997 (J. Patrick and Scott G., Ag. Econ prof @ Penn State and founder Sust. Ag. Res. And Ed., and Sust. Ag expert and Geography MA, Introduction and Overview, in For All Generations, ed. Madden and Chaplowe, p 18)

Sustainable ag would abandon subsidies
Faeth 1991 (Paul, WRI Assoc, Paying the Farm Bill, World Res. Inst., p 19-20)

Abandoning subsidies = U.S. leadership, saves WTO and checks FTA’s
Sally 2004 (Razeen, Sen. Res. Fellow @ Inst. SEA, “Doha round crucial”, Korea Herald, Aug. 31, p ln)

U.S. trade leadership is key to the global economy and checking wars – Bilateral spills over with WTO
Bergstein 2001 (Fred, Dir. Inst. For Int’l Econ and assis. Sec. of treasury, Foreign Affairs, April, p ln)

NASULGC 1999 (National Association of State Universities and Land-Grant Colleges, “Global Food Issues”, http://www.nasulgc.org/foodsociety/Global401.PDF)

plan --> transition, eliminates subsidies
Adelman and Barton 2002 (David E., Assoc. Prof Law @ UA & Ph.D/JD Stanford, and George E., Law prof @ Stanford, “Environmental Regulation For Agriculture”, Jan, 21 Stan. Envtl. L.J. 3, p ln)

ag economy key to economy and trade
Francl 1998 (Terry, et al., sen. Economist @ Am. Farm Bureau Fed., 10-30, http://www.heartland.org/pdf/gwag-study.PDF)

WTO collapse inevitable without removing subsidies

Legrain 2003 (Phillipe, spec. advisor to WTO, “Last Resort”, Nov. 3, The New Republic, p ln)
