Copley News Service, December 1, 1999

Farm Economy:
FF consumption has made ag mechanization and long-distance food transport possible Heinberg ‘3 The Party’s Over p.175 “Modern industrial agriculture has become… geologic past”

Mechanization has raised capital costs, forcing corporate consolidation and driving small farmers out of business – Ikerd 2002 www.ssu.missouri.edu/faculty/jikerd/papers/IllSmall.html “acriculture is not a new phenomenon…giant agribusiness corporations”

Long-distance food transport creates an economic incentive for farmers to adopt monoculture and costly chemical inputs, destroying small farms Clunies-Ross and Hilyard 1992 The Politics of industrial agriculture p. 15-16 “In economic terms…favour large, intensive farmers”

These inputs discourage crop diversification and hamstring farm profits Ikerd 2002 “Thankfully, a new breed of American farmer… among America’s larger farms”

This corporatization encourages production of commodity crops, collapsing US acricultural competitiveness and making global war inevitable Ikerd 2002 “Increasingly, the multinational corporations will find… and how many people will be killed”

Long-distance food transport destroys the economic sustainability of small farms – building new niche markets is key to revitalize farm profits Ikerd 2 “Sustainable farms must also be of a size… large farm be sustainable”

Mechanization and irrigation will collapse agriculture – causes soil erosion, chemical inputs, monocultures, salinisation, and water depletion Norberg-Hodge, Goering and Page 2001 From the Ground Up, p.29-31 “One of the most fundamental trends in industrial… than it is being replenished”

Failure to move away from the current system ensures agricultural collapse Altieri 2K Hungry for Profit ed. Magdoff, Foster and Buttel p. 77-78 “Until about four decades ago…”

Decline in the farm economy will spill over to the broader economy and create a backlash against trade liberalization Francl 98 www.heartland.org/pdf/gwag-study.pdf “ripple effect that a decline in farm income would have…. would stagnate or decline”

This backlash will cause pull-out of the WTO – boosting competitiveness key Goldstein and Martin 2K www.stanford.edu/class/polisci243c/readings/c0002092.pdf “groups affected by trade policy…free flow of goods and services”

Trade backlash collapses multilateral liberalization – this tanks the global economy and the WTO, causing global war Bergstein 1 FA, Aprol “present crisis is the decline of effective…toward hemispheric trade liberalization”

Continued liberalization is key to boost US exports, preventing a collapse in the global economy and the WTO Legrain 3 “Last Resort” The New Republic Nov. 3 “Such disputes could not only damage political and economic relations…much chance of that now”

Economic decline makes nuclear war with China inevitable Mead 4 “America’s Sticky Power” March 1, Foreign Policy “global economic might is therefore not simply…conflict is less likely to occur”

WTO Collapse causes nuclear war Copley News Service 12/1/99 “many children in America and other countries went to bed fearing annihilation by nuclear war…should be celebrating it”

Forcing local production saves the economy and spurs a shift to smaller farms without eliminating trade Gorelick 2K The ecologist 5-22 www.theecologist.org/archive_article.html?article=186 “Firstly, and most obviously, rather than specialise…  49 million kilogrammes”

Reducing food transportation spors a shift to sustainable ag – federal regulations are key for global modeling and movements Cobb 2001 Christian Century June 6 “political leaders propose two scenarios… nations into international agreements on the environment”

Local production solves the need for chemical inputs and farm machinery, while boosting yields Horberg-Hodge, Goering and Page 2001 From the Ground Up p.xxvii “The benefits of local food production are many… higher total output per unit of land…”

Agroterrorism
Long distance food system is uniquely susceptible to terrorist attacks – most cities only have a 2 day supply of food
Brian Halweil, World Watch, “Home Grown,” WW Paper 163. 2002. worldwatch.org
“This search for security and confidence is, of course, not limited…
…although their scale would help limit the consequences.)89

“The federal government has recently classified several scientific studies…
…to work with the food industry to close the security gaps, Brackett said.”

John Steinbruner, Senior fellow at Brookings, Foreign Policy, Dec 22 1997. l/n.
“The use of a pathogen, by constrast, is an extended…
..this sort but not necessarily its outer limits”

John L. Peterson, Founder Arlington Inst. 10-3-2002. “The Next sound you hear,”
www.wfs.org/mmpetersen.htm
“But there seems to be a rather specific objective…
…we will immediately put up our defenses.”

Irrigation

1.    Crop rotation lowers evapotransporation needs, reducing irrigation demands (Schneekloth 2002 “Management Strategies” CSU “Crop rotations can have a major…..When irrigating the entire acreage.”
2.    Ogalla depletion will collapse civilization (Economist 2003   “Irrigate and Die” “Privatisation and dams may …..do for water then?”)
3.    3. Sustainable ag solves middle east and African water wars (Charrier, Dinar, and Curtin 2003, “Water, Conflict Resolution and Environmental Sustainability in the Middle East” “Freshwater resources are finite, ….more efficient crops and methodologies”
4.    Irrigation causes water depletion, collapseing agricultural production (Clunies-Ross and Hildyard 1992, The Politics of Industrial Agriculture, Pg 25-6)
5.    Water Wars Escalate and the Impact is 4 billion people (CSM 99, 6-14)
6.    Goes Nuclear (Duetsch, “The Rabid Tiger Newsletter” Vol 2 No 9 Nov 18 2002)
7.    Middle East War -> Global nuclear war (Steinbach 02, Centre for research on globalization, “Israeli Weapons of Mass Destruction:  A Threat to Peace” “The Israeli nuclear arsenal….could trigger a world conflagration”

Plans

The USFG should establish an energy policy requiring a substantial
reduction in the total non-governmental consumption of fossil fuels by
requiring a gradual 80% phase-out of fossil fuel consumption in the
following practices by no later than 2025 -- crop drying, irrigation,
the operation of field machinery (including tillage & crop dusting
equipment), and the manufacturing of inorganic fertilizers & pesticides.
We get to clarify intent

The usfg should establish an energy policy requiring that total
non-governmental consumption of fossil fuels reduce by no less than 8%
via a phase-out of fossil fuel consumption by the agricultural sector in
the United States. The phase-out will require germane parties to reduce
their respective contributions to fossil fuel consumption by at least
30% of present levels by 2010. We get to clarify intent

The United States Federal Government should establish an energy policy requiring an 80% phase-out of non-governmental fossil fuel consumption in the following practices in the United States by no later than 2012 – the operation of agricultural machinery, food processing, and food transportation.  The plan will be carried out by the United States Dpartment of Agriculture.  We get to clarify intent.


aaron
msu

AFF CASE- NORTHWESTERN BC- HARVARD +

OBSERVATION ONE- HISTORY OF CONSUMPTION

TODAY¡¦S ENVIRONMENTALISM IS BOUND TO A HISTORY OF UNEQUAL FOSSIL FUEL CONSUMPTION FROM THOSE IN
THE NORTH AGAINST THOSE IN THE SOUTH. THIS DISPARATE ENERGY USE CONSTITUTES AN ECOLOGICAL DEBT THAT
HAS BEEN REFUSED AT THE INTERSECTTION OF GOVERNMENT POLICY AND INDIVIDUAL PRACTICES. THIS REFUSAL
STANDS AS THE A PRIORI EXAMPLE OF ENVIRONMENTAL AND ECONOMIC APARTHEID

GONZALES, ASST PROF LAW @ SEATTLE UNIVERSITY, 2001
78 DENV U L REV 979

THIS READING OF HISTORY AND THE ECOLOGICAL DEBT UNCOVERS THE VIOLENT ORDERING LOGIC OF COLONIZING
DISCOURSES IN THE CONTEXT OF ALL OUR RELATIONSHIPS. THIS NEW IMPERIALISM FORECLOSES THE POSSIBILITY
OF DEMOCRATIC ARTICULATION OF ALTERNATIVE VISIONS OF LIVING AND CONTESTING VIOLENT ENVIRONMENTAL
PRACITCES

BANERJEE, DEVELOPMENT AND STRATEGIC MANAGEMENT @ ADELAIDE, 2003 (WHO SUSTAINS WHOSE DEVELOPMENT, http://www.sagepub.co.uk/PDF/JOURNALS/FULLTEXT/a031341.pdf)

THIS VIOLENT PRODUCTION OF THE SUBJECT IN ITS RELATION TO THE STATE AND THE ECO-DEBT REQUIRES AN
EXAMINATION INTO THE HISTORY OF CONSUMPTIVE PRACTICES THEMSELVES- A HISTORICAL EXAMINATION OVER
CONSUMPTION CAN MOTIVATE A RADICALLY RE-FORMULATED DEMOCRATIC DISCURSIVITY THAT CAN EXAMINE THE
RELATIONS THAT MOTIVATE A POLITICS OF VIOLENCE

BOGUES, AFRICANA STUDIES @ BROWN, 2002
http://iupjournals.org/smallaxe/sm11.html
MASQUERADING AS FREEDOM, THE REFUSAL OF THE ECO-DEBT CONSTITUTES A FORECLOSURE OF DISCURSIVE
POSSIBILITY AND AN AFFIRMATION OF A SUBJECT BUILT ONLY TO CONSUME INFINITELY. THIS SUBJECT, POSED
AS APART FROM ITS CONTEXTS AND SOCIAL SURROUNDINGS, IS THE GREATEST TOOL FOR GLOBAL MILITARIZED
VIOLENCE- INDEED, THE UNQUESTIONABLE CONSUMPTIVE SUBJECT IS THE VEHICLE THAT PLACES THE DEMAND FOR
EXTERMINATION WITHIN SUBJECTS THEMSELVES

AGANTHANGELOU AND LING, GLOBAL CHANGE INSTITUTE & NEW SCHOOL, 2004
http://www.maxwell.syr.edu/maxpages/faculty/gmbonham/ISQ-Lily-Anna.doc

PLAN: THE UNITED STATES FEDERAL GOVERNMENT SHOULD REQUIRE A 90% REDUCTION OF NON-GOVERNMENTAL
FOSSIL FUEL CONSUMPTION IN THE UNITED STATES.

OBS TWO: TRAVERSING THE HISTORICAL

THE PLAN IS THE MOVE THAT CAN HIGHLIGHT PERSONAL RESPONSIBILITY FOR OUR CONSUMPTIVE PRACITCES THAT
MAKE UP THE ECO-DEBT- VOTE AFF TO RE-ASSERT THE PERSONAL INTO THE POLITICAL IN ENERGY POLICY AND
RADICALLY RE-ARTICULATE THE QUESTION OF DEBT AND CLIMATE CHANGE ON A GLOBAL SCALE

SIMMS, NEW ECONOMICS FOUNDATION, 2001
(ECOLOGICAL DEBT- BALANCING THE ENVIRONMENTAL BUDGET AND COMPENSATING DEVELOPING COUNTRIES http://www.jubilee2000uk.org/ecological_debt/Reports/04%20ecological%20debt.pdf)
OUR 1AC IS AN ENGAGEMENT WITH THE QUESTION OF WHAT KIND OF SUBJECTS CONSUMPTION CREATES AND
GOVERNMENTS CONCOCT. USE THE BALLOT TO REJECT THE NOTION OF A UNIFIED SUBJECT BUILT ONLY TO CONSUME
THAT IS AT THE HEART OF THE REFUSAL OF THE ECO-DEBT. AFFIRM THE 1AC¡¦S DECREASE IN CONSUMPTION AS A
STARTING POINT TO BEGIN THE DISCUSSION OVER HOW AND WHY THE ECO-DEBT WAS CREATED IN THE FIRST
PLACE. ONLY BE RE-OPENING THE QUESTION OF HOW WE CONSUME AND WHO WE ARE ASSUMED TO BE AS A RESULT
OF GOVERNMENT POLICY CAN WE CULTIVATE SPACES FOR DISCUSION THAT LEAVE THE QUESTIONS OF CONTEST AND
OPPOSITION CONSTANTLY OPEN

BROWN, POLI SCI @ BERKELEY, 1995
(WENDY, STATES OF INJURY, 48-51)

A DEMAND ON THE STATE IS NOT A DEFERRAL OF AUTHORITY. THE 1AC¡¦S CALL IS A CONFRONTATION WITH THE
WAY US ENERGY POLICY HAS CONSTITUTED ITS SUBJECTS AND TRANSNATIONALIZED VIOLENCE- WE MUST ACCOUNT
FOR THE STATE IN HISTORIES OF CONSUMPTION TO TRANSFORM BOTH OUR RELATIONSHIP TO THE GOVERNMENT AND
ENERGIZE A POLITICS OF RESPONSIBILITY AND DEMOCRATIC CONTESTATION

CAMPBELL, IR @ NEWCASTLE, 1998
MILLENIUM 27.3 P 513-519

THE GOVERNMENT¡¦S REFUSAL OF THE ECO-DEBT IS THE MOVE THAT DISTANCES US FROM OUR DAILY PRACTICES OF
VIOLENCE AND THE POSSIBILITY OF PRACTICING JUSTICE IN OUR RELATIONSHIPS. VOTE AFF TO DE-LEGITIMIZE
THE GOVERNMENT¡¦S CREATION OF A STABLE SUBJECT AND MAKE A WORLD WITH INFINITE OTHERS POSSIBLE

AGATHANGELOU AND LING (CITED ABOVE)

FINALLY, THE UNCONDITIONAL APPEAL FOR THE ECO-DEBT IS THE MOMENT THAT MARKS THE DECISION AND THUS
THE INFINITE PRACTICE OF JUSTICE. TO REFUSE TO ACT IS TO REFUSE THE CONCEPT OF JUSTICE ITSELF- ONLY
THE EXCESSIVE DEMAND IN THE FACE OF POSSIBLE INJUSTCE CAN MOTIVATE AN EVER-PRESENT MODE OF CARE FOR
OTHERS AND SELF THAT ITSELF REFUSES CLOSURE

DERRIDA 1994
SPECTRES OF MARX, 30-33

American debates about energy have reached a state of catastrophic closure -
short term political and economic debates have mad a sustainable energy
policy unthinkable. The result is choking the life our of democracy and the
planet
Brian oleary, 2k1 (http://home.independence.net)
Unfortunately, in the eyes of the mass media, discussion about ending
pollution

Treating the symptom and not the source is the defining theme of this
arrangement. Precautionary requirements for sustainability have been
squelched in a barrage of technological and economic fixes that license
unlimited consumption and ecological eradication.
Gary bryner, 2k2 (73U.colo.l.rev.341)
A cautious, conservative, ethically defensible

PP stands for democratic justice - refusal to give primacy to this
commitment provides a pitiful response to the most fundamental question of
our time - failure of restraint = atrocity on a grand scale
Low and Gleeson, 98 (justice, society, and nature: an exploration of
political ecology) 25-8
What are the implication of this escape?

Accelerated consumptive economy ensures war for fossil fuels
Robert freeman, 3-1-4 (commondreams.org/views04/0301-12.htm)
America has its own hand in a coconut

We ask you to affirm that: the United states federal government should sue
the precautionary principle as the criteria for formulating and implementing
regulations on the non-governmental consumption of fossil fuels in the
united states such that precautionary measure apply even if some cause and
effect relationships proving harm to present or future human and non-human
communities can not be established scientifically.

Cont. 2 - precaution is a principle

Voting for the plan is a normative endorsement of a new ethical vision of
energy policy. Reducing the debate to a programmatic assessment of the
economic and political barriers to the principle erases the most important
role for decisionmaking and guarantees the termination of the planet
Joel kassiola, 2k4 (environmental values 12:4, p 489-5-14
In opposition to this view of callicotts

Success of energy imagination depends on inclusion of the principle it's the
best method for initiating ecological restraint and democratic inclusion in
decisionmaking
Robyn eckersley, april '4 (the green state: rethinking democracy and
sovereignty) 134-8
In cases of scientific uncertainty

The principle best challenges ecologcail eradication and the economic and
technological forces which ensure it
Jordan and O'Riordan, the pp in contemporary environmental policy and
politics, 1998, www.johnsonfdn.org/conferences/precautionary/jord.html,
safeguarding ecological space the pp.. .alters the sq.. .tide of the times

principle imposes a binding requirement for reduction - our ev. References
the most cited application of the principle
phillippe sands, 94 (1 ind.j.global leg. Stud. 293)
there is no uniform understanding

principle doesn't close down tech debate - it makes it possible by taking
control out of the market - it drives public value driven energy
decisionmaking
carloyn raffensperger, 9-1-4 (multinational monitor, 9:25)
the second mode of implementation


Northwestern DJ

Oklahoma CJ connor cleary & blake johnson

AFF

We claim that fossil fuel consumption=assimilation.  Our argument is that before the discovery of fossil fuels on native lands (reservations by this point), the USFG was engaging in actual, physical genocide of indigenous peoples (we read a few narratives about this).  When we realized there were fossil fuels on native lands, we shifted to a policy of assimilation to gain access to the resouces on the land.  This occured through the Indian Reorganization Act of 1934.  Under this law, the USFG installed "tribal councils" as head of different tribes...these councils were rubber stamps for the government and signed away resources for consumption.

Our argument (yes, we affirm the resolution. No, we do not read a plan) is that we should reduce our consumption of fossil fuels because the demand for them is eradicating indigenous cultures. That is about it.

Our cites:  Brent Ashabranner, "Black Star, morning Sun" (book), 1982 (p. 29-30)
Ward Churchill, "A Little Matter of Genocide," 1997 (pg. 291-293)

Pittsburgh EW

Pittsburgh JM

 

To: Stefan.Bauschard@gmail.com
1AC:

Obs. 1 - The Economy

Scenario A - Volatility

Oil prices will remain high and volatile. It will be more of the same again
this year- Increased world demand and OPEC production gurantee.
X GLOBAL NEWSWIRE 2005 (Jan 26, 2005, L/N)
“Fuel prices in the market will remain volatile” and “which is considered a
risk factor in the oil business.”

And, China’s need for oil has fundamentally changed demand. Between U.S.
and Chinese oil consumption prices will hit $70 per barrel and destroy the
economy.
Halligan 2004 (Liam, Oct 24, 2004, SUNDAY TELEGRAPH (LONDON), L/N)
“Despite this prospect of cleaning our teeth” and “increase the actually
happened.”

Plus, High prices may lead to OPEC repricing their price floor to $40 a
barrel locking in a world of high and volatile prices.
Jaffe Jan 27, 2005 (Amy Meyers, Bad ass chick, The New York Sun, “Does OPEC
need to meet?”, L/N)
“So if OPEC doesn’t need to meet” and “hands and count the money.”

Furthermore, oil dependence costs the US Economy trillions of dollars and
sparks recession.
Dancs 2003 A(1-14-03, “The Economies of Oil Dependence,”
http://www.fguide.org/Bulletin/oildepend.htm)
“Oil dependence is incredibly costly” and  “were all followed by economic
recessions”

Sky rocketing demand causes an economic collapse that makes 1929 look like
child’s play
Roberts 2004, environmental expert and Harper’s contributor, The End of
Oil, 2004
“The last three times oil production” and “replace all the barrels they
produce.”

Economic collapse leads to nuclear war and extinction
Bearden 2000
<If you don’t have this cite by now I’m not going to give it to you bitch)

Scenario B is Finitude

China oil demand is growing unabated. Their blistering rate of demand will
require 4 more Saudi Arabia’s.
Investor’s Business Daily 2005 (Doug Tsuruoka, 1/26/05, l/n)
“It’s a hard issue to ignore if one” and “competing with China for
shrinking supplies.”

New oil prospects aren’t promising and even if they were it would not be
enough to matter
Goodstein, Cal Tech Physics Prof, 2004 (David, The End of the Age of Oil,
pg 35-36)
“What about the possibility that a huge” and “rather than burning it up in
our cars.”

Oil exploration gets more difficult everyday; now finds have peaked
Roberts 2004, environmental expert and Harper’s contributor, The End of
Oil, 2004, pg 50-51)
“Oil, in other words” and reserves from shrinking”

The increase in oil production is not sustainable. The impact is the end of
humanity as we know it.
Pheiffer Dec 29, 2004 (Dale Allen, geologist, Scientific journalist,
Contributer for From the Wilderness, “Current Situations and the 2005
Project”,
http://fromthewilderness.com/free/ww3/122904_current_situation.shtml)
“Oil production will begin to decline in 2007” and “survive while
surrounded by predators” (Doesn’t that sound bad ass?)

Scenario C is Indo/Pak

Competition for oil resources is unlinked to oil production peak ? Chinese
and Indian demand will crowd out the rest of the world even assuming oil
production increases. Only curbing U.S. consumption will solve mass
starvation and conflict between India and Pakistan.
Pfeiffer 2002 (Dale Allen, quals above,
http://www.fromthewilderness.com/free/ww3/092502_endgame.html)
“If energy demand in China, India and Indonesia” and “we need energy
efficiency and conservation”

War in India and Pakistan is a nuclear tinderbox waiting to be ignited
globally
Kelly 1999 (Michael, “Political Downsizing: The re-emergence of
self-determination, and the movement toward smaller, ethnically homogenous
states, Drake Law Review)

“Kashmir is now occupied by three sovereign nation-states” and “waiting to
be ignited.”

Observation 2: Energy Grab

Scenerio A- The Great Power War

China Oil demand is fueling their aggressive quest for oil reserves. You
name it and they are after it. Oil acquisitions are zero-sum with the
United States
Investor’s Business Daily 2005 (Doug Tsuruoka, 1/26/2005, L/n)

“Its nice to have a red-hot economy like China’s” and “Sudan and Yemen
already supply over 39% of China’s crude”

The Middle East is China’s only feasible option to fill in their oil needs
KLARE 2004 (Michael, Blood and Oil: The Dangers and Consequences of
America’s Growing Dependence on Imported Petroleum”, Metropolitan Books)
“The thirst for oil will become critical as the growing purchase power” and
“major anxiety in Beijing.”

Current Energy policy ensures a crash course between the US and China over
oil in the Middle East, sparking WW3
Luft 2004 (LA Times, Feb 2, 2004)
“Sixty-seven years ago, oil-starved Japan” and “we are still in a position
to halt China’s slide into oil dependency.”

Scenario B - The Spratly Islands

Denying China access to oil imports causes them to become more aggressive
in the Spratleys
National Interest, 2004
“Kazakhstan has given China a warm welcome” and “oil from disputed
territories”

Energy need is the key reason China would ignore US deterrent efforts and
invade the Spratley’s
Miller 2002 (“Maintaining Peace in the South China Seas and the Spratly
Islands” ___ I can’t read the eaddress- just google the phrases”
“One can make an argument that it is not in China’s best interest to claim
the potential oil” and “the nation most likely to fill the vacuum.”

The Spratleys are the most likely flashpoint for a U.S.-Sino war
Times Newspapers, June 3, 2004
“They bear romantic names, such as Mischief Reef” and “floating patterns
come to the Spratleys”

Conflict in the South China Sea over the Spratleys will draw in major world
powers
Waldron, 1997 (“How not to deal with China” March, Volume 103, Number 3)

“Then there is Southeast Asia, which, having weathered” and “or Japan- or
the United States”

Conflict in the South China Sea goes nuclear
The Straits Times 1995
“In the first ? the worst possible scenario ? Asian countries”

Text: The USFG should establish an energy policy requiring a cap that
reduces total non-governmental consumption of fossil fuels in the United
States by at least 1 million barrels of oil a day by 2013. These reductions
will be implemented via a  regulatory guideline requiring an overall
Corporate Average Fuel Economy Standard of at least 40 miles per gallon for
all passenger automobiles, light trucks, and SUV’s. Logisitics and
enforcement ensured. We get to clarify intent. increase corporate average
fuel economy standards to require a substantial reduction in total
non-governmental consumption of fossil fuels in the United States.

Observation 4: Solvency

A Cap on US oil consumption by 1 million barrels a day would necessitate an
increase in Café standards
Bamberger 2003 (Robert L,
http://fpc.state.gov/documents/organizations/23426.pdf)
“Some had hailed as an alternative” and “final bill reported from
conference.”

China’s oil demand will surpass US consumption. Its effect will sustain
high oil prices. We must develop fuel efficiency standards to address
bottlenecks in the energy sector that cause price spikes
Washington Post,  oct 14, 2004
“It’s hard to know whether this drag” and “legislation to create the right
incentives.”

Closing the loophole significantly reduces oil dependence
Klare 2004 (same book as above, pg 194-5)
“The Café standards have been an extradorinrily” and “or 1.8 billion
barrels per year.”

CAFÉ standards empirically increase fuel efficiency and solve oil dependence
Hanger 2004 (http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/04158/327256.stm)
“In 1975 Congress passed the Energy Policy Conservation Act” and
“significantly raise Café standards”

Plan solves dependence, even in a world of low prices
National Academy of Sciences, 2002
(http://www.nap.edu/books/0309076013/html)

“The CAFÉ program has clearly contributed” and “or about 14 percent of
today’s consumption”

And, the plan would eliminate the need for Middle East oil imports
Union of Concerned Scientists, 2002 (online, “Increasing America;s Fuel
Economy”
“Raising fuel economy standards is the most effective way” and “12 million
barrels by 2020”

US energy policy is modeled worldwide, we lead, others follow
WIRTH 2003 (Foreign Affairs, VOl 82, Issue 4, “the Future of Energy policy”)
“Energy is a common thread weaving through” and “and far into the future”

Regis RS

 

Affirmative #1

 

We begin with an investigation of the topic through the lens of a Kafka parable.  This parable can be found at http://www.cwd.co.uk/babel/kafka.htm.  It is called the Pit of Babel and was published in 1917.

 

Our investigation of the resolution leads us through various possible interpretations of the way that the Kafka parable might make sense of it in our lives personally.

 

We then read the story of The Tower of Babel from Genesis, Chapter 11, Verses 1-9.

 

We argue that language and our relationship with it has been ruptured for some time making singular, univocal meanings impossible.

 

We then read the resolution and affirm it as a starting point for evaluating the way that debate operates due to the research burdens assumed under the resolution:

 

Resolved: That the United States Federal Government should establish an energy policy requiring a substantial reduction in the total non-governmental consumption of fossil fuels in the United States.

 

Next, we read from an interview with Victor Pelevin, Russian Author and winner of the Russian Little Booker Prize.  He argues that certain forms of making sense of the world are totalitarian, even when they educate us about our enslavement.  We relate this to the way debate currently works.

 

Pelevin, Victor.  Interview with Leo Kropywiansky in The Bomb, Spring 2002.  This is available at www.bombsite.com/pelevin/pelevin.html.

 

We then read from a book by Martin Amis that indicates that constant politicization is bad.  We relate this to the way that debate currently operates. 

 

Amis, Martin.  Koba The Dread: Laughter and the Twenty Million, 2002. p. 14.

 

Affirmative #2

 

We make very similar arguments to those above.

 

We argue that topic education and learning to become orators in debate is untrue.

 

We read a card from Donald Rumsfield about this. 

 

Rumsfield at a February 2002 DOD Newsbriefing.  Available at www.slate.com/id/2081042.

 

We argue that we do not gain new information from doing topic research.

Our next argument is that language is not always perhaps universally significant? 

 

Wallace.  Oblivion: Stories.  2004 p. 150-151.

 

We read the resolution and affirm it.   This is above in the first disclosure, I hope that’s sufficient.

 

Our advantage is Imagination.

 

We read evidence that is not tagged but is easy to access on the following websites.

 

1. www.parentingwithfamilyplay.com/sommersualts.html.

 

“The first . . . standard move.”

 

2. www.kinderstart.com:8080/kindertoday/1005119525/index_htm.

 

“Yesterday my daughter . . . down three steps.”

 

3. We also read evidence indicating that all your impacts are non-unique.

 

PJ O’Rourke.  All the Trouble in the World.  1993. P. 8.

 

“Yes, there is . . . on the beach.”  (Lots of words in between).

 

4. We conclude by saying that some things are impossible.

 

 

Richmond SS

 

Disclosures are below...

 

Sacred and Holy

 

Observation 1: The Sacred and the Holy

 

There is a distinction between sacred orders and holy communities within

theology.  Sacred orders seek to eradicate difference, while holy

communities open up their arms to the stranger.  Only by embracing holy

communities can we circumvent apocalypse.

 

Fasching, Professor of Religious Studies at the University of South

Florida, 1993

[Darrell, The Ethical Challenge of Auschwitz and Hiroshima, p. 5-8]

 

Observation 2: Evil Empire

 

Short explanation of why the fossil-fuel energy regime is a sacred

order.

 

The Atrocity of environmental racism-

 

Development projects get put in the backyards of the people with the

least ability to protest.  This forces minority populations to bear the

negative aspects of growth.  They have no ability to protest and no

political avenue to change the status quo.

 

Lao, Professor of Public and Environmental Affairs at Indiana

University, 2003

[Rhodes Edwardo, Environmental Justice in America: a New Paradigm,

p.6-7]

 

In the city of Richmond, the courts are overturning decisions that would

benefit these minority communities.  These decisions will bring back

institutional racism.

 

Delgado and Stefanic, University of Colorado Law School Professors, 1995

[Richard and Jean, "Symposium: Brown V. Board of Education After 40

Years: Confronting the Promise: The Social Construction of Brown V.

Board of Education: Law Reform and the Reconstructive Paradox." p. l/n]

 

Sovereignty is constituted in terms of "bare life."  Environmental

racism is framed within the concept of "bare life."  This makes genocide

inevitable.

 

Agamben, Professor of Philosophy at the University of Verona, 1995

[Giorgio, Homo Sacer: Sovereign Power and Bare Life, p. 8-11]

 

Thus,

Ryan and I stand resolved that the United States Federal Government

should establish an energy policy requiring a substantial reduction in

the total non-governmental consumption of fossil fuels in the United

States.

 

Our affirmative is a criticism of sacred communities and we strive to

create a holy community.  Love is the avenue by which we do this.  We'll

defend love is good.

 

Bending, School of Development Studies, 2002

[Tim, "Power Versus Love: The Production and Overcoming of Hierarchic

Repression," Alternatives 27, p. 135-137].

 

An example of where our affirmative approach has succeeded is the

instance of the U'wa people of Colombia vs. Petroleum Occidental.

 

We must include the stranger in our politics in order to strive for

utopian possibilities.  The only way to create a holy community is

through opening our arms to the stranger.

 

Fasching, Professor of Religious Studies at the University of South

Florida, 1993

[Darrell, The Ethical Challenge of Auschwitz and Hiroshima, p. 288-290]

 

A short explanation of the framework- we are an enunciative politics

based off the sermonic power of discourse.  Traditional views of fiat

are bad.

 

Clean Air Act

 

Environmental Racism is occurring in Texas City, Texas.

Timms 2000 (Ed, Oct. 3. "Toxic Traps: The Texas Problem" Dallas Morning

News)

 

Not only in Texas City, but all over, groups are being

disproportianatally affected by environmental racism.

Robert Bullard, National Black Environmental Justice Network and Prof.

Soc. At Clark Atlanta University. Ascribe Newswire. Sep. 4, 2001. "First

Kyoto, Now Durban: Diverse Groups Release Consensus Statement Exposing

Climate Injustice, Environmental Racism", lexis.

 

Environmental Racism occurs every day in Atlanta.

Kaiser 2001. (Beverly, "Environmental Injustice in Poor Neighborhoods"

The Baltimore Sun. July 29. lexis.)

 

A loophole in the Clean Air Act permits this environmental racism.

Caplan 2001. (Christina. "The Failure of Current Legal and Regulatory

Mechanisms to Control Interstate Ozone Transport: The need for new

national legislation." 28 Ecology L.Q. 169 Lexis.)

 

Thus the plan:

Resolved: that the United States Federal Government should establish an

energy policy of environmental justice requiring a substantial reduction

in the total non governmental consumption of fossil fuels in the united

states by eliminating the loopholes and exemptions in the 1990 clean air

act that have allowed fossil fuel-fired plants to evade the new source

performance standards under section III of the environmental regulation

required by the act. Enforcement guaranteed.

 

Current paradigm of environmentalism exacerbates environmental justices

by allowing industries to pollute in low minority areas.

Kasawan 1997. (Alice. "Environmental Justice: Bridging the Gap Between

Environmental Laws and 'Justice'." American University Law Review p. 47)

 

Thus, the environmental justice movement has emerged to combat the

injustices of environmental racism.

Siegel 2002 (Janet. "Negotiating for Environmental Justice: Turning

Polluters into 'Good Neighbors' Through Collaborative Bargaining." 10

NYU Envtl. L.J. 147. lexis)

 

We must make ethical decisions regarding the environment before the next

crisis occurs.

Low and Gleeson 1998 (Nicholos and Brendan. Justice, Society and Nature:

An exploration of political ecology.)

 

Environmental justice is needed to avert nuclear war, genocide, mass

starvation. Our deliberations over justice is the only way to break the

impasse between abundance, consumption, and extinction.

Low and Gleeson 98

 

We must challenge the exclusive modes of thought and assumptions that

typically encircle discussions of the environment.

Reinsborough 2004 (Patrick. "Decolonize the Revolutionary imagination:

Values Crisis, the Politics of Reality and Why there is going to be a

common-sense Revolution in this generation" In Globalize Liberation: How

to uproot the system and builda  better world (Ed. Solnit) p. 185

 

Biopolitics

 

We begin our examination of the resolution with a discussion of

biopolitics inclusive of the philosophical concepts of "homo sacer,"

bare life, and sovereign power which have been forwarded by Giorgio

Agamben, a professor of philosophy at the College International de

Philosophie in Paris.

 

Bare life is the life people experience when they have lost every

quality and every specific relation except for the pure fact of being

human.  Bare life is the life of the homo sacer, the sacred person.  The

sacred person is the one who can be killed and yet not sacrificed.   This

paradox is the foundation of the modern sovereign nation-state.

Ultimately, this is the status of the modern individual living in a

system that exerts control over the collective bare life of all

individuals.  We must envisage a society no longer based on the praxis

of bare life if we are to escape a system of politics that makes

genocide inevitable.

 

Agamben explicates in 1995...

Agamben, Professor of Philosophy at the University of Verona, 1995

[Giorgio, Homo Sacer: Sovereign Power and Bare Life, p. 8-11]

 

In our time a discomforting phenomenon has come about.  This phenomenon

is the fact that there are a growing number of individuals who are no

longer representable inside the nation-state, i.e. refugees.   Because

these individuals are now "denationalized" they no longer possess the

rights of the citizen and are doomed to death.  They are today's homo

sacer.

 

Agamben articulates in 1996...

Agamben, professor of philosophy at the College International de

Philosophie in Paris, 1996

[Giorgio, Means without End, p. 21-23]

 

In order to confront the proliferation of the homo sacer in our society

and to start the task of envisaging a society no longer founded on the

exceptio of bare life, we must build our political philosophy around the

figure of the refugee.

 

Agamben explains in 1996...

Agamben, professor of philosophy at the College International de

Philosophie in Paris, 1996

[Giorgio, Means without End, p. 16]

 

We now move to our genealogical investigation of the problem:

 

Gerrit Gong establishes a framework for this portion of the debate when

he states in 2001: "At the crucial nexus of each government's and each

country's political battle to determine how the past will shape the

future, remembering and forgetting issues will provide the vocabulary

for and the battlefield on which strategic alignments in the

contemporary world will turn." (Wash Quarterly, Spring V24 n2)

 

We begin with a genealogical discussion of the distinction between

individuals who are fully integrated citizens within the sovereign and

those individuals suffering from a bare life.  This distinction has been

manifested throughout history in various ways and has brought us to the

most recent manifestation of this distinction inherent in the

capitalist-democratic plan to eliminate the poor.

 

Agamben provides the following insight in 1996...

Agamben, professor of philosophy at the College International de

Philosophie in Paris, 1996

[Giorgio, Means without End, p. 30-35]

 

Our genealogy now moves to a discussion of the camp.  The camp, the

space that opens up when the state of exception starts to become the

rule, has manifest itself in different ways and different places

throughout history.  The camp in the United States has manifested itself

today in the outskirts of industrialized cities.  It has become the new

biopolitical nomos of the planet.

 

Agamben relates this development to us in 1996...

Agamben, professor of philosophy at the College International de

Philosophie in Paris, 1996

[Giorgio, Means without End, p. 39-45]

 

Our genealogy is a useful tool in developing a new approach to

modern-day politics, in which we can challenge the system of biopolitics

and rethink our notions of freedom.

 

Michael Clifford, an associate professor of philosophy with the

Institute for Humanities explains the importance of a genealogical

perspective in 2001...

Clifford, Associate Professor of Philosophy with the Institute for

Humanities, 2001

[Michael, Genealogy After Foucault, p. ___]

 

Ryan and I now find it useful to move toward an examination of a modern

day instances of the homo sacer present in our society.

 

The first example we provide is that of environmental racism occurring

towards disenfranchised, minority communities:

 

The fossil fuel energy-regime's continual push for development and

industrialization is causing widespread growth.  The problem with this

unchecked growth is that someone has to endure the cost of it.  Almost

always these development projects end up happening in the backyards of

the minority populations causing widespread damage to their habitat and

health problems.  The minority populations are unable to protest though

because of the lack of political and economic power they have in

governmental/nongovernmental agencies.  These individuals who are

victims of environmental racism are inherently included through their

exclusion.

 

Rhodes Lao, a professor of public and environmental affairs at Indiana

University, explicates in 2003...

Lao, Professor of Public and Environmental Affairs at Indiana

University, 2003

[Rhodes Edwardo, Environmental Justice in America: a New Paradigm,

p.6-7]

 

Environmentally racist activities that are orchestrated by the

fossil-fuel energy regime tend to ignore the increased health hazards,

decreased life expectancy, and rising infant mortality rates happening

across the country as a result of their exploitative practices.

 

Beverly Kaiser reports from personal experience in 2001...

Kaiser, The Baltimore Sun, 2001

[Beverly, "Environmental Injustice in Poor Neighborhoods," p. l/n]

 

It is utterly important that we recognize the individuals suffering from

environmental racism in these communities as refugees.  Be it, they are

not refugees in the sense that they have had to flee from their country

but they are internalized refugees forced into the ghettos and the slums

of the post-industrialized cities in the United States and Native

American reservations.  We must recognize this modern day homo sacer in

order to take the first step towards a society no longer envisaged on

the foundation of bare life.

 

Thus, we present the following advocacy:

 

Ryan and I stand resolved that the United States Federal Government

should establish an energy policy requiring a substantial reduction in

the total non-governmental consumption of fossil fuels in the United

States.

 

We would like to conclude our discussion of the bio-political control of

the fossil fuel industry with a discussion of our avenues for

resistance.

 

The way in which we propose an escape from bio-politics and the avenue

by which we take the first step to establishing a political community no

longer founded on bare life is by simply establishing a politics of

means without end.  We can no longer allow our political decisions to be

made with an end in mind.  Rather, we must engage in a politic open to

the community within the realm of pure means.

 

Agamben outlines this politic in 1996...

Agamben, professor of philosophy at the College International de

Philosophie in Paris, 1996

[Giorgio, Means without End, p. 39-45]

 

In conclusion, our specific way of establishing a politic of a means

without end is simply by engaging in an ethic of love.

 

Our affirmative is a criticism of the war on difference waged by the

sovereign against the homo sacer, in this case disenfranchised, minority

communities.  Only by having the audacity to reach out to the homo sacer

in a loving way and engaging in a love ethic will we be able to forge a

holy community.  We must be willing to listen to the homo sacer's

stories as they each have something to contribute to the ethical

imagination.

 

Love solves the hierarchies responsible for the energy-regime's war on

difference.  We must no longer stand for the cold-hearted mindset of

neo-liberal economics and globalization that justifies the exploitation

of the "Other" in the status quo.

 

It is important to note that in order for our struggle to work love must

not be conceived of in the light of eroticism so present in the status

quo, rather we must look at it as an imaginative recognition of

otherness and an emotional upheaval that must be included in our

revolutionary struggle.

 

Bending, School of Development Studies, 2002

[Tim, "Power Versus Love: The Production and Overcoming of Hierarchic

Repression," Alternatives 27, p. 135-137].

 

Nuclear Power

 

OBSERVATION ONE: INHERENCY

 

US energy policy excludes the development of nuclear power - this

ensures the inevitable disappearance of the US nuclear power industry.

 

Stephen Ansolabehere, professor of political Science, and John Deutch,

Institute professor of Chemistry at MIT explain in 2k3:

Ansolabehere and Deutch et al, professor of political science and

Institute Professor of Chemistry MIT, 2k3

(Stephen and John, The Future of Nuclear Power: An Interdisciplinary MIT

Study, DOA 12-20-2k4, p. http://web.mit.edu/nuclearpower/)

 

Furthermore, the status quo is hurling the US towards a collision course

that will devastate our economy and national security - nuclear power is

a promising alternative to this impasse, however, hurdles in the

development of new nuclear power plants makes it virtually impossible

that new plants will be built.

 

Tyler Ellis, graduate student of nuclear engineering and physics at MIT,

and Frederic Joliot, Otto Hahn fellow at Karlsruhe, Germany explains in

2k4:

(Tyler, "Recommendations for the increased utilization of nuclear power

in the US energy infrastructure," p.

http://www.wise-intern.org/journal04/WISE2004-TylerEllisFinalPaper.pdf )

 

OBSERVATION TWO: HARMS

 

Scenario 1: Water Wars

 

First, Water shortages plague almost every nation in the mid-east and

Africa-water conflict risks cutting off US oil supplies and throwing the

entire region into chaos and war.

 

Hoffman, Senior analyst DOE and IGAS advisor, 8-13-2k4

(Allan, "The Connection: Water and Energy Security," p.

http://www.iags.org/n0813043.htm)

 

There's a huge probability of Middle Eastern water wars that cause

violent conflict.

 

Agence France Press September 21, 2k2

 

Middle Eastern wars will go nuclear.

 

Steinbach, Center for Research on Globalization, 2k2

[John, March,

http://www.wagingpeace.org/articles/2002/03/00_steinbach_israeli-wmd.htm

]

 

And, Nuclear power enables cost competitive desalination and water

purification - critical to solve water shortages that risk political

stability and economic growth - plans model is the only hope.

 

NEI 2k4

("Electricity and the Nation's Future Prosperity: nuclear energy and the

nation's future prosperity."

http://www.nei.org/documents/Vision2020_Booklet.pdf)

 

Scenario 2: Russian Proliferation

 

The plan increases US and global demand for nuclear fuel --

supercharging conversion of Russia's nuclear warheads to civilian use.

 

William Timbers president and CEO of the USEC, explains in 2k3:

Timbers, President and Chief Executive Officer USEC Inc, 9-19-2k3

Opportunities, Delivered at the Carnegie Endowment for International

Peace Second International Non-Proliferation Conference Moscow, Russia.

P.

http://www.usec.com/v2001_02/Content/News/Speeches/09-19-03-CEIPMoscowRe

marks.pdf )

 

Furthermore, HEU swap is critical to US nuclear energy supply and

curbing Russian nuclear proliferation.

 

Thomas Neff, senior research at MIT's Center for International Studies

and co-founder of CTR program, explains in 2k1:

Neff senior researcher at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's

Center for International Studies in Cambridge and founder of US-Russia

HEU-LEU swap, 6-2k1

(Thomas, "Decision Time for the HEU Deal: US Security v. Private

Interests," Arms Control Today)

 

Even though the HEU-LEU program is a success the plan is critical to

speeding up transfer and down blending of Russian HEU - faster is

better.

 

Matthew Bunn, Senior Research Associate in the Project on Managing the

Atom at the Belfer Center for Science and International Affairs at the

John F. Kennedy School of Government, Harvard University, explains in

2k3:

Bunn, Senior Research Associate in the Project on Managing the Atom in

the Belfer Center for Science and International Affairs at Harvard

University's John F. Kennedy School of Government, 3-23-2k3

(Matthew, "US-Russia HEU Agreement," p.

http://www.nti.org/e_research/cnwm/reducing/heudeal.asp?print=true)

 

And, Russian nuclear stockpile is the greatest threat to national

security - the material or weapons could be stolen by wannabe weapon

states or terrorist organizations - congressional mandate to secure and

dispose of material is critical.

 

Howard Baker, former Chief of Staff to Reagan and Lloyd Cutler Special

counsel to Clinton and Carter, explains in 2k1:

Baker & Cutler, former Republican senate majority leader and Chief of

Staff to Ronald Reagan and special counsel to Carter and Clinton,

1-11-2k1

(Howard and Lloyd, "An Unacceptable Risk," Washington Post p.ln)

 

Furthermore, Al-Qaeda's thirst for loose Russian nuclear weapons risks

catastrophic consequences on American soil - an attack will decimate

millions.

 

Allison, director of the Belfer Center for Science and International

Affairs at Harvard University's Kennedy School of Government, 9-19-2k4

(Graham, "Preventable Nightmare," LA Times p.ln)

 

Finally, America will respond with relentless force leveling the Middle

East.

 

EASTERBROOK, SENIOR EDITOR NEW REPUBLIC, 11-1-2K3

(GREG, "INTERVIEW ON CNN," CNN P.LN)

 

Scenario 3: Space

 

Nuclear power provides cutting edge technology for space exploration

 

Nuclear News 1-2k4

("Special Report; 2003 ANS/ENS International Winter Meeting:

Commemorating and advancing the philosophy of Atoms for Peace," p.ln)

 

Space colonization leads to a transformation of consciousness that

solves war.

 

White, SETI Researcher, 1990

[Frank, "The SETI Factor," p. l/n]

 

Thus we offer the following plan:

 

The United States Federal Government should require a substantial

reduction in total nongovernmental consumption of fossil fuels in the

United States by mandating the development of a once-through fuel cycle

nuclear power plants to meet a 1000 GW increase in nuclear power by

2025. Congress will phase in nuclear power to offset consumption of

fossil fuels that is used for US electricity generation. Also, Congress

will encourage development of new plants by offering a first mover cost

tax credit for up to $200/kWe for the plant's construction. Funding and

enforcement guaranteed we will clarify.

 

OBSERVATION THREE: SOLVENCY

 

First, Nuclear power is critical to US national security, curbing global

warming, the US economy, grid-reliability, and energy security.

 

NEI 2k4

("Electricity and the Nation's Future Prosperity: nuclear energy and the

nation's future prosperity."

http://www.nei.org/documents/Vision2020_Booklet.pdf)

 

Furthermore, Government first-mover tax credit for new plant

construction ensures construction of new plants and successful

operation.

 

Ansolabehere and Deutch Same Qualifications, et al, professor of

political science and Institute Professor of Chemistry MIT, 2k3

(Stephen and John, The Future of Nuclear Power: An Interdisciplinary MIT

Study, DOA 12-20-2k4)

 

Additionally, our plan is critical to global adoption of nuclear power

and developing nations will benefit from increased nuclear power.

 

Ellis, Same Qualifications, graduate student of nuclear engineering and

physics at MIT, and Frederic Joliot/Otto Hahn fellow at Karlsruhe,

Germany Institute for Nuclear Science, 2k4

(Tyler, "Recommendations for the increased utilization of nuclear power

in the US energy infrastructure," p.

http://www.wise-intern.org/journal04/WISE2004-TylerEllisFinalPaper.pdf )

 

Nuclear power solves fossil fuel shortages and will evolve to overcome

safety issues, accidents, disposal issues, and cost.

CEA, Feb. 2k2 ("From Research to Industry" French Atomic Energy

Commission http://www.cea.fr/gb/institutions/nuclear_power.html)

Pragmatic action is critical and top down reform solves better then your

K does.

 

Zizek, Professor of Philosophy at the University of Ljubljana, 1998

[Slavoj, Law and the Postmodern Mind, p. 91-94]

unproductive.

 

Williams, Assistant Professor of Political Science at the University of

Southern Maine, and Krause, Professor of Political Science @ the

Graduate Institute of International Studies, 1997

[Michael and Keith, Critical Security Studies]

 

Role playing in debate is essential to break down assumptions, develop

critical thinking skills, and deconstruct statism.

 

Joyner, Professor of International Law @ Georgetown, 1999

[ILSA Journal of Int'l and Comparative Law, Spring, p. l/n]

Observation 1: The harm of the status quo

The current system of capitalism has led to tremendous improvement over previous
economic structures. However, this system is constantly breeding new antagonisms
that will be more devastating than anything we have ever seen.
Zizek 2000 (Contingency, Hegemony, Universality. Pg 222-225)

The end point of these antagonisms, unless directed at the elimination of
capitalism in favor of communism is that genocidal violence that results in mass
death. This has been gender modified.
Internationalist Perspective 2000 (capitalism and genocide #36 Spring.
http://www.geocities.com/wageslaves/capandgen.html)

Capitalist Militarism has trapped humanity in a cycle of perpetual war – the
terminal impact is total annihilation
Mezaros 03

Hence the Plan: The United States Federal Government should establish an energy
policy requiring a substantial reduction in the total non-governmental
consumption of fossil fuels in the United States by nationalizing the means of
fossil fuel electricity generation in the United States without compensation. We
reserve the right to clarify intent. Questions? Please ask, don’t assume.

Observation 2 is solvency

Thus the energy industry must be nationalized to prevent collapse of the
electricity supply and continued worker exploitation resulting from the
inevitable ups and downs of capitalism. It is the key demand for the working
Marxists.
The Militant 2001 (Nationalize the energy companies. Vol 65 No. 3
www.themilitant.com)

Nationalization of the energy industry is a key step towards the fight against
capitalism.
Militant 2003, Gildorf and Lamont in 2003 (Socialist Workers candidate for
governer says ‘nationalize the energy industry.” Vol 67/ No. 35
www.themilitant.com )

Thus the role of the ballot and plan is one of rupture. The endorsement of
relentless criticism and struggle even if apparently small provides the inertia
and push that leads to radical cascading
Kovel 02 (The Enemy of Nature P 224)

The primary task of today’s anti capitalism is to rupture the ideological
field which propagates capitalism as acceptable provided it is made acceptable
on some level. This is important because all actions occur in the background of
the current ideological field.
Zizek 03 (revolution at the gates Pg 169-170)

Observation 3 is the framework
OUR FRAMEWORK FOR THIS DEBATE IS THAT FIATED ACTION MUST BE EVALUATED WITHIN THE
CONTEXT OF THE DISCOURSE THAT ACCOMPANIES IT. OUR ZIZEK 2001 EVIDENCE REFERENCES
THAT EVERYTHING IS ACCOMPANIED WITH THE CURRENT IDEOLOGICAL STRUCTURE, WHICH IN
THIS CASE IS CAPITALIST. WE DEFEND THE PLAN’S PASSAGE BUT RECOGNIZE THAT THE
PLAN IS IMPOSSIBLE WITHIN THE CURRENT IDEOLOGICAL COORDINATE BECAUSE THE
CONSTITUTION PREVENTS SEIZURE OF PROPERTY AND BUSH HAS AN ATTITUDE PROBLEM
TOWARDS COMMUNISTS. WE WILL DEFEND THE PLAN BUT IT MUST OCCUR WITHIN A DIFFERENT
IDEOLOGICAL COORDINATE, THAT OF COMMUNISM. OUR DISCOURSE WILL FRAME THE POLICY
AND THUS THE WAY IT IS IMPLEMENTED. The same way that racist discourse which
accompanies the discussion of the war on terrorism is reflected in its
deployment and implementation is the same way that our plan will be deployed
within the concepts of anti capitalism. WE WILL NOW READ EVIDENCE WHICH
INDICATES A KEY ASPECT OF POLICY FORMULATION IS THE DISCOURSE THAT ACCOMPANIES
IT AND THE PSYCHOLOGICAL EFFECTS OF THE FRAMING OF AN ISSUE IMMEDIATELY CHANGE
THE PERCEPTION OF HOW THAT PLAN OPERATES.

We must unpack the assumptions that undergird the policy

Jochem, Center for Energy Policy and Economics in Zurich 01, (society, behavior
and climate change mitigation)

Additionally Communicative practices determine how action occurs through the use
of signifiers and triggers for the way we formulate thought, also known as
indexing.
The Frameworks institute 2003
(http://www.frameworksinsinstitute.org/strateicanalyis/perspectives.shtml)

Observation 4: The Transition
Difficulty of transition is not a reason to reject it
Kovel 02 (The enemy of nature pg 150-151)

Threats that our anti capitalism will result in an oppressive genocidal system
reminiscent of death camps an gulags present a prohibition on thinking that is
ultimately more totalitarian than totalitarianism itself.
Zizek 2001 (Did somebody says totalitarianism? Pg 3-4)

Claims that we don’t outline the world after capitalism or the transition is
irrelevant. The key move is to begin to create the new world through moves like
the affirmative. Your stance merely prevents us from imagining a different
world, forcing us to resort to shallow reforms that merely sustain capitalism
and accepts that our impacts are inevitable
Zizek 2000 (contingency, hegemony universality pg 231)

Capitalism is the most extreme form of bio-politics resulting in mass death
International Perspectives 2000 (same source as above)

Your fear of lost freedom in an anti capitalist society is unfounded cynical
ideology. It ignores the fact our current system is less than democratic because
it excludes the possibility of radical change. The freedom to choose a
potentially authoritarian system represents the ultimate of freedom It is
obvious that leaders necessary are necessary to create sustained change,
Venezuela proves.
Zizek 2001 (Did somebody says totalitarianism? Pg 246-247)

 

Samford AW

 

This is the most recent version of our affirmative.

In responce to critical fuel shortages the Office of Price
administration was created to oversee the rational of Gasoline and other
fuel oil products. Fox and German 04
www.users.snip.net%ecgfl72/DC_Station/chapter9.html

Framework
Aristotle laid out three catagories of rhetoric, Deliberative, forensic
and epideictic. Our arguemnt is that debate is to dependant on
deliberative rhetoric.  The use of deliberative debate without a focus
on the past is facing the future blind.  Discussing the past withing a
debate framework offcers 3 advantages.
First removed by time it enables us to see events more clearly and
eveluate success and failure Stearns, Peter 2/24/03
www.theaha.org/pubs/stearns.html

Secondly, It increases teh value of delibrative debate by providing
insight into the world of future action. The status quo debate framework
relies of simply causation that are simplistic in the extreme and erase
the fundamental complexities in world politics. Forensic debate allows
us to discuss multiple causation Marcus Auerlias around 150 AD
www.itasca.com.schools/peacock/7team/peel/whyhist.html

Finially, it allows us to discuss the context in which the rez was
dreamed into existance. Not looking to the past it to be willfully
ignorant. Our frameowkr provides meaningfull education.

Thus, we offer the following
The United States Federal Governemnt should, through congressional
legislation establish and energy policy requiring a substantial
reduction in the total non governmental consumptions of fossil fuels in
the united states by implementing a system of gasoline rationing the the
Office of Price administration and specified in the fox and german
evidance, our intent is to affirm the gas rationing act of 1941 we
reserce the right to clarify.

Gas Rationing was key the the Us's ability to compensate for smassive
rubber shortages Bokel and Clark 97, John and Rolf "The Big "L" American
Logistics in World War II" ed Alan Gropman www.
ibiblio.org/hyperwar/USA/BIgL/BIgl-2.html

Rubber was critical to the trucks underpinning the US Supply lines, w/o
theese supplies the us campaign would have ended in miserable failure

Barry Dysart 97 "The Big "L" American Logistics in World War II" ed Alan
Gropman www. ibiblio.org/hyperwar/USA/BIgL/BIgl-2.html

The Nazi plans of genocide were far from complete Nazi victory would
have ensured the death of the slavic peoples through the use of disease,
deportation, and murder. 40 millions lives were at stake here alone.
Rummer 93 Democide: NAzi Genocide and Mass Murder chp1 "Most Nazi's were
absolute racists... and liver disease"

The occupation stratagies of japan were contigent on mass drugging of
the chinese population to make it docile while killing millions.
International Committee for Reconciliation and Justice 04
www.skycitygallery.com/japan/japan.html

The second world war was a desperate struggle, the state of crisis was
unimaginable prior to US entry into the war, Britain stood valiantly but
realistically futiely in the face of a germans onslaught, a combitation
of Russian attrition and the combined British and American, Canadian

“President Bush signed… to local communities.”

“The National Academy of Sciences… of implementation is zero.”

THE DOMESTIC AVIATION INDUSTRY IS COLLAPSING, AND RISING FUEL COSTS ARE THE REASON. EVEN IF GROWTH IN TRAVEL RETURNS, FUEL INEFFICIENCY WILL DOOM THE INDUSTRY.

“As to the financial… environment since 2001.”

THE FEDERAL AVIATION ADMINISTRATION SHOULD ESTABLISH AN AUCTIONED PERMIT TRADING SYSTEM COMPATIBLE WITH PROPOSED EUROPEAN UNION PERMIT TRADING SYSTEMS. 

 

AN AVIATION TRADING SYSTEM BASED ON FUEL EFFICIENCY IS ECONOMICALLY VIABLE AND WILL ALLOW FOR INDUSTRY GROWTH BY FORCING DEVELOPMENT OF MORE FUEL EFFICIENT TECHNOLOGY.

Affirmative

Observation 1:  Inherency-
Despite high performance levels, new nuclear plant construction is vital to meet growing demand.
Travers, Exec Dir. Of Ops @NRC, 2004 [William D, Hearing of the Energy Subcommittee of the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee, March 4]

Congress slashed the budget for the DOE’s Nuclear Power 2010 Initiative
Foster Electric Report June 23, 2004 [Report No. 361; Pg. 15]

Plan:  The United States Federal Government should establish an energy policy requiring a substantial reduction in total non-governmental consumption of fossil fuels in the United States by mandating that 30% of total non-governmental electrical generation from fossil fuels be replaced by nuclear power by 2020 and 50% by 2050.

Enforcement through the Nuclear Power 2010 Initiative and the phase-out of coal-fired plants exempted from Clean Air Act regulations.

Adv. 1:  Russian Relations
Current oil focus crowds out joint-development on nuclear power.
Victor, director of the Program on Energy and Sustainable Development at Stanford, and Victor, research associate in dept. of Economics at Yale, 2003. [David and Nadejda, Foreign Affairs, March-April]

US-Russian cooperation on nuclear power spurs a global alliance against fissile material spread.
Graham Allison, Foreign Affairs, Jan – Feb 2004

US-Russian relations are key to stopping Iran Proliferation
Allison (same source)

Iran Proliferation triggers nuclear war in the Middle East
John Yaukey, Gannet News Service, Oct 8 2003 “Four Nations Pose Biggest Deadly Weapons Risk.”

US-Russian relations averts war in Eurasia
Robert Legvold 2003 [The National Interest, Winter, “All the Way:  Crafting a US-Russian Alliance.”]

Adv. 2:  Fissile Material
Fissile Material spread will skyrocket without the promotion of fuel-cycle safety
The New York Times, Sept. 5, 2004 [Graham T. Allison, Prof of Government and Director of the Belfer Center for Science and International Affairs]

Cooperation on nuclear power leads to cooperation on waste disposal
Victor and Victor 2003 (above)

Proliferation will be rampant absent US promotion of safeguards and nuclear power leadership.
Domenici, Republican New Mexico Senator 1998 [Issues in Science and Technology, “Future Perspectives on Nuclear Issues.”]

Widespread prolif guarantees escalation and use.
Utgoff 2002 [Victor, Survival, vol. 44 Issue 2, summer]

Nuclear power is responsible for the only substantial reduction in fossil fuel consumption

Zero risk of leakage from waste
Bernard L Cohen, Prof of Physics at U. of Penn., Interdisciplinary Science Reviews, “Perspectives on High Level Waste Disposal Problem”  Sept. 1998

UMKC CG WEATHERIZATION 1AC

 

Observation 1- Despite the success of the Low Income Home Energy Assistance and Weatherization assistance Programs, both continue to be drastically underfunded

PLAN:  THE UNITED STATES FEDERAL GOVERNMENT SHOULD ESTABLISH AN ENERGY POLICY TO SUBSTANTIALLY REDUCE TOTAL NON-GOVERNMENTAL CONSUMPTION OF FOSSIL FUELS BY REQUIRING WEATHERIZATION OF ALL ELIGIBLE HOUSEHOLDS UNER LOW INCOME HOME ENERGY ASSISTANCE PROGRAM AND WEATHERIZATION ASSISTANCE PROGRAM GUIDELINES.  FUNDING AND ENFORCEMENT THROUGH NORMAL MEANS.  ASK AND WE WILL ANSWER.

 

Advantage is POVERTY

 

A)  First, weatherization mechanisms are the fastest way to reverse the causes of poverty

 

BRADLEY IN 2K4 (David, Executive Director of National Community Action Foundation, Statement to the subcommittee on Interior Related Agencies House Committee on Appropriations www.ncaf.org)

 

Additionally, lack of weatherization causes homelessness and increases the drop out rate perpetuating the cycle of poverty

And inability to pay utility bills robs low income families of dignity creating a permanent underclass

 

GONZALES IN 94 (Helen, Staff Attorney National Consumer Law Center, Federal Document Clearing House Congressional Testimony, March 23, LN)

NLIEC IN 2K1 (The Cold Hard Facts www.nationalfuelfunds.org/cold.pdf)

We feel it is important to acknowledge another perspective.  This is the perspective that the United States Federal Government should establish an energy policy requiring a substantial reduction in total non-governmental consumption of fossil fuels by banning the non-governmental consumption of oil in the United States.

 

Our rhetorical strategy motivates action.
