The rhetoric of the oil companies is the rhetoric of the sovereign.  This rhetoric dominates other rhetoric in an attempt to control gatekeeping, the contingency of the world.  The approach of the affirmative is to erode the sovereign rhetoric by displaying it next to that which is anti-thetical to its existence.

Miguel de Larrinaga 2000, (Re)Politicizing the Discourse: Globalization is a S(h)ell Game, Alternatives: Social Transformation and Humane Governance, Apr-June Vol. 25, Issue 2.

“Some campaigning groups …conditions of estrangement.”

USC -- Alll

 

All of our affirmatives have the same plan text –

 

The United States Congress should substantially reduce total non-governmental consumption of fossil fuels by establishing a National Renewable Portfolio Standard, that requires no more than eighty percent of the United State’s electricity production, be generated with fossil fuels by the year 2020.

 

We have mixed and matched our advantages based on particular debates.  Possible advantages include

 

Competitiveness

Environmental Leadership / Soft Power

Hydrogen

Coal / Appalachia

Deliberative Democracy

 

I have included the exact outlines of some of the configurations we have read so far.

 

 


Leadership / Competitiveness 1AC

 

Contention One – The Loss of American prestige

 

Instead of the United States being at the forefront of renewable energy development, it has taken a back seat to other international efforts. Germany is now leading the global transition towards renewable energy.

Robert Coller, San Francisco Chronicle, 12-20-2004

 “Set in the heart of Bavarian farmland, the 30-acre facility went online earlier … what doesn't. Yet even Germany's chief booster of renewable energy warns that the lessons are mixed.”

 

And, the economical value of renewable energy makes a transition away from carbon-based fuels inevitable

Roberts – writes about the energy industry for Harper's Magazine – 2004 (Paul, The End of Oil, p.200-201)

 

Finally, the status quo is becoming increasing reliant on natural gas for its electric power – this will inevitably result in massive price volatility and an economic collapse

Roberts – writes about the energy industry for Harper's Magazine – 2004 (Paul, The End of Oil, p.183)

 

Contention Two – Speaking softly while carrying a Big Stick

Kyoto’s entry-into-force makes domestic climate action inevitable. Enacting domestic legislation to promote renewables demonstrates a strong commitment to environmental protect that is essential to restore collapse US diplomatic credibility

Nigel Purvis, Scholar at the Brookings Institute, International Herald Tribune, 12-15-2004

 “After seven years in critical condition, the Kyoto global warming treaty … of the political and economic risks to the United States of continued inaction.”

 

Even though the US remains a superpower, its apathetic stance toward environmental protections is undercutting its international diplomatic capital.  Our commitment to the reduction of pollution is critical to strengthening out environmental leadership

Walter – chief economist at Deutsche Bank Group – 8-28-2002 (Norbert, New York Times, “An American Abdication,” p.A19)

 “At present there is much talk about the unparalleled strength of the United States on the … to acknowledge the very real concerns of many people about global environmental issues.”

 

And, Enactment of a Federal RPS is essential to bolstering our credibility – the international community is looking for any hint of change in US Climate Policy

Irish Times, 12-7-2004

 “UN: A UN conference on climate change opened yesterday with delegates … estimates of a sharp rise in temperatures if emissions are not curbed.”

 

Additionally, increase US/European cooperation is critical to counter terrorism and rogue nuclear threats – US leadership is only effective when combined with European Power

Joseph Nye, Dean of the Kennedy School of Government, International Herald Tribune, 11-14-2004

 “Finally, on the bottom board are transnational issues that cross borders outside … in Europe. That is why President Bush would be wise to act now.”

 

And, unchecked terrorism makes extinction inevitable

Alexander – professor and director of the Inter-University for Terrorism Studies in Israel and the United States – 8-28-2003 (Yonah, Washington Times, “Terrorism Myths and Realities,” p.A20)

 “Last week's brutal suicide bombings in Baghdad and …nuclear and cyber] with its serious implications concerning national, regional and global security concerns.”

 

Contention Three – Economic Competitiveness

Currently, US companies will be locked out of a nine trillion dollar market because of Kyoto’s entry into force.

Inter Press Service, “Environment: US firms see profit in carbon emissions market,” 12-6-2004

 “Frustrated by inaction in Washington, many local …We have buyers and sellers.. The issue becomes: what's it going to cost?"

 

And, absent federal leadership, states will implement a patchwork of conflicting regulations, crushing competitiveness.

Richard Stavros, Public Utilities Fortnightly, “Playing Russian roulette?”, No. 11, Vol. 142; Pg. 4, 11-1-2004

 “It could mark the biggest bungle of the last two a…sector could find itself held hostage to world opinion. “

 


Leadership / Competitiveness 1AC

 

Additionally, the failure to compete in this emerging renewables market will cripple U.S. economic and technological leadership

Hendricks – Executive Director of the Apollo Alliance – 2-12-2004 (Bracken, FDCH Congressional Testimony, Subcommittee on Energy and Mineral Resources Committee on House Resources, “Rising Price of Natural Gas,” Lexis-Nexis Universe)

 “Americans have always pulled together in tough times…, and sustaining American global economic and technological leadership.”

 

And. a 20% RPS will create a predictable and broad market for renewable energy in the U.S. – creating jobs at home and export opportunities abroad, ensuring competitiveness

Kammen – Professor of Energy and Society Director at the Renewable and Appropriate Energy Laboratory (RAEL) Energy and Resources Group – 7-11-2001 (Daniel, FDCH Congressional Testimony, “Energy Tax Incentives,” Lexis-Nexis Universe)

4) A federal Renewable Portfolio Standard (RPS) to help build renewable energy markets

“The RPS is a renewable energy content standard, akin … and set a clear target for industry research, development, and market growth 27 . “

 

Not only is the energy sector a beacon of economic growth, but it’s also critical to  our overall technological and industrial leadership

Kammen – Professor of Energy and Society Director at the Renewable and Appropriate Energy Laboratory (RAEL) Energy and Resources Group – 7-11-2001 (Daniel, FDCH Congressional Testimony, “Energy Tax Incentives,” Lexis-Nexis Universe)

“As a nation we are ignoring the importance of maintaining leadership … political climate for clean energy systems in order to reassert our leadership in this vital area.”

 

And, US economic competitiveness and technological leadership are crucial to America’s global primacy and economic prosperity.

Adam Segal, Maurice R. Greenberg Senior Fellow in China Studies at the Council on Foreign Relations and the author of Digital Dragon: High Technology Enterprises in China, Foreign Affairs, “Is America Losing Its Edge?” November/December 2004

 “The United States' global primacy depends in large part … the United States must get better at fostering technological entrepreneurship at home.”

 

Finally, they can’t win that a decline in U.S. hegemony is good.  A U.S. withdrawal will not result in a multipolar world, but rather an apolar world that will be filled with economic stagnation, an increase in AIDs and nuclear omnicide

Niall Ferguson, Foreign Policy Analyst, Foreign Policy “A World Without Power,” Washington: Jul/Aug 2004, Iss.143 pg. 32

 

“So what is left? Waning empires. Religious revivals. Incipient anarchy. … dangerous forces than rival great powers would benefit from such a not-so-new world disorder.”

 

Thus we present the following plan –

The United States Congress should substantially reduce total non-governmental consumption of fossil fuels by establishing a National Renewable Portfolio Standard, that requires no more than eighty percent of the United State’s current amount of electricity production, be generated with fossil fuels by the year 2020.

Contention Four – Solvency

 

A renewable Energy Portfolio that requires 20% of U.S. Electricity be supplied with renewable energy by 2020 is both feasible and affordable

Union of concerned Scientists 11-7-2001 (www.ucsusa.org/documents/ffs_rps_faq.pdf)

 

A National RPS will diversify U.S. electricity generation, expand renewable energy development throughout the nation and lower natural gas prices without significantly increasing electricity prices

Clemmer et. Al. 1999

(Steven L, Alan Nogee, “A powerful Opportunity:  Making renewable electricity the standard”, Union of Concerned Scientists)

 

In addition to promoting the development of renewable energy across the country, a national RPS will also create domestic jobs and export opportunities abroad.  Individual state will fail for a number of reasons

Herzgog, dec 2001 (“Renewables Energy: A viable choice” www.finadarticles .com)

 

A National RPS will significantly reduce pricea volatility in the electricity market

Drabick, oct 2003

{J.R., “State policies set mandates for Renewables Energy”. Vol. 44, no. 10, pg. 38)

 


Hydrogen 1AC

 

Contention One – The Drive for Fossil Fuels

 

All current methods of hydrogen fuel production will fail; we need to develop new techniques for the development of pure hydrogen

U.S. DOE Hydrogen Program Review, “Efficient Hydrogen Production Using Enzymes of the Pentose Phosphate Pathway,” 2002

http://www.eere.energy.gov/hydrogenandfuelcells/pdfs/32405a6.pdf.

“The currently used commercial methods for the production of hydrogen … as well as hydrogen, a gas stream less suitable for hydrogen fuel cells (Leslie, 1997).”

 

And, United States current drive to sustain and stabilize our dependence on fossil fuel has led to an aggressive military mindset that is willing to destroy all in the name of military and economic imperative

Robert Freeman, Writer – Economics and Education, Common Dreams, “Will the End of Oil Mean the End of America,” 3-1-2004

http://www.commondreams.org/views04/0301-12.htm

“America has its own hand in a coconut, one that may doom it just … in our shared global lifeboat that are also threatened by the end of oil.

 

And, absent a shift, society will continue to commit to the collective suicide of the other. This will cause us to exterminate ourselves in the name of our own survival.

Boaventura de Sousa Santos, Social theorist and the director of the Center for Social Studies at the University of Coimbra, 2003 Collective Suicide” Bad Subjects Issue 63, April 2003, Original in Portuguese, Translation by Jean Burrows http://eserver.org/bs/63/santos.html

“According to Franz Hinkelammert, the West has repeatedly been under the illusion …100 billion dollars, enough to pay the health costs of the world's poorest countries for four years.”

 

Thus we present the following plan –

The United States Congress should substantially reduce total non-governmental consumption of fossil fuels by establishing a National Renewable Portfolio Standard, that requires no more than eighty percent of the United State’s electricity production, be generated with fossil fuels by the year 2020.

 

Contention Two – Solvency

First, an RPS would spur the development of renewable electricity generation, paving the way for large-scale hydrogen production

Obadiah Bartholomy, Institute of Transportation Studies, “Wind Electricity for Hydrogen, an Assessment of  California Resource Potential, and Hurdles for Implementation,”  August 2004

http://www.its.ucdavis.edu/Hydrogen/Obadiah_Docs/Thesis_Proposal.doc

“The state of California possesses vast renewable resource potential … market for the wind resource may allow projects which were not thought feasible previously to proceed.”

 

And, Wind can be used to power hydrogen fuel cells – this can be used to replace many uses of fossil fuels

The Electricity Forum – August 2003 (“Wind energy could fuel future power needs,” http://www.electricityforum.com/news/aug03/windenergy.html, Downloaded on 10-4-2004)

“Wind power is now a viable, robust and fast-growing…will shape not only the energy sector of the global economy, but the global economy itself.”

 

Additionally, the Federal Government is necessary – any other actor will fail because of costs associated with transmissions lines required for renewable energy generation, specifically wind power

Sam Schoofs, Calvin College, 2004 WISE Intern, “A Federal Renewable Portfolio Standard: Policy Analysis and Proposal,” 8-6-2004

“The main technological question surrounding a federal RPS is whether or … to make sure proper local and state procedures have been followed. “

 

Consequently, the transition away from an fossil fuel dominated economy would end imperialist efforts and transform our relationship with nature

Jeremy Rifkin founder and president of The Foundation on Economic Trends. 2002

The Hydrogen Economy p.10-12

“A decentralized hydrogen-energy requiem offers the hope…in the hydrogen age”

 

Hydrogen 1AC

 

And, the way we approach our energy resources influences our historical perception of security. The existing geography of nation-states is a byproduct of the globalized oil economy. This has led to the centralization of authority which is capable of exterminating both itself and others in attempts to secure its own survival. The hydrogen economy is the best hope for changing this view of security.

Jeremy Rifkin founder and president of The Foundation on Economic Trends. 2002

The Hydrogen Economy p.244-250

“The hydrogen economy is going to bring…rethink our ideas about security

 

Additionally, the 1AC initiates a relationship with nature capable of prioritizing our politics towards a respect for life.  This serves as an invitation for respect as the central motivator for politics.

Val Plumwood, ARC Fellow @ the University of Sidney, Beneath the Surface 2000 pg 68-70

 

Finally, taking action to change the direction of the United State’s Energy Policy is beneficial – The plan is the only way to transition away from the current economic view of energy policy to a more sustainable energy future, where we take a more ecocentric, than anthropocentric approach to supplying energy.

Robert L. Stivers, Professor at Pacific Lutheran University's  Department of Religion,  “Sustainable Energy Futures: Economic and Ecological Ramifications of U.S. Energy Policy,” This article comes from a new casebook on environmental ethics co-authored with James Martin Schramm and forthcoming from Orbis Books in 2004 http://www.elca.org/jle/articles/contemporary_issues/health/article.stivers_robert_pf.html

“[1] Two primary visions of the future vie with each other to … go a long way to shape society and culture for years to come. These choices are critical.”

 


Hydrogen / Deliberative Democracy 1AC

 

Contention One – The Drive for Fossil Fuels

 

United States current drive to sustain and stabilize our dependence on fossil fuel has led to an aggressive military mindset that is willing to destroy all in the name of military and economic imperative

Robert Freeman, Writer – Economics and Education, Common Dreams, “Will the End of Oil Mean the End of America,” 3-1-2004

http://www.commondreams.org/views04/0301-12.htm

 “America has its own hand in a coconut… threatened by the end of oil. “

 

And, absent a shift, society will continue to commit to the collective suicide of the other. This will cause us to exterminate ourselves in the name of our own survival.

Boaventura de Sousa Santos, Social theorist and the director of the Center for Social Studies at the University of Coimbra, 2003 Collective Suicide” Bad Subjects Issue 63, April 2003, Original in Portuguese, Translation by Jean Burrows http://eserver.org/bs/63/santos.html

 “According to Franz Hinkelammert, the West … to pay the health costs of the world's poorest countries for four years.”

 

Thus we present the following plan –

The United States Congress should substantially reduce total non-governmental consumption of fossil fuels by establishing a National Renewable Portfolio Standard, that requires no more than eighty percent of the United States electricity production, be generated with fossil fuels by the year 2020.

 

Contention Two – Solvency

 

First, an RPS would spur the development of renewable electricity generation, paving the way for large-scale hydrogen production

Obadiah Bartholomy, Institute of Transportation Studies, “Wind Electricity for Hydrogen, an Assessment of  California Resource Potential, and Hurdles for Implementation,”  August 2004

http://www.its.ucdavis.edu/Hydrogen/Obadiah_Docs/Thesis_Proposal.doc

 “The state of California possesses vast renewable resource … market for the wind resource may allow projects which were not thought feasible previously to proceed.”

 

Consequently, the transition away from an fossil fuel dominated economy would end imperialist efforts and transform our relationship with nature

Jeremy Rifkin founder and president of The Foundation on Economic Trends. 2002

The Hydrogen Economy p.10-12

 

And, the way we approach our energy resources influences our historical perception of security. The existing geography of nation-states is a byproduct of the globalized oil economy. This has led to the centralization of authority which is capable of exterminating both itself and others in attempts to secure its own survival. The hydrogen economy is the best hope for changing this view of security.

Jeremy Rifkin founder and president of The Foundation on Economic Trends. 2002

The Hydrogen Economy p.242

 

Finally, taking action to change the direction of the United State’s Energy Policy is beneficial – The plan is the only way to transition away from the current economic view of energy policy to a more sustainable energy future, where we take a more ecocentric, than anthropocentric approach to supplying energy.

Robert L. Stivers, Professor at Pacific Lutheran University's  Department of Religion,  “Sustainable Energy Futures: Economic and Ecological Ramifications of U.S. Energy Policy,” This article comes from a new casebook on environmental ethics co-authored with James Martin Schramm and forthcoming from Orbis Books in 2004 http://www.elca.org/jle/articles/contemporary_issues/health/article.stivers_robert_pf.html

 “[1] Two primary visions of the future vie …and culture for years to come. These choices are critical. “

 

 


Hydrogen / Deliberative Democracy 1AC

 

Contention 3 – Deliberative Democracy

 

We believe the framework for the debate should be one of deliberative democracy. The role of the ballot in this debate is to decide which team advanced the most accessible, inclusive, and legitimate arguments for a specific government course of action. The benefit of our approach is its empowering vision of agency.

Guttmann, President of the University of Pennsylvania, and Thompson, Alfred North Whitehead Professor of Political Philosophy at Harvard University, 2004

[Amy and Dennis, Why Deliberative Democracy?, p. 3-7]

“Most fundamentally, deliberative democracy affirms …; what kinds of deliberative democracy are justifiable; and how its critics can be answered.”

 

Deliberative Democracy is a particularly appropriate as a framework to engage environmental policy-making. The net benefit of this framework for debate is the expansion of Green Citizenship. It is this citizenship that is central to successful embrace of sustainable relations with the environment.

Barry, lecturer in the Department of Politics at Keele University, 1999

[John, Rethinking Green Politics, p. 230-231]

The introduction of communicative rationality to the co-… young and old in support of 'green' or 'ecological' causes and attitudes.

 

Our framework of deliberative democracy is also necessary to flip the switch from a consumption-based relationship with the environment to an environmentally responsible citizenry

Barry, lecturer in the Department of Politics at Keele University, 1999

[John, Rethinking Green Politics, p. 218-219]

“The advantages of a deliberative approach can be seen by looking at the .. pertaining to them can and ought to be raised.”

 

We don’t presume to act as representatives in congress – our claim is that this debate is a local site of argumentative expression for the interests of citizens in environmental policymaking. Such avenues of public expression of interest are necessary to an informed, cooperative public on environmental questions.

Barry, lecturer in the Department of Politics at Keele University, 1999

[John, Rethinking Green Politics, p. 229-230]

“It is also related to the claims of the last section where green … democracy is the consideration of the interests of affected others.”

 

Viewing debate as a local site of democratic deliberation suggests the function of the round is social learning about our ability to function as citizens. This approach is the best pedagogic view of debate.

Barry, lecturer in the Department of Politics at Keele University, 1999

[John, Rethinking Green Politics, p. 229]

“The green claim to a principled as opposed to an instrumental adherence to democracy … as the ecological restructuring of the state and economy.”

 

 


Coal / Deliberative Democracy 1AC

 

Contention 1 is Coal Dependency

 

Coal-fired power plants are the largest source of toxic air pollution in the country – new clean coal initiatives won’t correct the problem

Becker – Director of The Sierra Club's Global Warming and Energy Program – 5-14-2001 (Dan, Common Dreams, “Coal Simply Doesn't Belong in a Clean Energy Future,” www.commondreams.org/views01/0514-03.htm, Downloaded on 11-1-2004)

“As Americans, we face a slew of choices… doesn't belong in a clean energy future.”

 

In addition,  the current energy policy is pushing the Appalachian region to the brink of environmental and economic collapse.  The current reliance on coal production and use is destroying the economic fabric of these communities and undermining productive forms of civic participation.  Unfortunately, Bush’s Clean Coal proposal will not stop the coal industry from pillaging Appalachia.

Hamline Journal of Public Law & Policy – Spring 2004 (Hannha C. Halbert – Juris Doctorate candidate, May 2006, “From Picket Line to Courtroom: The Changing Forum for Regional Resistance, Environmental Reform and Policy Change in Appalachia,” 25 Hamline J. Pub. L. & Pol'y 375)

“I. Introduction

As the majority of the world advocates for more… The Clean Coal initiative does neither.”

 

The harms are certain to intensify as the U.S. increases its reliance on coal

Herald-Dispatch – 8-11-2004 (Pamela Brogan and Jean Tarbett, “Coal-fired Plants Raise Health Concerns,” www.herald-dispatch.com/2004/August/11/LNspot.htm, Downloaded on 11-1-2004)

“WASHINGTON -- Across the country… health and our children’s health."

 

There is also a dark economic side to the story of Appalachia – this region and other coal producing areas have literally been turned into economic colonies to help power and sustain higher standards of living in other parts of the country

Davis – Dean of Students and Assistant Professor at the Appalachian School of Law – June 2002 (Wendy B., American University Law Review, “Out of the Black Hole: Reclaiming the Crown of King Coal,” 51 Am. U.L. Rev. 905)

“To encourage the development of the great natural… sapping its mineral and timber wealth.”

 

While President Bush continues to proclaim that his economic programs are expanding growth and reducing unemployment, many, especially those in Appalachia, are forced to live in poverty and inhumane conditions.  Ironically, it is the young people from Appalachia that are the first to respond when our nation goes to war.   Communities like these should be the center of new investment in renewable energy.

Jesse Jackson – 6-8-2004 (Chicago Sun Times, “What Appalachia says about U.S.,” www.suntimes.com/output/jesse/cst-edt-jesse08.html, Downloaded 10-9-2004)

“The hills of Appalachia have a hard truth about them… It is time for America to listen.”

 

This problem of economic exploitation is a product of current politics that strips away our citizenship in the quest to create perfect consumers, rather than concerned citizens. It is imperative that we act to combat this debilitating conception of agency.

Partridge, Co-Editor, 10-7-2003

[Ernest, www.crisispapers.org, “Consumer or Citizen?”, Originally in The Online Gadfly, April 2004]

“What is this country coming to?... ourselves and to our republic.”

 

Thus we present the following proposal:

The United States Congress should substantially reduce total non-governmental consumption of fossil fuels by establishing a National Renewable Portfolio Standard that requires no more than eighty percent of United States electricity be supplied with fossil fuels by the year 2020.

 

 


Coal / Deliberative Democracy 1AC

 

Contention 2 – Expanding Renewable Energy is Necessary to Undermine King Coal

 

An RPS is necessary to displace fossil-fired generation and economically empower local communities

Bernow, et. al – Vice Pres. of Tellus Institute and Dir. of it’s Energy and Environment Program – May 1997 (Stephen Bernow, Bill Dougherty – an engineer in the energy and environment program at Tellus, and Max Duckworth – a research associate in the electricity and energy and environment programs at Tellus, Electricity Journal, “Quantifying the Impacts of a National, Tradable Renewables Portfolio Standard,” Lexis-Nexis Universe)

“With its inclusion in Rep. Schaefer's Electricity Consumers' Power… least administrative oversight.”

 

Expanding renewable energy will reduce reliance on deadly coal

Larsen – Earth Policy Institute – 8-24-2004 (Janet, “Coal Takes Heavy Human: Some 25,100 U.S. Deaths from Coal Use Largely

Preventable,” www.earth-policy.org/Updates/Update42.htm, Downloaded on 11-1-2004)

“Using coal, a hazardous nineteenth-century fuel… health care bill of over $160 billion.”

 

Expanding renewable energy empowers individuals to make decisions regarding their energy use

Bull & Billman – Associate Director for Science and Technology and Senior Planner at the National Renewable Energy Laboratory – Winter 2000 (Stanley R. Bull and Lynn L. Billman, The Washington Quarterly, “Renewable Energy: Ready to Meet Its Promise?” vol. 23, no. 1, p.229)

“A Stronger Farm Economy

The rural economy in the United States remains… information services, and entertainment.”

 

Renewable energy can also economically empower coal producing communities that are experiencing rampant poverty

Stockman – Organizer with the Ohio Valley Environmental Coalition – 3-15-2001 (Vivian, TomPaine.com, “Clean Coal: The Mother of all Oxymorons Billions More for Coal While Alternatives Languish,” www.mindfully.org/Energy/Clean-Coal-Oxymoron.htm, Downloaded on 12-6-2004)

“Coal's Dirty Habits

In the latest incoming salvos from the Coal PR machine… The answer is blowing in the wind.”

 

Political action by citizens – rather than consumers – is necessary to meaningfully reduce consumption.  The political process must be reclaimed from the constraining influence of corporations to promote responsible citizenship.

Hannis – 1998 (Michael, “The Myth Of Green Consumerism; Consumption, Community And Free Markets,” www.lancs.ac.uk/users/philosophy/mave/mh_2.htm, Downloaded on 12-5-2004)

“Conclusion

Market forces will never meaningfully reduce consumption… limits of ecological sustainability ever be effective.”

 

Contention 3 – Deliberative Democracy

 

We believe the framework for the debate should be one of deliberative democracy. The role of the ballot in this debate is to decide which team advanced the most accessible, inclusive, and legitimate arguments for a specific government course of action. The benefit of our approach is its empowering vision of agency.

Guttmann, President of the University of Pennsylvania, and Thompson, Alfred North Whitehead Professor of Political Philosophy at Harvard University, 2004

[Amy and Dennis, Why Deliberative Democracy?, p. 3-7]

“Most fundamentally, deliberative democracy affirms… how its critics can be answered.”

 

Deliberative Democracy is a particularly appropriate as a framework to engage environmental policy-making. The net benefit of this framework for debate is the expansion of Green Citizenship. It is this citizenship that is central to successful embrace of sustainable relations with the environment.

Barry, lecturer in the Department of Politics at Keele University, 1999

[John, Rethinking Green Politics, p. 230-231]

“The introduction of communicative rationality to the co-ordination… support of 'green' or 'ecological' causes and attitudes.”

 

 


Coal / Deliberative Democracy 1AC

 

Our framework of deliberative democracy is also necessary to flip the switch from a consumption-based relationship with the environment to an environmentally responsible citizenry

Barry, lecturer in the Department of Politics at Keele University, 1999

[John, Rethinking Green Politics, p. 218-219]

“The advantages of a deliberative approach can be seen by looking… can and ought to be raised.”

 

We don’t presume to act as representatives in congress – our claim is that this debate is a local site of argumentative expression for the interests of citizens in environmental policymaking. Such avenues of public expression of interest are necessary to an informed, cooperative public on environmental questions.

Barry, lecturer in the Department of Politics at Keele University, 1999

[John, Rethinking Green Politics, p. 229-230]

“It is also related to the claims of the last section where green democracy… consideration of the interests of affected others.”

 

Viewing debate as a local site of democratic deliberation suggests the function of the round is social learning about our ability to function as citizens. This approach is the best pedagogic view of debate.

Barry, lecturer in the Department of Politics at Keele University, 1999

[John, Rethinking Green Politics, p. 229]

“The green claim to a principled as opposed to an instrumental adherence… restructuring of the state and economy.”

 

Furthermore, real improvements in environmental justice must come through deliberative democracy about government policy. Any other approach to these problems fails to join and shape the ongoing discourse to remake society.

Torres – Counsel to the Attorney General, on leave from the University of Texas Law School – Spring 1994

(Gerald, Fordham Urban Law Journal, “Environmental Burdens and Democratic Justice,” 21 Fordham Urb. L.J. 431)

“V. Conclusion

Our current level of knowledge requires that we begin developing… twenty years as a problem that never went away. n153”

Finally, our move to advocate for Appalachia is the essential point to enter into the ongoing democratic deliberation over environmental justice.

Hamline Journal of Public Law & Policy – Spring 2004

(Hannha C. Halbert – Juris Doctorate candidate, May 2006, “From Picket Line to Courtroom: The Changing Forum for Regional Resistance, Environmental Reform and Policy Change in Appalachia,” 25 Hamline J. Pub. L. & Pol'y 375)

“V. Conclusion

Appalachia is a unique cultural region… environmental standards, the dialogue must change.”

 

 


USC (Fiori & Jones)

USC (Iftimie & Smith)

UTD CS

 

Observation One:  DA SQUO

 

 

First, FERC has rejected all attempts by the states to mandate higher fixed rates for wind and solar energy and renewable bid reservations because they violate section 210 of PURPA ­ another ruling against would lead to the cancellation of the state programs and a national chilling effect on renewable development.

 

 

Detsky, 2003

[Mike, Colorado Journal of International Environmental Law and Policy, Spring]

 

 

“On the eve of California…Senate in 2002.”

 

 

Ferc has ruled that the states cant’ set renewable rates above avoided costs. These avoided cost contracts are expiring seeom, leaving renewable produces facing sharp declines in rates

 

Zucchet 2002

(Michael, renewable resource electricity in the changing regulatory environment. http://www.eia.doe.gov/cneaf/pubs_html/rea/feature2.html)

 

“Ferc oversees several aspects…….would create financial problems for QF’s”

 

Plan: The United States Federal Government should amend the Public Utilities Regulatory Policy Act to require all non-governmental utilites to reduce consumption of fossil fuels by 5% by 2007 and 20% by 2020 to be implemented through standardized, mandatory retail purchase and interconnection of solar and renewable biomass energy

 

 

 

Net metering will provide a valuable means for famers and rural communities by allowing them to produce their own biomass electricity and sell it to the grd

 

Union of Concerned Scientists, 2002

(clean energy blueprint benefits farmers and rural communities. http://www.ucsusa.org/clean_energy/page.cfm?pageID=792)

 

“By increasing renewable energy use,……………electricity from renewable energy systems”

 

Second, current interconnection standards and net metering provisions are fragmented and impose high costs on small scale renewable producers attempting to connect to the grid.  National Standards are needed to reduce market uncertainty.

 

 

Garman, 2001

[David, http://www.eere.energy.gov/office_eere/congressional_test_071901.html?print]

 

 

“Distributed electricity generation…process of generating electricity.”

 

 

performance, and reliability standards for solar energy and wind energy producers.  We reserve the right to clarify intent.

 

 

Advantage One:  Stuff

 

 

Currently, small farms are collapsing due to the economic strain of competition with industrial farms.

 

 

Mittal, 2001

[Anuradha, Freedom to Trade, Food First Backgrounder, Foodfirst.org]

 

 

“Small farms contribute…local economy four times.”

 

 

And, as small farms disappear, so too does agricultural diversity.  Small farmers practice techniques that preserve diverse crop varieties and encourage preservation of wild plant species.

 

 

Boyce 2004

[James, http://www.umass.edu/peri/pdfs/WP86.pdf, July]

 

 

“Around the world, it is generally small farms…and low-diversity agricultural ecosystems.”

 

Renewable solar and biomass are critical to revitalizing rural communities

(Ames and Werner, September 9, 2001. http://www.agobservatory.org/library.cfm?refID=30145)

“U.S agriculture is at a crossroads…………opportunity that is good for American farmers and good for their country”

 

 

And, this decline in agricultural diversity puts the US agricultural system on the brink of total collapse

 

 

Union of Concerned Scientists, 2001

[Industrial Agriculture: Features and Policies, www.ucsusa.org]

 

 

“US agriculture rests on a narrow genetic…on their way to oblivion.”

 

 

And, preservation of small farmers and their practices is the sine qua non of diversity and ultimately human survival.

 

 

Boyce 2004

[James, http://www.umass.edu/peri/pdfs/WP86.pdf, July]

 

 

“There is a future for small farms…of the northwestern United States.”

 

Local farmers are necessary to face the inevitable departure of corporate agriculture and preclude wars for food and culminating in extinction.

Ikerd, 2002

(John, Mother Jones News. http://www.findarticles.com/articles/mi_m1279/is_2002_june-july/ai_86388781)

 

 

Food Shortages will cause nations to go to war over food, sparking world war three

Calvin, 98

(A Brain for All Season, http://William Calvin.com/BrainForAllSeasons/NAcoast.htm)

 

 

“Futurists have learned to bracket the future……..extram warming from the north atlantic”

 

 

 

 

Advantage Two:  The grid

 

The centralized model of electricity delivery makes a major, endemic failure inevitable- decentralizing the electricity distribution creates resilience and makes grid collapse impossible.

 

Lovins, Datta Swisher, 2002

(Small is profitable: The hidden economic benefits of making electrical resources the right size, Rocky Mountain institute)

“Vulnerability: brittle power Brittle Power, an extensive …………..just by choosing the best buys first”

 

Grid Upgrades and reforms focus on bigger lines and longer transmission distances which make cascading failure more likely and harder to contain

Lovins, 2003

(http://www.commondreams.org/views03/0821-02.htm , August 21, 2003)

 

“The usual suspects – politicians, regulators, deregulators, utilites and environmentalists…..choose to tailor their usage to price, and decentralized generation.”

 

We control uniqueness- aging and unreliable centralized power stations are being retired in the status quo. The long lag time in replacing these plants will bankrupt the utility industry and make load synchronization more difficult.

 

Lovins, Datta, and Swisher, 2003

(Same as above)

 

“Admist the ‘noise’ of short- and medium……..over a larger increment and during a longer period”

 

 

 

And, the lack of proper infrastructure makes it impossible to contain a blackout ­ once it begins the outage will spread at ludicrous speed

 

 

Makovich, 2003

[Larry, Capital Hill Testimony, FDCH, Committee: House Energy and Commerce, Headline: Power Blackouts, September 4, l/n]

 

 

“As power system conditions change…data, rules, and organizations.”

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Scenario 1: THE ECON

And, just a few days of outages from blackouts would reduce economic growth to zero and destroy the information-based economy

 

 

Brayn, 2003

[Jay, The Gazette (Montreal, Quebec), August 19]

 

 

“This worsened the already…an information-age economy”

 

 

And, this widespread failure of the information technology infrastructure will destroy the global ecnomy and plunge the word into recession

 

 

Yardeni, 1999

[Edward, http://forum.ra.utk.edu/1999summer/riskybiz.htm]

 

 

“Our global and domestic markets…world trade and cause deflation.”

 

 

Finally, economic collapse will plunge the world into nuclear conflict, ending all life on earth

 

 

Bearden in 2000

[T.E., June 24, http://www.seaspower.com/EnergyCrisis-Bearden.htm]

 

 

“Bluntly, we foresee these factors…at least for many decades.”

 

 

SCENARIO 2: NUCLEAR POWER

-       Blackouts lead to meltdown

Vann 2003

 

 

Regulatory measures preventing blackouts rely on more power lines and transmissions increases which will only make the risk of catastrophic grid failture more likely

 

Lovins, 2003

(Amory. http://www.commondreams.org/views03/0821-02.htm)

 

-Meltdown kills millions

Wasserman 2000

 

Impact is extinction

Grossman 97

 

 

Scenario 3: the red

 

Power failures will cause reactor meltdowns and accidental nuclear launches.

Earth Island Journal, 99

(y2k could hit nuclear power plants, 4:14)

“the third type could happen if the electricity fails…………recover and continue the mission”

 

Accidental launch escalates into full scale war and kills billions

PR newswire, 1998

(april 29, “NEJM study warns of increasing risk of accidental nuclear attack” lexis-nexis

 

 

 

 

Advantage 3: The Peak

 

Natural  Gas will peak globally in a world wide depression and rolling blackouts leading to societal disintegration

 

Rifkin, 2002

(Jeremy, The Hydrogen Economy, Putnam Press)

 

“New computer-model studies surveying……………we are familiar with or can even model or imagine)

 

 

The Natural gas peak will be dramatically worse than any oil shortage. The unexpected shortages will collapse the U.S economy.

 

Darley 2004.

(High Noon for natural gas: The Next Energy Crisis )

 

“The U.S. energy story is compley………a hydro-carbon hole, from which they will be hard to put to emerge unscathed”

 

Renewable electricity generation is key to ending  dependence on natural gas and preventing the impacts of peaking natural gas reserves

 

White,2004

(U.S dependence on imported Liquefied Natrual Gas, www.ceert.org/pubs/crrp/natgas/riskydiet2004.pdf)

“Thus, after 30 years of dependence on foreign oil, …………renewable energy sources in place of gas to produce electricity”

 

Observation Two: Solvency

 

 

A 20% reduction in utilites consumption of fossil fuels will stabilize natural gas and electricity prices.

Union of Concerned Scientists, 2004

(EIA Study: Natural Renewable Energy Standards of 20 percent easily affordable. Http://www.ucsusa.org/clean_energy/renewable_energy/page.cfm?page ID=45)

“ a national renewable portfolio standard to provide……save gas customers $10 billion per year by 2020”

 

 “Renewable energy (RE) is derived from … their recent energy crisis.”

 

 

 

 

 

PURPA must be amended to esatablish a fixed pricing policy for renewable energy

Gipe, 2002

(http://www.wind-works.org/articles/SCEndorse FeedLaw.html Sierra Club endorses Electricity Feed Law)

“ Electricity Feed Laws, so called because they allow owners of wind……….to create a standard purchase prices for wind, solar, and agricultural biomass”

 

And, uniform interconnection standards are essential to promoting small-scale renewable solar and wind systems.  Without clear national standards, the cost of switching to renewables will be an absolute deal breaker

 

 

Stars, 2001

[Thomas, http://energycommerce.house.gov/107/hearings/07272001Hearing340/Starrs560.htm]

 

 

“One of the most significant barriers…an absolute deal-breaker”

 

 

And, the retail purchase rate is the determining factor is making small-scale renewables economically viable

 

 

Stars, 1996

[Thomas, http://www.crest.org/repp_pubs/articles/issuebr2/issuebr2.pdf]

 

 

“In determining the economic feasibility…adverse utility revenue impacts”

 

 

Finally, distributed use of small-scale renewables will ensure grid reliability

 

 

Stars, 2001

[Thomas, http://energycommerce.house.gov/107/hearings/07272001Hearing340/Starrs560.htm]

 

 

“Continuing technology innovation is creating...from watts to megawatts”

 

 

 

 

Run by UTD Andreas and Denman at District III tournament.

>ADVANTAGE ONE: Fecal Matters

>The current ethics of waste privatizes refuse rendering it invisible
>and odorless. Its removal is bureaucratically managed and hidden from
>the view and smell of daily life. This process polices the boundaries
>of the body externalizing waste and rendering it shit; negative,
>valueless, and separate from the self.
>
>Hawkins 99
>(Gay, professor of Cultural Theory, University of New South Whales,
>Cultural Economies of Waste, paper presented to 'Rethinking Economy:
>Alternative Accounts, Australian National University, August, 1999,
>http://www.arts.monash.edu.au/projects/cep/knowledges/hawkins.html)
>
>The rhetoric of shit as negative influences our relationships with
>others. Bodies are labeled dirty and become expendable. Attempts at
>social change are considered the shit of disorder. The entire world is
>reduced to the imperial designs of waste disposal. These ethics judge
>others an affront to our own humanity and deem them expendable.
>
>Esty 99
>[Joshua D. - Professor of English at the University of Illinois,
>Urbana-Champaign, Contemporary Literature, Vol. 40, no. 1, p. 28-30]
>
>The construction of that which is external to the self as waste
>reduces people to bare life authorizing extermination.
>
>Agamben 98
>[Giorgio â€“ prof of philosophy European Graduate School, Homo Sacer:
>Sovereign Power and Bare Life, Stanford University Press, Stanford, p.
>3]
>
>Relationship to waste determines the way we use the world. It is a
>locus of technologies of the self in which we can alter our political
>relations with others.
>
>Cortez 2k4
>[Marisol F. â€“ Cultural Studies Ph.D. Candidate, University of
>California â€“ Davis, "Brown Meets Green: the Political Fecology of
>PoopReport.com," online:
>www.poopreport.com/Academic/Content/Cortez/cortez.doc]
>
>ADVANTAGE TWO: Deus ex Machina
>
>Waste offers an access point for the reexamination of our economic
>valuations, reveals the power of governmentality in our consumptive
>patterns, and configures modern society around the ordering mechanisms
>of thermodynamic machinations.
>
>Hawkins 99
>(Gay- professor of Cultural Theory, University of New South Whales,,
>Cultural Economies of Waste, paper presented to 'Rethinking Economy:
>Alternative Accounts, Australian National University, August, 1999,
>http://www.arts.monash.edu.au/projects/cep/knowledges/hawkins.html)
>
>This mechanistic rationale imposes technological domination on the way
>we can interact with the world and each other. Machines hold a
>privileged status making life expendable.
>
>Junger 93
>[Ernst â€“ German writer and literary critic, New German Critique, No.
>59, Spring â€“ Summer, p. 30-31]
>
>Biomass challenges the techno-scientific logic of conventional energy
>through the inclusion of people and practices considered worthless to
>industrial society.
>
>Visvanathan, 2k1
>(Shiv, senior fellow, Center for Study of Developing Societies,
>Reinventing Social Imagination, Between Cosmology and System,
>http://www.ces.fe.uc.pt/emancipa/research/en/ft/sonhos.html)
>
>CONTENTION TWO: The New Republic
>
>Decentralized biomass is a subversive form of resistance that
>undercuts the construction of obsolescence and the disciplinary
>domination of thermodynamics. This new radical democracy recycles
>ideas, waste, and pollutants making new room for ways of being and
>reinventing citizenship.*gender modified
>
>Visvanathan, 2k1
>(Shiv, senior fellow, Center for Study of Developing Societies,
>Reinventing Social Imagination, Between Cosmology and System,
>http://www.ces.fe.uc.pt/emancipa/research/en/ft/sonhos.html)
>
>Our relationship to shit is transformative â€“ breaking down the
>barriers between waste and self are critical to an ethics of
>responsibility that prevents us from devaluing and eliminating what is
>external to the body.
>
>Cortez 2k4
>[Marisol F. â€“ Cultural Studies Ph.D. Candidate, University of
>California â€“ Davis, "Brown Meets Green: the Political Fecology of
>PoopReport.com," online:
>www.poopreport.com/Academic/Content/Cortez/cortez.doc]
>
>The choice of home power biomass systems alters our relationship to
>technology and the political system. This break from conventional
>politics makes room for excluded voices that are rendered outside the
>current forum.
>
>Tatum 99
>(Jesse S., Muted Voices: The Recovery of Democracy in the Shaping of
>Technology, London University Press, 1999)
>

Vermont, Jason Hitchcock & Nick Landsman-Roos

Contention One: Current US consumption of oil shows no sign of
decline—elimination of trade barriers by NAFTA and unwillingness to drill
domestically ensures long term dependency on Middle Eastern oil
Stacey L. Middleton (J.D. Candidate @ Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law) “How
The Petroleum Addict Negotiates With The Dealer: Challenges To The Bush
Administration's North American Energy Policy” Cardozo Journal of International
and Comparative Law; 11 Cardozo J. Int'l & Comp. L. 177; Spring, 2003; l/n
//nick

threatening sovereignty over natural resources and spurring Canadian calls for
renegotiations of NAFTA Chapter Six

The Petroleum Addict Negotiates With The Dealer: Challenges To The Bush
Administration's North American Energy Policy” Cardozo Journal of International
and Comparative Law; 11 Cardozo J. Int'l & Comp. L. 177; Spring, 2003; l/n

and Comparative Law; 11 Cardozo J. Int'l & Comp. L. 177; Spring, 2003; l/n

Contention Three: East Asia Energy Crisis
The US and China are in a tussle for Middle Eastern Oil—although the US would
probably win the war for Saudi Oil, Chinese dependency might force conflict in
other parts of the world
Paul Roberts (author of "The End of Oil: On the Edge of a Perilous New World.”)
“The undeclared oil war” Alameda Times-Star (Alameda, CA); July 4, 2004 Sunday

-- And despite China’s importation of oil from the Middle East in the status quo
it’s on the brink of extending its control to the Spratly Islands.  This
expansion would result in many scenarios for armed conflict and war
John Thornhill “As the world's most populous nation emerges as the next Asian
superpower John Thornhill examines the possible repercussions for the security
and the economy of the region”; Financial Times (London,England); December 3,
2002 Tuesday; l/n //nick

-- And, US reductions in importation from the Middle East wont impact Middle
Eastern exports because China will step in to buy exports—but continued US
influence in the region would force China to exert military dominance in East
Asia, most likely in the Spartly Islands, to gain control over energy there
even at the cost of a conflict with the US
Ed Blanche (staff writer) “China Turns to The Gulf”; Global News Wire; Arabies
Trends; January 1, 2003; l/n //nick

-- And war over the Spratly Islands escalates to global nuclear war between the
US
and China
The Nikkei Weekly (Japan); “Developing Asian nations should be allowed a grace
period to allow their economies to grow before being subjected to trade
liberalization demands, says Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad”; July
3, 1995; l/n //nick

Thus the plan:
The United States Federal Government should establish an energy policy by
amending Chapter Six of the North American Free Trade Agreement to require a
substantial reduction in total non-governmental consumption of fossil fuels in
the United States by limiting its importation of fossil fuels to a baseline
level equal to current cdomestic production. We’ll Clarify.

Contention Three: Solvency
Federal action to amend Chapter Six of NAFTA to limit its importation of fossil
to a baseline level equal to domestic production is critical to patching up
relations with Canada and decreasing or stopping or dependency on Middle
Eastern oil.
Stacey L. Middleton (J.D. Candidate @ Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law) “How
The Petroleum Addict Negotiates With The Dealer: Challenges To The Bush
Administration's North American Energy Policy” Cardozo Journal of International
and Comparative Law; 11 Cardozo J. Int'l & Comp. L. 177; Spring, 2003; l/n
//nick

Contention Three: Boreal Hybridity

The Federal government must amend NAFTA Chapter Six to create a more equitable
energy policy with Canada that will stop the depletion of their natural
resources in Alberta
Stacey L. Middleton (J.D. Candidate @ Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law) “How
The Petroleum Addict Negotiates With The Dealer: Challenges To The Bush
Administration's North American Energy Policy” Cardozo Journal of International
and Comparative Law; 11 Cardozo J. Int'l & Comp. L. 177; Spring, 2003; l/n
//nick

Reconceptualization of the Boreal forest as a cyborg is critical to promoting
the principles of social-ecological inclusivity—only through this synthesis
embodied in the cyborg can be recognize the inevitability of power structures
and then seize governmentality to take a stand against modernist
techno-management;  this representation has real material effects—the
democratization of forest-nature discourse through the cyborg is the first step
in combating colonial domination and creating a new environmental ethic
Andrew Baldwin (Carleton University) “The Nature of the Boreal Forest:
Governmentality and Forest-Nature” Space and Culture; 2003; Vol. 6, No. 4; p.
415-428; SAGE Publications //nick

limit for all proposals.

terminals

Wake Forest CH

 

Wake CH 1AC

 

Plan: The United States Federal Government should through legislation establish a cap on non-governmental carbon dioxide emissions, reducing it to two thirds of present levels by 2020 by mandating a reduction in fossil fuel consumption, and implement the cap through auctioned tradable permits. We’ll clarify intent.

 

Plan: The United States Federal Government should legislatively establish a cap on non-governmental carbon dioxide emissions from fossil fuel consumption, reducing them to two-thirds of 2004 levels by 2020. The cap should be implemented through an auctioned cap and trade system. Emissions credits will be based on reductions in fossil fuel consumption. We will clarify if asked.

 

Plan: The United States Federal Government should through legislation establish a cap on non-governmental carbon dioxide emissions, reducing it to two thirds of present levels by 2020 by mandating a reduction in fossil fuel consumption, and implement the cap through tradable permits. We’ll clarify intent.

Access to energy is key to solve

Sarah Espenhahn, and Gill Wilkins, consultants at Future Energy Solutions,  Mar 2002.

Powering development The World Today. London: Vol.58, Iss. 3;  pg. 22, 3 pgs

 

“ENERGY HAS A KEY ROLE in development. . . some economies to stay afloat.”

 

Redistribution requires reducing consumption

John Goekler, Facing the Future: People and the Planet Kim Bush, and Gilda Wheeler, Sustainable Solutions to the World Energy Crisis, 2003 http://www.global-issues.net/In_Depth/energy3.htm

“On the international level. . . of what is already available.”

 

Morally responsible to do something, small issues and semantics are trivial and not reasons to not act.

Pogge, professor of philosophy at Columbia, 2000

Dissent, Fall, (Thomas), “The moral demands of global justice”

Vol. 47, Iss. 4;  pg. 37, 6 pgs

 

“IT IS OFTEN said that moral reflections. . . reforms in the global economic order.”

 

 

Wayne State Farmer & Murill

this is the aff we ran at districts:

Contention One: Market Barriers
Current pricing legislation ensures that utilities
will not purchase renewable energy from Indigenous
lands--- this is the tribe’s major impediment to
economic sovereignty

Gough, Secretary of the Intertribal Council On Utility
Policy, 2002
(Bob, Great Plains Natural Resources Journal, Fall
page lexis gjm)

“Because of the negative impacts … of strengthening
this sovereignty. Thank you.”

Indian Country is a maze of regulatory uncertainty-
Federal action is necessary to clear the way for
renewables

LeBeau, Vice President of Earth Energy & Environment,
2001
(Tracey, Stanford Law & Policy Review, page lexis gjm)

“In the area of utility regulation … a tremendously
more coherent tribal-federal regulatory process.”

Advantage One: Culture
The California Public Utilities Commission will not
permanently close the Mohave generation station –
however temporary shut down is inevitable – this is
disastrous for indigenous peoples

The U.S. Coal Review, December 13, 2004 page lexis gjm

“In fact, regulators … extension of the deadline to
idle the plant.”

Coal production on indigenous lands is an extension of
colonialism-indigenous peoples become as expendable as
the resources on their lands.

Robyn, assistant professor in the Criminal Justice
Department at Northern Arizona University, 2002
(Linda, The American Indian Quarterly, Spring, project
muse gjm)

“Colonialism continues today … exploitable group or
disposable resource”

Coal mining on the Black Mesa is annihilating
indigenous culture- it destroys the land and exhausts
the water needed to farm and raise cattle.

Reily, director of editorial business for Times,
6-6-2004 (Sean Patrick, The Los Angeles Times, L/N,
MAF)

“For years upon years beneath star-heavy skies … each
part to make the other work."

The Black Mesa operations are uniquely oppressive- the
Hopi and Navajo are under-compensated and the coal
slurry operations deplete the water that is essential
to their way of life

The Irish Times 2-4-2004

“However, ongoing habitation of this area … They will
think they are gods."

Consumption of indigenous lands is the consumption of
indigenous cultures – this threatens their very
survival

Suagee, Director of the First Nations Environmental
Law Program, 1991
(Dean, University of Michigan Journal of Law Reform
page lexis gjm)

“As the industrialized societies … force marks the
other end.”

Plan

Text: The United States Federal Government through the
Department of Defense should require the phased
closure of the Mohave Generation Station and
replacement of the energy currently produced there
with solar source(s).  Utilities should be required to
purchase -- at a fixed minimum price, and grant grid
access for wind and solar-produced electricity from
Indian Country.  Funding and enforcement is
guaranteed.  We reserve the right to clarify.

Contention Two: Solvency

Solar projects on Black Mesa insulate the Hopi and
Navajo from the economic impacts of plant closure ---
and is consistent with their cultures

Masayesva, Executive Director, Black Mesa Trust,
6-27-2004 (Vernon, Los Angeles Times, L/N, MAF)

“Sean Patrick Reily's article "Gathering Clouds" …
Indian water that is being abused?”

Black Mesa plants

are geothermal, biomass, and wind”

need to rapidly drive down the costs of renewables

this is our RPS aff / add-ons

Plan:

The United States Federal Government, through the
Department of Energy, should establish an energy
policy based on a gradual federal Renewable Portfolio
Standard to substantially reduce the total consumption
of fossil fuels in the United States.

Specifically, the RPS should require
non-governmentally owned electrical power firms to
reduce their existing and future plants’ consumption
of fossil fuels by 2% in 2006, rising incrementally
each year to 10% by 2010 and 20% by 2020, and replace
that consumption with non-hydroelectric renewable
energy. Firms may meet these targets by: incorporating
renewable technologies within their plants, buying
renewable produced energy from other suppliers, or
purchasing renewable energy credits from other firms.

Funding and enforcement guaranteed through normal
means, we reserve the right to clarify

The Advantage is Competitiveness

A. Competitiveness is critical to maintaining the US
role as world stabilizer

The world wide transition to renewable energy is
inevitable – lack of development will cause the US to
lose its edge in this critical sector

Judy Biggert, FDCH Political Transcripts, May 19, 2004
page lexis

The renewables market is rapidly expanding – the US
stands to miss out on this multibillion dollar energy
revolution

Janet Sawin, Climate Wise, March 2002
http://www.greenbiz.com/news/columns_third.cfm?NewsID=20066

Failure to compete in the renewables market will
cripple US economic and technological competitiveness

Bradeck Hendricks, FDCH Congressional Testimony,
February 12, 2004 page lexis

US Technological dominance is key to maintaining US
hegemony

Michael Smith, FDCH Congressional Testimony, September
18, 2002 page lexis

US hegemony is key to preventing terrorism and nuclear
war

Niall Fergusen, Foreign Policy Issue 143, July/August
2004 page 32

B. A Federal RPS will ensure US competitiveness and
technological dominance

A 20% RPS will create a predictable and broad market
for renewable energy in the US leading to increased
investment and R&D

Daniel Kammen, FDCH July 11, 2001 page lexis

A RPS with cap and trade increases flexibility,
boosting investment and R & D

JR Drabick, BioCycle, October 2003 page proquest

Contention Two: Our Framework

A. Our Theory

First – We’ll defend the international system of
realism – this is a system that is absolutely
inevitable which makes pragmatic views the only hope
of overcoming systems of domination

Alastair Murray, Reconstructing Realism: Between Power
Politics and Cosmopolitan Ethics, 1997

Secondly – Attempts to transcend realism are doomed to
failure because they privilege nebulous change to the
detriment of stability

Alastair Murray, Reconstructing Realism: Between Power
Politics and Cosmopolitan Ethics, 1997

We’ll also defend our mechanism of environmental
policy – only confronting this system can allow for a
sustainable foundation for the prevention of
environmental destruction – laws inevitability makes
it impossible to ignore these interactions

Daniel Farber, Eco-Pragmatism, 1999 page 205-206

Finally – Attempts to move away from capitalism causes
transition wars that threaten humanity

Perry Anderson, In the Tracks of Historical
Materialism, 1984 pages 102-103

B. Our practice –

We’ll defend the educational benefits of flip side
research intensive debate –

First – Engaging in policy making promotes vigorous
academic research that is critical to education

Kristin Chisholm Dybvig and Joel O Iverson, 1999
http://debate.uvm.edu/dybvigiverson1000.html

Secondly – role-playing forces us to step outside our
belief system which increases critical thinking and
creates a springboard for participatory democracy and
activism

Gordon Mitchell, Argumentation and Advocacy, Winter
2000 page proquest

Finally – Our framework of flip side debate promotes
testing assumptions by forcing debaters to engage a
stable advocacy and defend both sides of an issue

Gregory Jay, College English, 1994 page proquest

Sometimes we take out the B subpoint and the framework
and read these advantages/ solvency:

Advantage Two: Trade Wars

Only a federal RPS can prevent EU trade wars and
protectionism

Peter Fontaine, Public Utilities Fortnightly, August
2004 page lexis

Trade wars go nuclear

Spicer 1996

Advantage Three: Warming

New data proves warming is real and anthropogenic

The Times (London), May 06, 2004 page lexis

The current rate of warming assures extinction

John Brandenburg and Monica Paxson, Dead Mars, Dying
Earth 1999 page 232

Warming leads to the spread of diseases via insects –
the impact is species loss and deforestation

Ross Gelbspan, Boiling Point, 2004
www.bookbrowse.com/index.cfm?page=title&titleID=1474&view=excerpt

The impact is extinction

Laurie Garrett, The Coming Plague, 1996 page 5-6

Climate change decreases the abundance of species in
the soil

Rounsevell, Evans and Bullock, Climatic Change 1999
page 699

Increased CO2 will decrease plant growth

Rotter and Van De Geijn, Climatic Change, 1999 page
658-659

Weeds are decreasing crop yields by 25% per year

Patterson, Westbrook and Rogasik, Climate Change, 1999
page 712

Weeds outweigh the benefits of CO2

Patterson, Westbrook and Rogasik, Climate Change, 1999
(sorry no page number)

Blips in food prices kill billions

Tampa Tribune January 20, 1996

Climate change spurs world wide conflict and multiple
scenarios for nuclear escalation

Peter Schwartz and Doug Randall, An Abrupt Climate
Change, October 2003
www.gbn.org/ArticleDisplayServlet.srv?aid=26231

Adaptation assumes SQ food production – warming makes
this impossible

Peter Schwartz and Doug Randall, An Abrupt Climate
Change, October 2003
www.gbn.org/ArticleDisplayServlet.srv?aid=26231

Contention Two: Solvency

A 20% RPS will create a predictable and broad market
for renewable energy in the US leading to increased
investment and R&D

Daniel Kammen, FDCH July 11, 2001 page lexis

US leadership is key to slowing the rate of warming

Guy Dauncey, Earth Island Journal, Autumn 2003 page
proquest

boosting investment and R & D

2003 page lexis

we also have a critical aff that makes the following
arguments:

-- consumption is a circular process we consume fossil
fuels, but fossil fuels also consume us (we us detroit
as a metaphor for this)

-- capitalism constructs our identity, part of this
argument is the argument that we should redefine the
concept of fossil fuels to include individuals as
fossil fuels (we are organic material under constant
pressure used to energize the system of capitalism)

-- street art in detroit is an analogy for our form of
politics -- its an everyday form of resitance that can
create a temporary break from the capitalist system

-- we read a bleiker card about how this form of
resistance breaks down larger superstructures and how
we need a multitude of circular politics

Bleiker, School of Political Science, University of
Queensland, Brisbane, 2003
(Roland, Contemporary Political Theory page proquest
GJM)

as far as an advocacy statement, we usually defend all
of the 1AC but we usually also read we require a
reduction in the consumption of the self

In this file is our 1ac, our only add on we read so far, and on the last page is our generic neg strat.

/Nuke power 1ac

 

Cont one

Sub a

4/5ths of coal power plants are exempt from govt pollution controls

Shi-ling HSU, assc prof of law, geo wash uni law school, summer 2001, 14 tul. Envtl. L.j 427, lexis

“nearly four-fifths…..[hereinafter Najor I]”

 

Sub B

Air pollution

1. coal plants = dirty emissions

Hsu-2001

“the electricity generation industry…further emissions reductions”

 

2.  kill 30000 a year

Bernard Cohen, 2004, the nuclear power advantage, http://npcil.org/nupower_vol13_4/npaavpo14.htm

“air pollution:  while….illness are also substantial”

 

Acid rain

1.  coal plants = acid rain

Hsu 2001

“retiring coal-fired power plants….below 1990 levels”

 

2.  acid rain hurts eco systems

Richard TURCO, 2002, earth under siege, p 260-261

“in the beginning, the precursors……through the local ecosystem”

 

3. disruptions to the econsystem = extinction

Susan harder, 2004, www.vancouver.wsu.edu/fac/harders/spring2003/biodiversity _lecture.pdf

 

OZONE

Coal plants kill ozone

Pamela cohn, 1995, emory international law review, spring, 181-182

“sulfur dioxide causes….wait and see attitude”

 

2.  loss of the ozone =extinction

Turco 2002

 

Cont two

Oil dependency

Sub a

Us in increasingly dependent on oil

Michael T. Klare, prof at Hampshire college, Current history, “global petro-politics” march 2002 page 99

“growing American dependence…and latin America”

 

Sub b

Dependency on oil makes oil wars inevitable

Klare 2002

“oil is closely associated…a cause of war.”

 

Sub C

Only a shift to a hydrogen economy can permanently end us dependency on foreign oil

Paul Roberts, 2003, the end of oil

“this, of course….energy economy”

 

PLAN

The united states federal government should establish an energy policy requiring a substantial reduction in the total non-governmental consumption of fossil fuels in the united states by requiring the phase out of coal fired plants currently exempted from the clean air act and related amendments within five years and replacement by Integral Fast Reactors.  Funding and enforcement through normal means.  We have intent and reserve the right to clarify.

 

Cont three

Sub A

Substation of coal plants with integral fast reactors solves environmental impacts

Cohen 2004

“one important advantage….to ecological systems”

 

Sub b

Ifr best method for hydrogen

Brian downing quiq, march 22 1997, www.dcia.com/ifr.html

“in the advanced space….requires the ifr”

 

Sub c

Only hydrogen solves oil

Fortune nov 12 2001

“once the fuel…..displacement by hydrogen”

 

Sub d

Ifrs can provide energy for the same cost of a coal plant, uses nuclear waste as fuel, cant prolif and eliminates the risk of accidents

Minnesota daily, “dump yucca mountain nuclear disposal plan”, march 7, 2002, lexis

“scientists have been….reconsider that decision”

 

Sub E

Regs make nuclear power economical

Gerald E. Marsh, august 2003, the national center for public policy research.  #480 “nuclear power: clean, safe, and needing a level playing field”

http://www.nationalcenter.org/npa480.html

“nuclear power is economical….would be built”

 

Sub f

NRC is licensing new light water reactors now, making your prolif and waste impacts inevitable

Denis beller, journal of land, resources, & environmental law, “Atomic time machines: back to the nuclear future”, 24 j. land resources & envtl. L. 41, 2004, lexis

“while all of this has…from nuclear power.”

 

ADD ons

 

Yucca

Dumping of waste = genocide

Ward Churchill, American Indian culture and research journal, 1999 vol 23:4, pg 47

“taken as a whole….to be consummated

 

We solve-ca mini daily

John Gofman, 1996, http://www.ratical.com/radiation/cnr

“I hope that the…..maintain their neutrality”

 

Weber BS

 

AFFIRMATIVE STUFF

 

We run a Zombies affirmative sometimes (CONSULT negative disclosure).  Its basically the same thing, except it’s a reason to vote aff.  We don’t defend the whole resolution, instead we say that is we are ever going to respond to consumption, we must understand biopolitics.  Same evidence, same DOD clips.

 

We have ran an LNG affirmative.  Sometimes this is straight up (Wake Case list has it).   We claim accidents, warming, indigenous genocide (through gas demand), and a Turkish straights advanatage that says our demand is messing things up over there.   Our PT says to have FERC ban the consumption of Natural Gas in the U.S.

 

We also run the LNG aff critically, with the same plan text.  We say that LNG is the newest form of energy, and its capital’s attempt to make us buy into there energy sceme.   We talk about how LNG is made to look cleaner, more abundant, safer, and domestically secure.  In reality we say it’s a way that capitalism make us in its own image.   We are what we consume, and capital can only survive if we accept the reality that it gives us.  We must ban/say no to LNG to prevent capitalism’s accumulation of energy.  We read how LNG causes accidents, and destroys communities, and how the docks will be put in poorer communities, and the same indigenous advantage.  (CONSULT THE NEGATIVE CASE LIST FOR AUTHOR CITES)  We read Kovel evidence, LNG Watch in 2004 evidence, and some Julian Darley in 2004 evidence from a book called  “High Noon for Natural Gas).

 

The Last affirmative that we run is Net Metering:

 

This is also on the case list, and it almost identical to the way UT-Dallas is running theirs.  We claim nuclear blackouts, agrodiversity, LNG trade-off, warming, and terrorism sometimes.   Our plan text is to have the FERC cap consumption at 20% and then force non governmental electrical producers to net meter at the retail rate for renewables.   We specify a 1% a year implementation phase in.

 

Outline

 

 

Distributed Generation is almost non existent.  Although we have the technology, three independent barriers prevent consitency and new renewable development.

 

Kalland in 2002 (Steven, “Federal Muscle flexing at the FERC Volume 3 Issue 6, November- December 2002 www.jxj.com/magsandj/cospp/2002_06/net_metering.html)-mikee

 

 

DG CONSISTENCY IS A PROBLEM, MAKING NET METERING PROBLEMATIC IN THE STATUS QUO.

Kalland in 2002 (Steven, “Federal Muscle flexing at the FERC Volume 3 Issue 6, November- December 2002 www.jxj.com/magsandj/cospp/2002_06/net_metering.html)-mikee

 

 

There is no federal net metering law and current state laws very too much to be effective.

NREC in 2003 (National Rural Electric Cooperative April 2003

http://www.nreca.org/nreca/policy/regulatory/Whitepaper/Whitepaper.pdf)-mikee

 

 

 

 

Decades of dependence on fossil fuels has accelerated the impacts of blackouts, in out current system a grid collapse is inevitable.

 

Wasserman in 2003 (Harvey [senior advisor to the Nuclear Information & Resource Service, senior editor at the Free Press in Ohio] Democracy Now 2003, Monday August 18, “will our reliance on ff & nuclear energy cause even Bigger blackouts?)-mikee

 

 

 

ANOTHER NUCLEAR REACTOR MELTDOWN WOULD SPREAD RADIATION GLOBALLY, THIS WOULD UPSET CONTAMINATION CONDITIONS AND LEAD TO EXTINCTION.

 

Charles Hyder, who holds a Ph.D. in Astrogeophysics and worked at NASA  in 2002 (Charles [holds B.S. and M.S. degrees in physics from the University of New Mexico (1958,1960), and a Ph.D.  University of Colorado (1964).  He has published more than twenty solar and comet papers.] “Human Extinction on this Chernobyl Contaminated Planet,” www.members.fortunecity.com/osservatorio/charleshyderbook2.html

 

 

 

 

Renewables are the only way to solve

Brown in 2003 (Michael, “The right response to system failure to modernize,” May of 2003,  http”// www.jxj.com/magsandj/cospp/2003_05/index.html)-mikee

 

 

Energy Prices are hurting small farmers, they are key to agrodiversity.

Mittal in 2001 (Amerada, co-director, Food First, with Mayumi Kawaai, Freedom To Trade? Trading Away American Family Farms, October 19, 2001, www.mindfully.org/Farm/Trading-Away-Family-Farms.htm)-mikee

 

 

 Agro diversity key to prevent extinction

Fowler and Mooney in 1990

West Georgia KT

HEY THERE FASCIST - HERE'S THE FULL TEXT TO THE LATEST VERSION OF OUR
1AC, RUN AT NORTHWESTERN.
-=-=-=-=-=-=-

WELCOME TO THE SHORES OF BLOODY LAKE MICHIGAN, THE GREAT LAKE THAT MOST
LOOKS LIKE A PHALLUS, WHERE 10,000 YEARS AGO IN A DISPLAY OF FROZEN
MANIFEST DESTINY, THE ICE-AGE GLACIERS CONDUCTED A HOLOCIDAL WAR OF
PRE-IMPERIALISM AGAINST THE LIKES OF MANY KEYSTONE SPECIES SUCH AS THE
SABER TOOTHED TIGER AND THE WOOLY MAMMOTH.  IT IS UPON THE BONES OF
THESE MAJESTIC, IF OFTEN MISUNDERSTOOD, CREATURES THAT THE BRICKS AND
MORTAR OF NORTHWESTERN UNIVERSITY WAS BUILT.  WITHOUT THE SCREAMS OF
THOSE STARVING AND FREEZING ANIMALS WE COULD NOT ENJOY THE COMFORTS OF
OUR PRIVELEGED DEBATE SETTING .  IT IS IN RECOGNITION OF THIS FOUNDING
ACT OF VIOLENCE THAT THE 1AC STANDS IN AFFIRMATION OF THE LEFT SIDE OF
THE PAIRING.

-=-=-=-=-=-=-

<COMMENCE BRITISH VOICE>

NOW THAT THAT BULLSHIT IS OVER WITH, IT’S TIME TO TALK ABOUT SPACE, AND
SPATIALITY, AND THE CONCOMITANT SPATIALIZATION OF SPACE, AND HOW THAT’S
RELEVANT TO ALL THE SPACES THAT ENCOMPASS OUR DABAIT-SPACE. WE ARE IN
THE EPOCH OF SPACE, AND THE ANXIETY OF OUR CUBIC TIME IS ONE OF SPACE.
IN ORDER TO ACCESS ALTERITY AND INFINITE RESPECT FOR THE OTHERNESS OF
THE OTHER, WE MUST PERFORMATIVELY ENACT A PARALLEL AFFIRMATION  OF THE
SPACE INHABITED BY OTHERNESS. THIS PROCESS UN-INAUGURATES THE
CONDITIONS OF SPATIALITY THAT MAKES VIOLENCE POSSIBLE IN THE FIRST
PLACE. THE IMPETUS OF VIOLENCE IS THAT WHICH DENIES THE OTHER THEIR
SPACE, AND/OR SPATIALIZES THE OTHER INTO MARGINALIZED SPACES WHICH HAVE
BEEN PRE-SCRIPTED BY THE BUREAUCRACY-SPACE.

<END BRITISH VOICE>

THE SPATIAL COORDINATES OF OUR LIVES PRODUCE CARS, ARMORED PERSONNEL
CARRIERS, LIGHT TRUCKS, AMBULANCES, AND MONSTER TRUCKS.  THE REDUCTION
OF HUMAN LIFE TO SPATIALITY REACHES IT’S APOGEE IN PUBLIC
TRANSPORTATION, LIFE IS REDUCED TO YOUR POISTION VIS A VIS A BUS LINE,
AND THE BIOPOLITICAL CARE FOR THE POPULATION THAT ALLOWS
GOVERNMENTALITY TO MAKE MEANING OF LIFE ITSELF.  THE INTERNAL
COMBUSTION ENGINE OR THE GRANDFATHERED SMOKE SPEWING POWER PLANT WOULD
BE THE PROPER PLACE TO SITUATE OUR TOPIC KNOWLEGE, YET OBVIOUSLY WE
DON’T REALLY CARE AT ALL ABOUT THAT SO WE’LL CONTINUE TO WEAVE OUR WEB
OF DISINQUIRY.

IN RESPONSE TO THIS APORIA, IT IS PATENTLY OBVIOUS THAT THE MOST
ETHICAL RESPONSE IS TO AFFIRM THE TOPIC AS A HOMOTOPIA. THIS
AFFIRMATION RECONFIGURES THE BALLOT-SPACE AND THE DABAIT-SPACE AS A
DISCURSIVE HOMOTOPIA, THAT IS, WE EXAMINE THE DISCURSIVE SPACES OF THE
TOPIC AND THE RESOLUTION AND CONSUMPTION AND DABAIT ITSELF.  HOMOTOPIAS
ARE ABLE TO UNRAVEL THE HIDDEN MEANINGS AND THE GIVENNESS OF THESE
THINGS, FOR IT IS GIVENNESS, DEMARCATED TOPOGRAPHICAL BOUNDARIES, WHICH
SPATIALIZE NON-HOMOTOPIAS INTO MARGINALIZED SPACES AND NON-SPACES VIA
DISCURSIVE GENOCAUSTAL AND HOLOCIDAL IMPERIALISM.

IT’S BASICALLY JUST LIKE THE AMISH.

THE PROBLEMATIC OF SPACE IS ALSO TIED TO THE NOTION OF PROGRESS.  WHAT
WE CONCIEVE OF AS “PROGRESS” TIES DIRECTLY TO THE EUCLIDIAN ASSUMPTION
OF A 'PERFECT' INDEPENDENCE, AT SOME LEVEL, OF 'THINGS'. IT IS ON THE
BASIS OF THIS INDEPENDENCE OF 'THINGS' THAT WE HAVE CONSTRUCTED THE
ABSTRACT RATIONALIST NOTION OF 'CAUSALITY'. TWENTIETH CENTURY PHYSICS
HAS DEMONSTRATED
CONCLUSIVELY, HOWEVER, THAT SPACE IS NEITHER EUCLIDIAN NOR TIME
INDEPENDENT ; INSTEAD, THE NON-EUCLIDIAN SPACE-TIME CONTINUUM IS A
PARTICIPANT IN NATURAL PHENOMENA.  THE SCIENCE OF GEODESY, WHICH
DETERMINES THE EARTH’S SHAPE AND SIZE BY SURVEYS AND MATHEMATICAL
MODELING, HAS DETERMINED THAT THE EARTH IS IN FACT NOT A PERFECT
SPEHERE, BUT EXHIBITS THE ATTRIBUTES OF A GEOID.  WE CAN BE SAID TO BE
LIVING IN A GEOIDAL EPOCH, BECAUSE THE EARTH IS LITERALLY EARTH SHAPED.
THIS HAS BEEN CONFIRMED AS EARLY AS 247 B.C. BY THE GREEK GEOGRAPHER
ERATOSTHENES
THE FACT IS, THAT WE HAVE 'LEAKAGE' BETWEEN AND BETWIXT 'THINGS' AND
THE SPACE WHICH ENVELOPES THEM. THIS MEANS THAT OUR LINEAR EFFORTS TO
REORDER AND RESTRUCTURE THINGS SO THAT WE MIGHT 'PROGRESS' TOWARDS A
DESIRED STATE CANNOT SUCCEED, BECAUSE EACH TIME WE ATTEND TO THE NEXT
ITEM ON OUR LIST, OUR ACTIONS ARE BLEEDING THROUGH THE ETHER AND
EFFECTING THOSE THINGS WE JUST ATTENDED TO IN AN UNKNOWN AND
UNPREDICTABLE WAY. OUR EFFORTS AT 'PROGRESS' ARE AKIN TO RE-ARRANGING
DECK CHAIRS ON THE TITANIC.
SEEN THROUGH THE MORE REALITY-CONSISTENT LENSES OF A NON-EUCLIDIAN
SPACE-TIME CONTINUUM, WHEREIN SPACE IS A 'PARTICIPANT' ALONG WITH
'THINGS', THE REDUCTION OF LIFE TO GIVENNESS IS REPLACED WITH A NEW WAY
OF BEING IN THE WORLD; OUR FEAR OF ANTHROPIC MORTALITY IS
DECONSTRUCTED, AND THE REDUCTION OF LIFE TO THE ZERO POINT OF THE
TSUNAMI  IS SIMULTANEOUSLY ACHIEVED AND EXTINGUISHED.
